Rigidity of warped cones and coarse geometry of expanders

David Fisher ,¬† Thang Nguyen ¬†and¬† Wouter van Limbeek
(Date: March 12, 2024)
Abstract.

We study the geometry of warped cones over free, minimal isometric group actions and related constructions of expander graphs. We prove a rigidity theorem for the coarse geometry of such warped cones: Namely, if a group has no abelian factors, then two such warped cones are quasi-isometric if and only if the actions are finite covers of conjugate actions. As a consequence, we produce continuous families of non-quasi-isometric expanders and superexpanders. The proof relies on the use of coarse topology for warped cones, such as a computation of their coarse fundamental groups.

Contents
  1. 1 Introduction
  2. 2 Preliminary remarks
  3. 3 Coarse fundamental group of level sets of warped cones
  4. 4 Coarse homotopy invariance of group contributions
  5. 5 Stabilization of maps on coarse fundamental groups
  6. 6 Identification of growth rate by quasi-isometry
  7. 7 Construction of a semiconjugacy
  8. 8 Promotion of the semiconjugacy
  9. 9 Construction of families of expanders

1. Introduction

1.1. Brief overview:

This paper can be viewed from two distinct points of view. From one point of view, our primary contribution is proving the existence of wide classes of expanders and superexpanders which are geometrically different. These results are discussed in Subsection 1.3 of this introduction. From another point of view, we prove a dramatic rigidity result for group actions. Namely, we show that a certain geometric space associated to a group action, the warped cone of John Roe, is a complete conjugacy invariant for a large class of group actions. Our results on rigidity of group actions can be viewed as a dynamical analogue of quasi-isometric rigidity in geometric group theory and have other applications in the context of the coarse Baum-Connes conjecture. These results are discussed in Section 1.2. All the results on expanders and superexpanders are deduced from the rigidity results for group actions. The reader can read the next two subsections of this paper in either order, depending on their interests.

1.2. Warped Cones

Let ŒìŒì\Gamma be a finitely generated group acting isometrically on a compact metric space MùëÄM. For t>0ùë°0t>0, define the metric space Mt:=(t‚ÄãM√óŒì)/ŒìassignsubscriptùëÄùë°ùë°ùëÄŒìŒìM_{t}:=(tM\times\Gamma)/\Gamma, where t‚ÄãMùë°ùëÄtM is a copy of MùëÄM scaled by a factor tùë°t and ŒìŒì\Gamma is equipped with a fixed word metric. Define the geometric cone ùí¢‚Äã(Œì‚Ü∑M)ùí¢‚Ü∑ŒìM\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)} to be a metric space that assembles all MtsubscriptùëÄùë°M_{t} as ùí¢‚Äã(Œì‚Ü∑M)=(M√ó(0,‚àû)√óŒì)/Œìùí¢‚Ü∑ŒìMùëÄ0ŒìŒì\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)}=(M\times(0,\infty)\times\Gamma)/\Gamma where the metric on M√ó(0,‚àû)ùëÄ0M\times(0,\infty) is given by t‚Äãg+d‚Äãt2ùë°ùëîùëësuperscriptùë°2tg+dt^{2} for some fixed Riemannian metric gùëîg on MùëÄM. For isometric ŒìŒì\Gamma actions this definition coincides with Roe‚Äôs warped cone over a group action [Roe], see Remark 2.2. At times it is better for applications to consider instead the metric space ùíû‚Äã(Œì‚Ü∑M)ùíû‚Ü∑ŒìM\operatorname{\mathscr{C}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)} that is simply the disjoint union of the MtsubscriptùëÄùë°M_{t}. We will study warped cones up to quasi-isometry.

Definition 1.1.

Let XùëãX and YùëåY be metric spaces. A map f:X‚ÜíY:ùëì‚Üíùëãùëåf:X\rightarrow Y is an (L,C)ùêøùê∂(L,C)-quasi-isometry if there exist L>1ùêø1L>1 and C>0ùê∂0C>0 such that:

  1. (1)

    for every a,b‚ààXùëéùëèùëãa,b\in X we have 1L‚ÄãdX‚Äã(a,b)‚àíC‚â§dY‚Äã(f‚Äã(a),f‚Äã(b))‚â§L‚ÄãdX‚Äã(a,b)+C1ùêøsubscriptùëëùëãùëéùëèùê∂subscriptùëëùëåùëìùëéùëìùëèùêøsubscriptùëëùëãùëéùëèùê∂\frac{1}{L}d_{X}(a,b)-C\leq d_{Y}(f(a),f(b))\leq Ld_{X}(a,b)+C

  2. (2)

    for every y‚ààYùë¶ùëåy\in Y, there is x‚ààXùë•ùëãx\in X such that dY‚Äã(f‚Äã(x),y)‚â§Csubscriptùëëùëåùëìùë•ùë¶ùê∂d_{Y}(f(x),y)\leq C.

To study quasi-isometries of disjoint unions of level sets, we need to extend this notion slightly. Given a collection of spaces {Xt}t‚ààTsubscriptsubscriptùëãùë°ùë°ùëá\{X_{t}\}_{t\in T} and {Ys}s‚ààSsubscriptsubscriptùëåùë†ùë†ùëÜ\{Y_{s}\}_{s\in S} we call them (L,C)ùêøùê∂(L,C)-quasi-isometric if there is a bijection œï:T‚ÜíS:italic-œï‚ÜíùëáùëÜ\phi:T\rightarrow S and (L,C)ùêøùê∂(L,C)-quasi-isometries ft:Xt‚ÜíYœï‚Äã(t):subscriptùëìùë°‚Üísubscriptùëãùë°subscriptùëåitalic-œïùë°f_{t}:X_{t}\rightarrow Y_{\phi(t)}. As usual spaces or collections of spaces are quasi-isometric if there exist some L>1ùêø1L>1 and C>0ùê∂0C>0 for which they are (L,C)ùêøùê∂(L,C)-quasi-isometric.

To state a version of our results we need to define what it means for group actions to be commensurable. While this is similar to, and motivated by, the definition of commensurability for finitely generated groups, we warn the reader that actions of commensurable groups are not commensurable in this sense and in fact need not give rise to quasi-isometric warped cones! The notion in this context is slightly more complicated than in the world of finitely generated groups.

Definition 1.2.

Two group actions Œì0‚Ü∑M0‚Ü∑subscriptŒì0subscriptùëÄ0\Gamma_{0}\curvearrowright M_{0} and Œì1‚Ü∑M1‚Ü∑subscriptŒì1subscriptùëÄ1\Gamma_{1}\curvearrowright M_{1} are commensurable if

  • ‚Ä¢

    MisubscriptùëÄùëñM_{i} is a finite cover of Mi‚àí1subscriptùëÄùëñ1M_{i-1} for one of i=0,1ùëñ01i=0,1 and

  • ‚Ä¢

    for the same index iùëñi we have that ŒìisubscriptŒìùëñ\Gamma_{i} is the group of lifts of Œìi‚àí1subscriptŒìùëñ1\Gamma_{i-1} to MisubscriptùëÄùëñM_{i}.

In the definition the indices should be interpreted modulo 222. This is slightly awkward but in the actual theorems it will be finite quotients of the original actions that are related, not finite covers. This last notion corresponds most closely to the idea of two subgroups of a larger group having intersection which has finite index in both, i.e. the extrinsic definition of commensurability. For the intrinisic definition of commensurablity, i.e. the analogue of having isomorphic finite index subgroups, it is useful to make explicit the notion of when two actions are isomorphic up to commensuration. In particular, the regularity of the commensurating map plays a role in applications.

Definition 1.3.

A commensuration of the actions Œì‚Ü∑M‚Ü∑ŒìùëÄ\Gamma\curvearrowright M and Œõ‚Ü∑N‚Ü∑ŒõùëÅ\Lambda\curvearrowright N consists of the following data:

  • ‚Ä¢

    an action Œì‚Ä≤‚Ü∑M‚Ä≤‚Ü∑superscriptŒì‚Ä≤superscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime}\curvearrowright M^{\prime} commensurable to Œì‚Ü∑M‚Ü∑ŒìùëÄ\Gamma\curvearrowright M and an action Œõ‚Ä≤‚Ü∑N‚Ä≤‚Ü∑superscriptŒõ‚Ä≤superscriptùëÅ‚Ä≤\Lambda^{\prime}\curvearrowright N^{\prime} commensurable to Œõ‚Ü∑N‚Ü∑ŒõùëÅ\Lambda\curvearrowright N,

  • ‚Ä¢

    a bi-Lipschitz map f:M‚Ä≤‚ÜíN‚Ä≤:ùëì‚ÜísuperscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤superscriptùëÅ‚Ä≤f:M^{\prime}\to N^{\prime},

  • ‚Ä¢

    an isomorphism œÜ:Œì‚Ä≤‚ÜíŒõ‚Ä≤:ùúë‚ÜísuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤superscriptŒõ‚Ä≤\varphi:\Gamma^{\prime}\to\Lambda^{\prime},

such that fùëìf is œÜùúë\varphi-equivariant. If M‚Ä≤superscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤M^{\prime} and N‚Ä≤superscriptùëÅ‚Ä≤N^{\prime} are homogeneous spaces and fùëìf is affine, then we call this data an affine commensuration.

Here a map between homogeneous spaces is affine if it is compatible with the homogeneous structures, i.e. if it is the composition of a translation and a group automorphism (see Definition 8.1).

We state our main result first for geometric warped cones. Under an additional technical condition, we will obtain a similar result for non-geometric warped cones below.

Theorem 1.4.

Let ŒìŒì\Gamma and ŒõŒõ\Lambda be finitely presented groups acting isometrically, freely and minimally on compact manifolds MùëÄM and NùëÅN (respectively). Assume that neither of ŒìŒì\Gamma and ŒõŒõ\Lambda is commensurable to a group with a nontrivial free abelian factor. Suppose that ùí¢‚Äã(Œì‚Ü∑M)ùí¢‚Ü∑ŒìM\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)} is quasi-isometric to ùí¢‚Äã(Œõ‚Ü∑N)ùí¢‚Ü∑ŒõN\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Lambda\curvearrowright N)}. Then there is an affine commensuration of the two actions.

For a minimal isometric ŒìŒì\Gamma‚Äìaction on MùëÄM, the closure Gùê∫G of ŒìŒì\Gamma in Isom‚Å°(M)IsomùëÄ\operatorname{Isom}(M) acts transitively on the compact manifold MùëÄM and minimality is preserved by commensurability. So our hypotheses imply that MùëÄM and NùëÅN, as well as M‚Ä≤superscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤M^{\prime} and N‚Ä≤superscriptùëÅ‚Ä≤N^{\prime}, are homogeneous and so the claim that the commensuration is affine is sensible.

We can also prove a result forcing an affine commensuration of actions even given only sequences (tn)subscriptùë°ùëõ(t_{n}) and (sn)subscriptùë†ùëõ(s_{n}) and quasi-isometries between the tnsubscriptùë°ùëõt_{n}‚Äìlevel set of ùíû‚Äã(Œì‚Ü∑M)ùíû‚Ü∑ŒìM\operatorname{\mathscr{C}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)} and the snsubscriptùë†ùëõs_{n}‚Äìlevel set ùíû‚Äã(Œõ‚Ü∑N)ùíû‚Ü∑ŒõN\operatorname{\mathscr{C}(\Lambda\curvearrowright N)}, but this requires some additional technical assumptions on acting groups. The main advantage from our perspective of the geometric warped cone is that the maps on different level sets are in a natural sense coarsely homotopic. The more general context is interesting because it is the avenue to our results about expanders and superexpanders. For this more general result, we require an additional assumption on one of the acting groups, which we call Property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL} and define in Subsection 5.1 below. Groups with property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL} have only finitely many automorphisms satisfying any fixed constraint on distortion with respect to the stable length of group elements. Lattices in semisimple Lie groups have property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL}.

Theorem 1.5.

Let ŒìŒì\Gamma and ŒõŒõ\Lambda be finitely presented groups acting isometrically, freely and minimally on compact manifolds MùëÄM and NùëÅN (respectively). Assume that

  • ‚Ä¢

    Neither of ŒìŒì\Gamma and ŒõŒõ\Lambda is commensurable to a group with a nontrivial free abelian factor, and ŒìŒì\Gamma has Property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL}, and

  • ‚Ä¢

    There exist uniform quasi-isometries fn:Mtn‚ÜíNsn:subscriptùëìùëõ‚ÜísubscriptùëÄsubscriptùë°ùëõsubscriptùëÅsubscriptùë†ùëõf_{n}:M_{t_{n}}\to N_{s_{n}}, where tn,sn‚Üí‚àû‚Üísubscriptùë°ùëõsubscriptùë†ùëõt_{n},s_{n}\to\infty.

Then there is an affine commensuration of the action of ŒìŒì\Gamma on MùëÄM and the action of ŒõŒõ\Lambda on NùëÅN.

We next state, somewhat informally, a corollary of Theorem 1.5, our results for building many non-quasi-isometric expanders/group actions in Section 9, and the main results of Sawicki‚Äôs recent paper on the coarse Baum-Connes conjecture for warped cones over group actions with spectral gap [Saw3]. Sawicki‚Äôs proof is based on ghost projections constructed in an earlier paper of Drutu and Nowak [DN]. We note that we use Theorem 1.5, not Theorem 1.4, since Sawicki is forced to pass to discrete versions of the cone for his proofs.

Corollary 1.6.

There are continua of non-quasi-isometric spaces where the coarse Baum-Connes assembly map is not surjective.

In the next subsection we discuss applications of our results to producing families of expanders that are not quasi-isometric. In the few subsections following that one, we discuss the necessity of the hypotheses of these two theorems, some history of the work motivating our interest in this problem, and finally an outline of both our proofs and the paper.

1.3. Expanders

Expander graphs play an important role in fields ranging from computer science to geometric topology to operator algebras. An expander graph is a sequence of finite graphs of increasing size and bounded degree with strong spectral properties that, for example, force embeddings of the graphs into Hilbert spaces to be highly distorted (see Section 9.2 for precise definitions). Recently, attention has also been drawn to superexpanders where the spectral properties prevent good embeddings into broader classes of metric spaces. The first constructions of expanders were probabilistic, but so far there is no probabilistic construction of superexpanders. More recently, attention has focused on constructions of (super)expanders with a wide range of geometric behavior. This began in [MN1, Theorem 9.1] and [Ost, Theorem 5.76] and has led to a rush of recent results by Khukhro‚ÄìValette, Hume, Delabie‚ÄìKhukro, De Laat‚ÄìVigolo and Sawicki [KV, Hum, DK, dLV, Saw1]. Most of these papers study the problem from the point of view of its intrinsic interest, but there are also intriguing connections to the theory of computation in [MN2].

Explicit examples of expanders were first constructed by Margulis using congruence quotients of groups with property (T) [Mar1]. Using a strengthening of Property (T), Lafforgue showed that the same graphs are superexpanders [Laf]. Group actions on homogeneous spaces are a geometric source of expanders: Indeed, Margulis also constructed expanders from the action of SL‚Å°(n,‚Ñ§)SLùëõ‚Ñ§\operatorname{SL}(n,\mathbb{Z}) on ùïãnsuperscriptùïãùëõ\mathbb{T}^{n} for any n‚â•2ùëõ2n\geq 2 [Mar1]. Margulis‚Äô construction is mostly carried out in the dual setting of SL‚Å°(n,‚Ñ§)SLùëõ‚Ñ§\operatorname{SL}(n,\mathbb{Z}) actions on ‚Ñ§nsuperscript‚Ñ§ùëõ\mathbb{Z}^{n}, while the explicit translation to actions on homogeneous spaces was first made by Gabber and Galil [GG].

To see that group actions yield a robust source of expanders and superexpanders, we recall a discretiziation procedure that converts a group action into a sequence of graphs. Given a group action on a metric space (M,d)ùëÄùëë(M,d), we can consider rescalings MtsubscriptùëÄùë°M_{t} defined as (M,t‚Äãd)ùëÄùë°ùëë(M,td). For a sequence tn‚Üí‚àû‚Üísubscriptùë°ùëõt_{n}\to\infty, Vigolo discretizes the rescalings MtnsubscriptùëÄsubscriptùë°ùëõM_{t_{n}} to get a sequence of approximating graphs XnsubscriptùëãùëõX_{n}, and gives a criterion for {Xn}nsubscriptsubscriptùëãùëõùëõ\{X_{n}\}_{n} to be an expander sequence [Vig1]. The approximating graph is obtained by partitioning each MtsubscriptùëÄùë°M_{t} into sets of roughly equal diameter which correspond to vertices of the graph and then adding an edge between two elements in the partition if the translate of one by a generator intersects the other. Vigolo shows his discretizations are expanders if and only if the action of ŒìŒì\Gamma on MùëÄM has a spectral gap, a result extended to superexpanders by Sawicki [Saw1]. In fact, for the proofs of our theorem, we will need to pass from this sequence of graphs to one more closely tied to the geometry of MùëÄM as describe in [Vig1, Section 6].

When the underlying space is a manifold, we will refer to these as geometric expanders or geometric superexpanders.

There is a large literature producing actions with spectral gaps, so this construction provides a wealth of methods to produce expanders. Since we will focus on minimal isometric group actions, we will need a compact group KùêæK and a dense subgroup Œî<KŒîùêæ\Delta<K with a spectral gap on L2‚Äã(K)superscriptùêø2ùêæL^{2}(K). For particular choices of KùêæK, many of these are constructed as lattices in a Lie group Gùê∫G which have dense embeddings in a compact form KùêæK of Gùê∫G, namely by Margulis and Sullivan using groups with property (T)ùëá(T) and by Drin‚Äôfeld using more elaborate representation theory [Mar2, Sul, Dri]. In the late ‚Äô90s, examples were found by more elementary methods by Gamburd‚ÄìJakobson‚ÄìSarnak in [GJS] where the authors conjecture that a generic dense free subgroup of a compact simple group KùêæK will have a spectral gap. In recent work towards that conjecture, Bourgain‚ÄìGamburd and Benoist‚ÄìDe Saxce show that any dense free subgroup of KùêæK with algebraic entries has a spectral gap [BG2, BG1, BdS].

Our contribution to the geometry of expanders will be in providing many examples of expanders that are not quasi-isometric. While much of the work mentioned above is of this kind, so far applications to computer science require stronger results, namely that these expanders are, in an appropriate sense, an expander for random graphs [MN2]. It is possible that the geometric expanders considered here also satisfy this property, but a proof of this will require new ideas.

We say two sequences of graphs {Xn}subscriptùëãùëõ\{X_{n}\} and {Yn}subscriptùëåùëõ\{Y_{n}\} are (L,C)ùêøùê∂(L,C)‚Äìquasi-isometric if there are maps fn:Xn‚ÜíYn:subscriptùëìùëõ‚Üísubscriptùëãùëõsubscriptùëåùëõf_{n}:X_{n}\rightarrow Y_{n} that are (L,C)ùêøùê∂(L,C)‚Äìquasi-isometries. (See Definition 1.1.) Interested in the possible geometry of expanders, we define two sequence of graphs to be {Xn}subscriptùëãùëõ\{X_{n}\} and {Yn}subscriptùëåùëõ\{Y_{n}\} to (L,C)ùêøùê∂(L,C)-quasi-isometrically disjoint if there are no (L,C)ùêøùê∂(L,C)-quasi-isometric subsequences. (When discussing quasi-isometry of subsequences, we assume the obvious re-indexing.) When the sequences are (L,C)ùêøùê∂(L,C)-quasi-isometrically disjoint for all LùêøL and Cùê∂C, we call them simply quasi-isometrically disjoint. We call a collection Œ©Œ©\Omega of sequences of graphs quasi-isometrically disjoint if any pair of sequences in Œ©Œ©\Omega is quasi-isometrically disjoint. From our results on group actions, we can produce many explicit families of quasi-isometrically disjoint expanders:

Theorem 1.7.

Let KùêæK be a compact Lie group and fix r‚â•2ùëü2r\geq 2. Then free, rank rùëür subgroups of KùêæK with spectral gap yield quasi-isometrically disjoint expanders unless they are commensurable. In particular, there exist explicit quasi-isometrically disjoint continuous families of expanders.

To obtain families as in the theorem, we just note that from the existing literature we can produce many free groups with spectral gap: For example, set K=SU‚Å°(n)ùêæSUùëõK=\operatorname{SU}(n) with n‚â•2ùëõ2n\geq 2 and fix a free dense rank subgroup Œõ‚äÜSU‚Å°(n)ŒõSUùëõ\Lambda\subseteq\operatorname{SU}(n) of rank r‚àí1ùëü1r-1 and with spectral gap. Then consider the family {‚ü®Œõ,k‚ü©}k‚ààKsubscriptŒõùëòùëòùêæ\{\langle\Lambda,k\rangle\}_{k\in K}. For generic kùëòk, we have Œì:=‚ü®Œõ,k‚ü©‚âÖFrassignŒìŒõùëòsubscriptùêπùëü\Gamma:=\langle\Lambda,k\rangle\cong F_{r}, and the spectral gap for ŒõŒõ\Lambda implies that ŒìŒì\Gamma has spectral gap. For more details and other constructions, see Section 9.

We remark here that before the above result, the only known construction of uncountably many quasi-isometrically disjoint expanders is obtained by a fixing a single expander X:={Xn}nassignùëãsubscriptsubscriptùëãùëõùëõX:=\{X_{n}\}_{n} with some geometric invariant, such as diameter, growing very rapidly, and considering the set of all subsequences of XùëãX. To show this produces uncountably many quasi-isometrically disjoint expanders, one uses that there are uncountably many sequences of natural numbers that pairwise have finite intersection, a fact that was pointed out to us by D. Sawicki. As already pointed out by Vigolo, constructions from warped cones can lead to large families which cannot easily be distinguished by a condition on rapidly growing geometric invariants [Vig1]. For example, in Theorem 1.7 and Theorem 1.8 below we can always produce examples where either number of vertices or the diameter of the nùëõnth graph is nùëõn.

From the point of view of coarse geometry a key property of expanders is that they do not embed uniformly in any Hilbert space. By analogy, one defines superexpanders to be graphs that satisfy a certain Poincar√© inequality that obstructs uniform embedding in some class ùíûùíû\mathcal{C} of Banach spaces. Here we will always consider the class ùíûùíû\mathcal{C} of Banach spaces with nontrivial Rademacher type, which includes the class of uniformly convex Banach spaces. Superexpanders were first shown to exist by Lafforgue using strong property (T) in [Laf]. More examples were constructed by Mendel and Naor in [MN1] and by Liao in [Lia]. It is already clear from Lafforgue‚Äôs first paper that his results, combined with Margulis‚Äô construction in [Mar2], produce geometric expanders. While there are in some sense many fewer examples of group actions with the stronger spectral properties required to produce geometric superexpanders, we are still able to construct families of these. For the following theorem we let Gùê∫G be a higher rank pùëùp-adic Lie group, Œõ<GŒõùê∫\Lambda<G a cocompact lattice with a dense image homomorphism œÅ:Œõ‚ÜíK:ùúå‚ÜíŒõùêæ\rho:\Lambda\to K where KùêæK is a compact connected Lie group. Given a free group FksubscriptùêπùëòF_{k} with k>2ùëò2k>2, we let Œì=Œõ√óFkŒìŒõsubscriptùêπùëò\Gamma=\Lambda\times F_{k} which acts on KùêæK by letting œÅ‚Äã(Œõ)ùúåŒõ\rho(\Lambda) act on the left, picking any inclusion i:Fk‚ÜíK:ùëñ‚Üísubscriptùêπùëòùêæi:F_{k}\rightarrow K and letting i‚Äã(Fk)ùëñsubscriptùêπùëòi(F_{k}) act on the right.

Theorem 1.8.

Varying the inclusion iùëñi above, the actions of ŒìŒì\Gamma on KùêæK produce explicit quasi-isometrically disjoint families of superexpanders.

In the proof of this theorem the ŒõŒõ\Lambda‚Äìaction provides the spectral gap required to make the graphs superexpanders, while the free group provides us with the ability to vary the actions and geometry of the graphs. Both Theorem 1.7 and 1.8 are consequences of Theorem 1.5 and some results on character varieties used to guarantee that the actions are free and minimal.

1.4. History and motivations

Given a group ŒìŒì\Gamma and a sequence ŒìnsubscriptŒìùëõ\Gamma_{n} of finite index subgroups, the box space is the disjoint union of metric graphs Xn=Œì/ŒìnsubscriptùëãùëõŒìsubscriptŒìùëõX_{n}=\Gamma/\Gamma_{n}. The key observation that begins the paper of Khukhro‚ÄìValette is that the Gromov‚ÄìHausdorff limit of {Xn}nsubscriptsubscriptùëãùëõùëõ\{X_{n}\}_{n} is in fact ŒìŒì\Gamma, so that if there is a quasi-isometry between box spaces of ŒìŒì\Gamma and ŒõŒõ\Lambda, then ŒìŒì\Gamma and ŒõŒõ\Lambda are quasi-isometric and one has access to the broad literature on quasi-isometries of groups. The proof of De Laat‚ÄìVigolo follows a similar line but replaces box spaces by warped cones. They study warped cones over actions on manifolds and show that any sequence of level sets for ùíû‚Äã(Œì‚Ü∑M)ùíû‚Ü∑ŒìM\operatorname{\mathscr{C}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)} has Gromov‚ÄìHausdorff limit Œì√ó‚Ñùdim(M)Œìsuperscript‚ÑùdimensionùëÄ\Gamma\times\mathbb{R}^{\dim(M)}, a result also proven by Sawicki in [Saw2]. In both cases these results allow one to distinguish large classes of expanders by referring to the literature on quasi-isometric rigidity of groups.

More recently, Delabie‚ÄìKhukhro have shown that quasi-isometries of box spaces are in fact much more restricted than just quasi-isometries of the ambient group [DK]. Essentially Delabie‚ÄìKhukhro use that the quasi-isometry makes the box spaces coarsely homotopic and show that this forces the ambient groups to be commensurable and the sequences of subgroups to be isomorphic using the notion of a coarse fundamental group. These results are the natural analogue of ours in the setting of box spaces, but do not require any assumptions on the groups. The fact that there is some obstruction to a result like ours in terms of the acting group is already noticed explicitly by Sawicki, who proves a conditional result about quasi-isometries of warped cones induced by a single good map f:M‚ÜíN:ùëì‚ÜíùëÄùëÅf:M\rightarrow N [Saw2]. While we do not use this result of Sawicki‚Äôs here, from this perspective, a key technical difficulty in our work is producing any such map.

We are also motivated by the natural analogy between classifying finitely generated groups up to quasi-isometry and classifying the warped cones of group actions up to quasi-isometry. The new classification questions that arise seems to connect to numerous other fields of mathematics including computer science, dynamics, geometric group theory and operator algebras. We remark here that much as it is for finitely generated groups, quasi-isometry is the right notion of equivalence in the category of warped cones. First, changing the generating set of the acting group changes the warped cone metric but the metrics remain quasi-isometric. Second, choosing a different but bi-Lipschitz metric on MùëÄM also changes the warped cone metric, but again only up to quasi-isometry. This second observation implies that all Riemannian metrics on a fixed manifold will give rise to quasi-isometric warped cones. In the context of actions on totally disconnected spaces, Sawicki shows that non-bi-Lipschitz metrics can give rise to non-quasi-isometric warped cones for the same group action. One can probably also produce examples of this in the setting of actions on manifolds simply by taking a Riemannian metric and snowflaking it.

1.5. Hypothesis on group actions

In both Theorems 1.4 and 1.5, the assumption on absence of abelian factors of ŒìŒì\Gamma and ŒõŒõ\Lambda is necessary: In [Kim], Kim shows that circle rotations that are related by integral fractional linear transformations give rise to quasi-isometric geometric warped cones. Since rotation number is a conjugacy invariant of rotations, this provides many non-conjugate ‚Ñ§‚Ñ§\mathbb{Z}‚Äìactions on S1superscriptùëÜ1S^{1} that have quasi-isometric geometric warped cones and the rotation numbers can be sufficiently different that the problem is not resolved by commensuration of the actions. In an appendix to a recent paper by Sawicki, Kielak‚ÄìSawicki give an even more remarkable construction showing that there are rotations on S1superscriptùëÜ1S^{1} whose warped cone is quasi-isometric to the warped cone of the trivial action on ùïã2superscriptùïã2\mathbb{T}^{2} [Saw2] and also produce a variety of other examples of this flavor, including ones between minimal isometric actions. The key insight there is to see that one can shift geometry of the acting group to geometry of the ambient space, provided one takes sequences of level sets that grow at different rates and the geometry of the space and group factors are sufficiently similar. These more exotic examples do not give rise to quasi-isometries of geometric warped cones.

We do not currently know if Property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL} is necessary in Theorem 1.5 or if all finitely generated subgroups of compact Lie groups have Property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL}. We have also not explored the degree to which variants of the theorems might be true for actions that are not isometric, which is an intriguing direction for future research.

1.6. Basic intuition and outline of the proofs and the paper

The basic intuition behind our theorem is roughly that if the quasi-isometries between the cones respected a distinction between directions related to paths in the manifold and directions related to paths in the group, then the quasi-isometry would appear to need to recognize the orbit structure of the action. This is because points x,yùë•ùë¶x,y in MùëÄM are in the same ŒìŒì\Gamma‚Äìorbit if and only if the distance between xùë•x and yùë¶y in level sets of ùíû‚Äã(Œì‚Ü∑M)ùíû‚Ü∑ŒìM\operatorname{\mathscr{C}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)} remains bounded. In addition if the quasi-isometry respects the distinction between directions related to paths in the manifold and directions related to paths in the group, one should be able to rescale the quasi-isometries along the manifold direction to have them converge to a bi-Lipschitz map. Together these two intuitions would produce an orbit equivalence between actions, which can be seen to be a conjugacy by results of the first author and Whyte [FW]. The actual proof does not follow exactly this line and as mentioned above, the examples of Kim and Kielak‚ÄìSawicki show that the basic intuition is wrong for at least some examples. Their intriguing examples show that one cannot, in general, hope that quasi-isometries of warped cones respect the distinction between directions related to paths in the manifold and paths in the group. Our theorems and proofs do give strong evidence that in the case of minimal isometric actions, their examples capture more or less all the ways in which this mixing of space and orbit can occur for quasi-isometries of warped cones.

Before beginning our proof, Section 2 recalls definitions of warped cones and coarse fundamental groups. The first step of our proof is to show that the coarse fundamental group of a warped cone ùíû‚Äã(Œì‚Ü∑M)ùíû‚Ü∑ŒìM\operatorname{\mathscr{C}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)} is the group Œì~~Œì\widetilde{\Gamma} of lifts of the ŒìŒì\Gamma‚Äìaction to the universal cover M~~ùëÄ\widetilde{M} of MùëÄM. A similar computation was obtained independently and simultaneously by Vigolo [Vig2] (see Remark 3.2 for further discussion). As quasi-isometries necessarily induce isomorphisms of coarse fundamental groups, we get an isomorphism between Œì~~Œì\widetilde{\Gamma} and Œõ~~Œõ\widetilde{\Lambda} induced by the quasi-isometry of warped cones. In Section 4, we use this to define an obstruction map that captures when a quasi-isometry of warped cones mixes group directions with manifold directions. The obstruction map is a composition

œÄ1‚Äã(M)‚ÜíŒì~‚Äã‚ü∂‚âÖ‚ÄãŒõ~‚ÜíŒõ‚Üísubscriptùúã1ùëÄ~Œì‚ü∂~Œõ‚ÜíŒõ\pi_{1}(M)\rightarrow\widetilde{\Gamma}\overset{\cong}{\longrightarrow}\widetilde{\Lambda}\rightarrow\Lambda

where the first and last arrow come from the structure of groups of lifts and the isomorphism in the middle arises from our quasi-isometry. We show that after passing to commensurable actions, our hypothesis that ŒìŒì\Gamma and ŒõŒõ\Lambda have no abelian direct factors forces the obstruction map to vanish. At this point we have isomorphisms œÄ1‚Äã(M)‚âÖœÄ1‚Äã(N)subscriptùúã1ùëÄsubscriptùúã1ùëÅ\pi_{1}(M)\cong\pi_{1}(N) and œÜ^:Œì‚ÜíŒõ:^ùúë‚ÜíŒìŒõ\widehat{\varphi}:\Gamma\rightarrow\Lambda. The existence of œÜ^^ùúë\widehat{\varphi} is already a major development, since we now have an identification of acting groups and so it is sensible to ask if the actions are conjugate.

The outline is actually a bit more complicated at this step. If we have a quasi-isometry of geometric warped cones, it is not hard to see purely from coarse topology that œÜ^^ùúë\widehat{\varphi} actually exists and is independent of tùë°t (see Section 5.6). In the context of Theorem 1.5, we actually have a sequence œÜ^nsubscript^ùúëùëõ\widehat{\varphi}_{n} of isomorphisms and a key step is to argue that this sequence of quasi-isometries stabilize along a subsequence. We actually need only that they stabilize up to conjugation, i.e. that œÜ^nsubscript^ùúëùëõ\widehat{\varphi}_{n} stabilize in Out‚Å°(Œì)OutŒì\operatorname{Out}(\Gamma) rather than in Aut‚Å°(Œì)AutŒì\operatorname{Aut}(\Gamma). This is trivial if say Out‚Å°(Œì)OutŒì\operatorname{Out}(\Gamma) is finite, but in general requires an argument. In Section 5, we show that the group automorphisms that arise in our context are Lipschitz for the stable length, and we introduce Property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL} which essentially says that given a constant Dùê∑D there are only finitely many elements of Out‚Å°(Œì)OutŒì\operatorname{Out}(\Gamma) represented by automorphisms that are Dùê∑D‚ÄìLipschitz for stable length.

The next step after this is also a matter that only arises in the setting of Theorem 1.5. The reader only interested in Theorem 1.4 can skip all but the first and last subsections of Section 5 and all of Section 6. In Section 6, we show that vanishing of the obstruction map in the context of Theorem 1.5 forces tnsubscriptùë°ùëõt_{n} and snsubscriptùë†ùëõs_{n} to be linearly related. Once one knows this, it is easy to see that one can assume tn=snsubscriptùë°ùëõsubscriptùë†ùëõt_{n}=s_{n}. We note here that it is easy to compute the obstruction map for the examples of Kim and Kielak‚ÄìSawicki and see that it does not vanish.

The main step of our proof, completed in Section 7, is to show that one can now in fact construct a semiconjugacy between the actions. To do so, we modify the map of levels sets given by the quasi-isometry by a monodromy correction, which measures the extent to which the quasi-isometry mixes manifold and orbit directions. We show these modified maps are coarsely Lipschitz maps between the manifolds. The estimate on the constants is such that the resulting maps converge to a Lipschitz map as t‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùë°t\rightarrow\infty. The stabilization up to conjugacy of the isomorphisms œÜnsubscriptùúëùëõ\varphi_{n}, allows us to further adjust the quasi-isometries of level sets before passing to the limit, so that in the limit we produce a Lipschitz semiconjugacy.

The final issue is to show that the semi-conjugacy we construct is actually an affine conjugacy, which is proved using a variant of a standard argument from homogeneous dynamics in Section 8.

Lastly in Section 9, we prove Theorems 1.7 and 1.8 from Theorem 1.5. The key idea is to produce continua of group actions that are not affinely conjugate but that have the necessary spectral gaps. To produce expanders, it suffices to consider actions of free group FksubscriptùêπùëòF_{k} where we fix the action on Fk‚àí1subscriptùêπùëò1F_{k-1} to be one with a spectral gap and vary the last generator as described after Theorem 1.7. To produce superexpanders, where we need a spectral gap with more general Banach coefficients, we consider products Œî√óFnŒîsubscriptùêπùëõ\Delta\times F_{n} acting on a compact Lie group KùêæK where ŒîŒî\Delta acts by left-translations and FnsubscriptùêπùëõF_{n} acts by right-translations. We guarantee spectral gap for this action by choosing the ŒîŒî\Delta‚Äìaction so that it already has spectral gap, and this will be inherited by the product. We remark that to think of this as an affine action requires thinking of KùêæK as (K√óK)/diag‚Å°(K)ùêæùêædiagùêæ(K\times K)/\operatorname{diag}(K) where diag‚Å°(K)diagùêæ\operatorname{diag}(K) is the image of the diagonal embedding of KùêæK. The existence of continua of non-conjugate free minimal actions follows from results on character varieties proved using Borel‚Äôs theorem that word maps are dominant, see Subsection 9.3.

Acknowledgments

The authors thank Michael Larsen and Nick Miller for useful conversations on representation varieties and word maps. DF thanks Piotr Nowak for introducing him to this circle of ideas and thanks Assaf Naor and Mikeal de la Salle for interesting conversations about superexpanders and strong property (T)ùëá(T). WvL is grateful to Federico Vigolo for explaining the connection between expanders and warped cones over group actions at the Newton Institute in May 2017, which aroused his interest in this topic. We thank Emmanuel Breuillard for his explanation of the proof of Lemma 9.6. We also thank Vigolo and Damian Sawicki for helpful comments on a preliminary version of this paper. DF was partially supported by NSF Grants DMS‚Äì1308291 and DMS‚Äì1607041. WvL and TN thank the Indiana University Math Department for support during a visit there and TN thanks the Michigan Math Department and NSF Grant DMS‚Äì1607260 for support during a visit there.

2. Preliminary remarks

2.1. Generalities for warped cones

Let a finitely generated group ŒìŒì\Gamma act isometrically on a closed Riemannian manifold (M,g)ùëÄùëî(M,g). Let SùëÜS be a symmetric generating set for ŒìŒì\Gamma, so that ŒìŒì\Gamma is equipped with a word metric. The geometric cone of Œì‚Ü∑M‚Ü∑ŒìùëÄ\Gamma\curvearrowright M is the metric space

ùí¢‚Äã(Œì‚Ü∑M):=(M√ó(0,‚àû)√óŒì)/Œì,assignùí¢‚Ü∑ŒìMùëÄ0ŒìŒì\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)}:=(M\times(0,\infty)\times\Gamma)/\Gamma,

where M√ó(0,‚àû)ùëÄ0M\times(0,\infty) is equipped with the warped product metric t‚Äãg+d‚Äãt2ùë°ùëîùëësuperscriptùë°2tg+dt^{2}. We let t‚ÄãMùë°ùëÄtM denote the manifold MùëÄM with the metric t‚Äãgùë°ùëîtg, and write Mt:=(t‚ÄãM√óŒì)/ŒìassignsubscriptùëÄùë°ùë°ùëÄŒìŒìM_{t}:=(tM\times\Gamma)/\Gamma for the level set of the geometric cone at time tùë°t. We write dtŒìsuperscriptsubscriptùëëùë°Œìd_{t}^{\Gamma} for the metric on MtsubscriptùëÄùë°M_{t}. It is immediate that MtsubscriptùëÄùë°M_{t} can also be described as the metric space with underlying set MùëÄM and dtŒìsuperscriptsubscriptùëëùë°Œìd_{t}^{\Gamma} defined as follows:

Lemma 2.1.

Let x,y‚ààMùë•ùë¶ùëÄx,y\in M. Then

dtŒì‚Äã(x,y)=infŒ≥‚ààŒì(t‚ÄãdM‚Äã(x,Œ≥‚Äãy)+‚ÄñŒ≥‚Äñ).superscriptsubscriptùëëùë°Œìùë•ùë¶subscriptinfimumùõæŒìùë°subscriptùëëùëÄùë•ùõæùë¶normùõæd_{t}^{\Gamma}(x,y)=\inf_{\gamma\in\Gamma}(t\,d_{M}(x,\gamma y)+\|\gamma\|).
Remark 2.2.

For clarity, we mention that our definition of the metric on the (geometric) warped cone differs from Roe‚Äôs. For isometric actions, it is well known that Roe‚Äôs definition is equivalent to the one given by the formula in the lemma above and so to ours.

From the above expression, it is clear the large-scale geometry of these level sets is invariant under taking finite quotients or extensions of the action:

Lemma 2.3.

Let F‚äÜŒìùêπŒìF\subseteq\Gamma be a finite normal subgroup, and write Œì‚Ä≤:=Œì/FassignsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤Œìùêπ\Gamma^{\prime}:=\Gamma/F and M‚Ä≤:=M/FassignsuperscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤ùëÄùêπM^{\prime}:=M/F. Write MtsubscriptùëÄùë°M_{t} (resp. Mt‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùëÄùë°‚Ä≤M_{t}^{\prime}) for the level set at time tùë°t of the cone over Œì‚Ü∑M‚Ü∑ŒìùëÄ\Gamma\curvearrowright M (resp. Œì‚Ä≤‚Ü∑M‚Ä≤‚Ü∑superscriptŒì‚Ä≤superscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime}\curvearrowright M^{\prime}). Then MtsubscriptùëÄùë°M_{t} is (1,B)1ùêµ(1,B)‚Äìquasi-isometric to Mt‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùëÄùë°‚Ä≤M_{t}^{\prime}, where BùêµB is the maximal word length in ŒìŒì\Gamma of an element of FùêπF.

Proof.

Write œÄ:Mt‚ÜíMt‚Ä≤:ùúã‚ÜísubscriptùëÄùë°superscriptsubscriptùëÄùë°‚Ä≤\pi:M_{t}\to M_{t}^{\prime} for the natural quotient map. It is easy to see that œÄùúã\pi is distance non-increasing, i.e. 111‚ÄìLipschitz. For the lower bound, let Cùê∂C be the maximal word length of an element of the finite group FùêπF. Further for any Œ≥‚ààŒìùõæŒì\gamma\in\Gamma, let Œ≥‚Ä≤superscriptùõæ‚Ä≤\gamma^{\prime} denote its image in Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime}. Then we have ‚ÄñŒ≥‚Äñ‚â§‚ÄñŒ≥‚Ä≤‚Äñ+Cnormùõænormsuperscriptùõæ‚Ä≤ùê∂\|\gamma\|\leq\|\gamma^{\prime}\|+C, which easily implies the other bound.‚àé

We also define the full warped cone ùíû‚Äã(Œì‚Ü∑M):=‚äîtMtassignùíû‚Ü∑ŒìMsubscriptsquare-unionùë°subscriptùëÄùë°\operatorname{\mathscr{C}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)}:=\sqcup_{t}\,M_{t} and more generally, for any sequence tn‚Üí‚àû‚Üísubscriptùë°ùëõt_{n}\to\infty, the associated warped cone ùíû(tn)‚Äã(Œì‚Ü∑M):=‚äînMtnassignsubscriptùíûsubscriptùë°ùëõ‚Ü∑ŒìùëÄsubscriptsquare-unionùëõsubscriptùëÄsubscriptùë°ùëõ\mathscr{C}_{(t_{n})}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M):=\sqcup_{n}\,M_{t_{n}}. For most of the paper, and for applications to expander graphs, we need to consider quasi-isometries of warped cones associated to a sequence (tn)subscriptùë°ùëõ(t_{n}), i.e. a sequence of uniform quasi-isometries fn:Mtn‚ÜíNsn:subscriptùëìùëõ‚ÜísubscriptùëÄsubscriptùë°ùëõsubscriptùëÅsubscriptùë†ùëõf_{n}:M_{t_{n}}\to N_{s_{n}}. Note that in general it need not be true that tn‚âçsnasymptotically-equalssubscriptùë°ùëõsubscriptùë†ùëõt_{n}\asymp s_{n} ‚Äì indeed, we already alluded to an example of Kielak‚ÄìSawicki that produces a quasi-isometry between the warped cone over a suitable rotation on S1superscriptùëÜ1S^{1} for a quadratically growing sequence, and the warped cone over the trivial action on T2superscriptùëá2T^{2} for a linear sequence. However, see Section 6, where we show that tn‚âçsnasymptotically-equalssubscriptùë°ùëõsubscriptùë†ùëõt_{n}\asymp s_{n} under suitable hypotheses.

A map f:X‚ÜíY:ùëì‚Üíùëãùëåf:X\to Y of metric spaces is called (L,C)ùêøùê∂(L,C)‚Äìcoarsely Lipschitz if for any x1,x2‚ààXsubscriptùë•1subscriptùë•2ùëãx_{1},x_{2}\in X, we have

dY‚Äã(f‚Äã(x1),f‚Äã(x2))‚â§L‚ÄãdX‚Äã(x1,x2)+C.subscriptùëëùëåùëìsubscriptùë•1ùëìsubscriptùë•2ùêøsubscriptùëëùëãsubscriptùë•1subscriptùë•2ùê∂d_{Y}(f(x_{1}),f(x_{2}))\leq Ld_{X}(x_{1},x_{2})+C.

In general, a quasi-isometry of geometric cones yields uniformly coarsely Lipschitz maps of levels.

Lemma 2.4.

Let f:ùí¢‚Äã(Œì‚Ü∑M)‚Üíùí¢‚Äã(Œõ‚Ü∑N):ùëì‚Üíùí¢‚Ü∑ŒìMùí¢‚Ü∑ŒõNf:\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)}\to\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Lambda\curvearrowright N)} be a quasi-isometry. For any t>0ùë°0t>0, define ft:Mt‚ÜíNt:subscriptùëìùë°‚ÜísubscriptùëÄùë°subscriptùëÅùë°f_{t}:M_{t}\to N_{t} as the composition

ft:Mt‚Ü™ùí¢‚Äã(Œì‚Ü∑M)‚Å°‚ü∂ùëì‚Äãùí¢‚Äã(Œõ‚Ü∑N)‚Ü†Nt:subscriptùëìùë°‚Ü™subscriptùëÄùë°ùí¢‚Ü∑ŒìMùëì‚ü∂ùí¢‚Ü∑ŒõN‚Ü†subscriptùëÅùë°f_{t}:M_{t}\hookrightarrow\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)}\overset{f}{\longrightarrow}\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Lambda\curvearrowright N)}\twoheadrightarrow N_{t}

where the first map is the inclusion of a level set and the last map is the projection to a level set. Then there exists t0>0subscriptùë°00t_{0}>0 such that for t>t0ùë°subscriptùë°0t>t_{0}, the maps ftsubscriptùëìùë°f_{t} are uniformly coarsely Lipschitz.

Proof.

It is clear the inclusion of a level set is 111-Lipschitz and fùëìf is (L,C)ùêøùê∂(L,C)-coarsely Lipschitz. Therefore to show the composition is uniformly coarsely Lipschitz, we need to bound the distortion coming from the projection to a level set. More precisely, let p2:ùí¢‚Äã(Œì‚Ü∑M)‚Üí(0,+‚àû):subscriptùëù2‚Üíùí¢‚Ü∑ŒìM0p_{2}:\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)}\to(0,+\infty) denote the projection of the warped cone on the second factor, and likewise define q2:ùí¢‚Äã(Œõ‚Ü∑N)‚Üí(0,‚àû):subscriptùëû2‚Üíùí¢‚Ü∑ŒõN0q_{2}:\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Lambda\curvearrowright N)}\to(0,\infty). We claim that fùëìf coarsely preserves the second factor, namely that there exists K‚â•1ùêæ1K\geq 1 and B>0ùêµ0B>0 such that for all x‚ààùí¢‚Äã(Œì‚Ü∑M)ùë•ùí¢‚Ü∑ŒìMx\in\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)}, we have

K‚àí1‚Äãp2‚Äã(x)‚àíB‚â§q2‚Äã(f‚Äã(x))‚â§K‚Äãp2‚Äã(x)+B.superscriptùêæ1subscriptùëù2ùë•ùêµsubscriptùëû2ùëìùë•ùêæsubscriptùëù2ùë•ùêµK^{-1}p_{2}(x)-B\leq q_{2}(f(x))\leq Kp_{2}(x)+B. (2.1)

Indeed, consider a basepoint x0‚ààùí¢‚Äã(Œì‚Ü∑M)subscriptùë•0ùí¢‚Ü∑ŒìMx_{0}\in\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)} with p2‚Äã(x0)=1subscriptùëù2subscriptùë•01p_{2}(x_{0})=1. It is easy to obtain the estimates of Equation (2.1) from the observation that p2subscriptùëù2p_{2} and q2subscriptùëû2q_{2} are distance non-increasing, and further

d‚Äã(x,x0)‚â§|p2‚Äã(x)‚àíp2‚Äã(x0)|+diam‚Å°(M),ùëëùë•subscriptùë•0subscriptùëù2ùë•subscriptùëù2subscriptùë•0diamùëÄd(x,x_{0})\leq|p_{2}(x)-p_{2}(x_{0})|+\operatorname{diam}(M),

and likewise for d‚Äã(f‚Äã(x),f‚Äã(x0))ùëëùëìùë•ùëìsubscriptùë•0d(f(x),f(x_{0})).

From Equation (2.1), it is easy to see that the projection of f‚Äã(Mt)ùëìsubscriptùëÄùë°f(M_{t}) to the level set NtsubscriptùëÅùë°N_{t} increases distances by a factor of at most (K‚àí1‚Äãt‚àíB)‚àí1‚Äãtsuperscriptsuperscriptùêæ1ùë°ùêµ1ùë°(K^{-1}t-B)^{-1}t, which is bounded above by (2‚ÄãK)‚àí1superscript2ùêæ1(2K)^{-1} for t‚â´1much-greater-thanùë°1t\gg 1. ‚àé

2.2. Coarse homotopy and fundamental group

We briefly recall the definition of and basic facts about coarse fundamental groups. For more information, see e.g. [BCW, DK].

Definition 2.5.

Let XùëãX be a metric space and r>0ùëü0r>0. An rùëür-path is a sequence of points Œ±=(p0,‚Ä¶,p‚Ñì)ùõºsubscriptùëù0‚Ä¶subscriptùëù‚Ñì\alpha=(p_{0},\dots,p_{\ell}) where d‚Äã(pi,pi+1)<rùëësubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëñ1ùëüd(p_{i},p_{i+1})<r. An rùëür-loop is an rùëür-path with p0=p‚Ñìsubscriptùëù0subscriptùëù‚Ñìp_{0}=p_{\ell}. The endpoint append of an rùëür-path Œ±ùõº\alpha is the rùëür-path

append‚Å°(Œ±)=(p0,‚Ä¶,p‚Ñì,p‚Ñì).appendùõºsubscriptùëù0‚Ä¶subscriptùëù‚Ñìsubscriptùëù‚Ñì\operatorname{append}(\alpha)=(p_{0},\dots,p_{\ell},p_{\ell}).

If Œ≤=append‚Å°(Œ±)ùõΩappendùõº\beta=\operatorname{append}(\alpha), we say Œ±ùõº\alpha is the endpoint deletion of Œ≤ùõΩ\beta. Two rùëür-paths Œ±=(p0,‚Ä¶,p‚Ñì)ùõºsubscriptùëù0‚Ä¶subscriptùëù‚Ñì\alpha=(p_{0},\dots,p_{\ell}) and Œ≤=(q0,‚Ä¶,qn)ùõΩsubscriptùëû0‚Ä¶subscriptùëûùëõ\beta=(q_{0},\dots,q_{n}) are rùëür-close if either

  1. (a)

    Œ≤ùõΩ\beta is the endpoint append or deletion of Œ±ùõº\alpha, or

  2. (b)

    Œ±ùõº\alpha and Œ≤ùõΩ\beta have the same length (i.e. ‚Ñì=n‚Ñìùëõ\ell=n) and d‚Äã(pi,qi)<rùëësubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëûùëñùëüd(p_{i},q_{i})<r for all iùëñi.

An rùëür-homotopy based at p0subscriptùëù0p_{0} between two rùëür-loops Œ±ùõº\alpha and Œ≤ùõΩ\beta based at p0subscriptùëù0p_{0} is a sequence of rùëür-loops based at p0subscriptùëù0p_{0}

Œ±=c0,c1,‚Ä¶,ck‚àí1,ck=Œ≤formulae-sequenceùõºsubscriptùëê0subscriptùëê1‚Ä¶subscriptùëêùëò1subscriptùëêùëòùõΩ\alpha=c_{0},c_{1},\dots,c_{k-1},c_{k}=\beta

where ci,ci+1subscriptùëêùëñsubscriptùëêùëñ1c_{i},c_{i+1} are rùëür-close for all iùëñi.

We define the coarse fundamental group:

Definition 2.6.

Let XùëãX be a metric space and r>0ùëü0r>0 and p0‚ààXsubscriptùëù0ùëãp_{0}\in X. The coarse fundamental group of XùëãX based at x0subscriptùë•0x_{0} and of scale rùëür is the group œÄ1‚Äã(X,x0;r)subscriptùúã1ùëãsubscriptùë•0ùëü\pi_{1}(X,x_{0};r) whose elements are rùëür-homotopy classes of rùëür-loops based at x0subscriptùë•0x_{0}, with multiplication given by concatenation.

Let us first discuss dependence on the basepoint x0subscriptùë•0x_{0}. The situation is completely parallel to the one for (continuous) fundamental groups. Namely, we say a metric space is connected on the scale rùëür if there is an rùëür-path between any two of its points. If a space is connected on the scale rùëür, then the isomorphism type of œÄ1‚Äã(X,x0;r)subscriptùúã1ùëãsubscriptùë•0ùëü\pi_{1}(X,x_{0};r) is independent of x0subscriptùë•0x_{0}. In this case we refer to this group as œÄ1‚Äã(X;r)subscriptùúã1ùëãùëü\pi_{1}(X;r). Any two possible identifications differ by an inner automorphism.

Let us now discuss basic functoriality properties of coarse fundamental group of a metric space XùëãX. First, we can compare the coarse fundamental group at different scales r1<r2subscriptùëü1subscriptùëü2r_{1}<r_{2}. Namely, since any r1subscriptùëü1r_{1}-path is an r2subscriptùëü2r_{2}-path, we have an obvious change of scale‚Äìmap

œÄ1‚Äã(X,x0;r1)‚ÜíœÄ1‚Äã(X,x0;r2).‚Üísubscriptùúã1ùëãsubscriptùë•0subscriptùëü1subscriptùúã1ùëãsubscriptùë•0subscriptùëü2\pi_{1}(X,x_{0};r_{1})\to\pi_{1}(X,x_{0};r_{2}).

If cùëêc is a (continuous) path in XùëãX, we say an rùëür-path Œ±=(p0,‚Ä¶,p‚Ñì)ùõºsubscriptùëù0‚Ä¶subscriptùëù‚Ñì\alpha=(p_{0},\dots,p_{\ell}) is a discretization of cùëêc on the scale rùëür if there is a partition

0=t0<t1<‚ãØ<t‚Ñì=10subscriptùë°0subscriptùë°1‚ãØsubscriptùë°‚Ñì10=t_{0}<t_{1}<\dots<t_{\ell}=1

of [0,1]01[0,1] such that pi=c‚Äã(ti)subscriptùëùùëñùëêsubscriptùë°ùëñp_{i}=c(t_{i}) and c‚Äã([ti,ti+1])‚äÜBX‚Äã(pi;r)ùëêsubscriptùë°ùëñsubscriptùë°ùëñ1subscriptùêµùëãsubscriptùëùùëñùëüc([t_{i},t_{i+1}])\subseteq B_{X}(p_{i};r) for every iùëñi. The rùëür-homotopy class of a discretization is invariant under refinement under the partition and hence does not depend on the partition chosen. It is not hard to check that (continuous) homotopies of loops based at x0subscriptùë•0x_{0} give rùëür‚Äìhomotopic discretizations. Therefore we have a well-defined discretization map

œÄ1‚Äã(X)‚ÜíœÄ1‚Äã(X;r).‚Üísubscriptùúã1ùëãsubscriptùúã1ùëãùëü\pi_{1}(X)\to\pi_{1}(X;r).

An (L,C)ùêøùê∂(L,C)‚Äìcoarsely Lipschitz map defines an obvious morphism on coarse fundamental groups

f‚àó:œÄ1‚Äã(X,x0;r)‚ÜíœÄ1‚Äã(Y,f‚Äã(x0);L‚Äãr+C).:subscriptùëì‚àó‚Üísubscriptùúã1ùëãsubscriptùë•0ùëüsubscriptùúã1ùëåùëìsubscriptùë•0ùêøùëüùê∂f_{\ast}:\pi_{1}(X,x_{0};r)\to\pi_{1}(Y,f(x_{0});Lr+C).

These behave well with respect to composition, namely if f:X‚ÜíY:ùëì‚Üíùëãùëåf:X\to Y is (Lf,Cf)subscriptùêøùëìsubscriptùê∂ùëì(L_{f},C_{f})‚Äìcoarsely Lipschitz and g:Y‚ÜíZ:ùëî‚Üíùëåùëçg:Y\to Z is (Lg,Cg)subscriptùêøùëîsubscriptùê∂ùëî(L_{g},C_{g})‚Äìcoarsely Lipschitz, then g‚àòfùëîùëìg\circ f is (Lg‚ÄãLf,Lg‚ÄãCf+Cg)subscriptùêøùëîsubscriptùêøùëìsubscriptùêøùëîsubscriptùê∂ùëìsubscriptùê∂ùëî(L_{g}L_{f},L_{g}C_{f}+C_{g})‚Äìcoarsely Lipschitz and (g‚àòf)‚àó=g‚àó‚àòf‚àósubscriptùëîùëì‚àósubscriptùëî‚àósubscriptùëì‚àó(g\circ f)_{\ast}=g_{\ast}\circ f_{\ast}.

2.3. Technical coarse homotopy lemma

Aside from endpoint appends and deletions, we can perform any coarse homotopy by making only two changes at the time, and these are in consecutive positions:

Lemma 2.7.

Suppose Œ±,Œ≤ùõºùõΩ\alpha,\beta are rùëür-close rùëür-loops based at p0subscriptùëù0p_{0} of the same length. Then there is an rùëür-homotopy (possibly through curves of longer length) from Œ±ùõº\alpha to Œ≤ùõΩ\beta such that consecutive paths differ in at most two points, and these are consecutive (we allow endpoint appends and deletions).

Proof.

Write Œ±=(p0,‚Ä¶,p‚Ñì+1)ùõºsubscriptùëù0‚Ä¶subscriptùëù‚Ñì1\alpha=(p_{0},\dots,p_{\ell+1}) where p0=p‚Ñì+1subscriptùëù0subscriptùëù‚Ñì1p_{0}=p_{\ell+1} and likewise write Œ≤=(p0,q1,‚Ä¶,q‚Ñì,p0)ùõΩsubscriptùëù0subscriptùëû1‚Ä¶subscriptùëû‚Ñìsubscriptùëù0\beta=(p_{0},q_{1},\dots,q_{\ell},p_{0}). Since Œ±ùõº\alpha and Œ≤ùõΩ\beta are rùëür-close, we know d‚Äã(pi,qi)<rùëësubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëûùëñùëüd(p_{i},q_{i})<r for all 1‚â§i‚â§l1ùëñùëô1\leq i\leq l.

It is easy to see that there is an rùëür-homotopy as desired (i.e. making only local changes) between Œ±ùõº\alpha and the loop that prepends the point p0subscriptùëù0p_{0} to Œ±ùõº\alpha, i.e. the loop

prepend‚Äã(Œ±):=(p0,p0,p1,‚Ä¶,p‚Ñì+1).assignprependùõºsubscriptùëù0subscriptùëù0subscriptùëù1‚Ä¶subscriptùëù‚Ñì1\text{prepend}(\alpha):=(p_{0},p_{0},p_{1},\dots,p_{\ell+1}).

This is rùëür-close to the loop obtained by replacing the second entry by q1subscriptùëû1q_{1}, i.e.

Œ∑1:=(p0,q1,p1,‚Ä¶,p‚Ñì+1).assignsubscriptùúÇ1subscriptùëù0subscriptùëû1subscriptùëù1‚Ä¶subscriptùëù‚Ñì1\eta_{1}:=(p_{0},q_{1},p_{1},\dots,p_{\ell+1}).

Now we take a homotopy with only local changes to the loop which is exactly the same except repeating the point p2subscriptùëù2p_{2} twice:

(p0,q1,p1,p2,p2,p3,‚Ä¶,p‚Ñì+1).subscriptùëù0subscriptùëû1subscriptùëù1subscriptùëù2subscriptùëù2subscriptùëù3‚Ä¶subscriptùëù‚Ñì1(p_{0},q_{1},p_{1},p_{2},p_{2},p_{3},\dots,p_{\ell+1}).

Now we make a ‚Äòsynchronized jump‚Äô where we change the third entry from p1subscriptùëù1p_{1} to q1subscriptùëû1q_{1} and the fourth entry from p2subscriptùëù2p_{2} to q2subscriptùëû2q_{2} and end up with the loop

Œ∑2:=(p0,q1,q1,q2,p2,p3,‚Ä¶,p‚Ñì+1).assignsubscriptùúÇ2subscriptùëù0subscriptùëû1subscriptùëû1subscriptùëû2subscriptùëù2subscriptùëù3‚Ä¶subscriptùëù‚Ñì1\eta_{2}:=(p_{0},q_{1},q_{1},q_{2},p_{2},p_{3},\dots,p_{\ell+1}).

See Figure 1 for the idea.

Now we move the repeated entry of q1subscriptùëû1q_{1} over so that p3subscriptùëù3p_{3} is repeated twice, and we do another synchronized jump. We keep doing synchronized jumps until we changed all points pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i} to points qisubscriptùëûùëñq_{i}. Finally we move any repeated points so that they are at the end, and after endpoint deletions we obtain Œ≤ùõΩ\beta.‚àé

2.4. Additional notation and terminology

Let Œ±=(pi)0‚â§i‚â§nùõºsubscriptsubscriptùëùùëñ0ùëñùëõ\alpha=(p_{i})_{0\leq i\leq n} be an rùëür-path in a compact metric space XùëãX. The length ‚Ñì‚Äã(Œ±)‚Ñìùõº\ell(\alpha) of Œ±ùõº\alpha is defined by

‚Ñì‚Äã(Œ±):=‚àë0‚â§i<nd‚Äã(pi,pi+1).assign‚Ñìùõºsubscript0ùëñùëõùëësubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëñ1\ell(\alpha):=\sum_{0\leq i<n}d(p_{i},p_{i+1}).

We denote by Œ±¬Ø=(pn‚àíi)0‚â§i‚â§n¬Øùõºsubscriptsubscriptùëùùëõùëñ0ùëñùëõ\overline{\alpha}=(p_{n-i})_{0\leq i\leq n} the reverse of Œ±ùõº\alpha. If Œ≤=(qi)0‚â§i‚â§mùõΩsubscriptsubscriptùëûùëñ0ùëñùëö\beta=(q_{i})_{0\leq i\leq m} is another rùëür-path in XùëãX with d‚Äã(pn,q0)‚â§rùëësubscriptùëùùëõsubscriptùëû0ùëüd(p_{n},q_{0})\leq r, then

Œ±‚àóŒ≤:=(p0,‚Ä¶,pn,q0,‚Ä¶,qm)assign‚àóùõºùõΩsubscriptùëù0‚Ä¶subscriptùëùùëõsubscriptùëû0‚Ä¶subscriptùëûùëö\alpha\ast\beta:=(p_{0},\dots,p_{n},q_{0},\dots,q_{m})

denotes the concatenation of Œ±ùõº\alpha and Œ≤ùõΩ\beta.

3. Coarse fundamental group of level sets of warped cones

3.1. Statement of result

The goal of this section is to compute the coarse fundamental group of the level set MtsubscriptùëÄùë°M_{t} of ùíû‚Äã(Œì‚Ü∑M)ùíû‚Ü∑ŒìM\operatorname{\mathscr{C}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)} at time tùë°t. A heuristic comes from the analogy between coarse algebraic topology on Mt=(t‚ÄãM√óŒì)/ŒìsubscriptùëÄùë°ùë°ùëÄŒìŒìM_{t}=(tM\times\Gamma)/\Gamma and (continuous) algebraic topology on E:=(M√óX~)/Œìassignùê∏ùëÄ~ùëãŒìE:=(M\times\widetilde{X})/\Gamma, whenever X=X~/Œìùëã~ùëãŒìX=\widetilde{X}/\Gamma is an aspherical manifold with fundamental group ŒìŒì\Gamma. After lifting the ŒìŒì\Gamma‚Äìaction on MùëÄM to an action of a group Œì~~Œì\widetilde{\Gamma} on the universal cover M~~ùëÄ\widetilde{M} of MùëÄM, we have E=(M~√óX~)/Œì~ùê∏~ùëÄ~ùëã~ŒìE=(\widetilde{M}\times\widetilde{X})/\widetilde{\Gamma}, so we see that œÄ1‚Äã(E)‚âÖŒì~subscriptùúã1ùê∏~Œì\pi_{1}(E)\cong\widetilde{\Gamma} is the group of lifts of ŒìŒì\Gamma to M~~ùëÄ\widetilde{M}. We prove the same result holds in the coarse setting:

Proposition 3.1.

Let ŒìŒì\Gamma be a finitely presented group acting minimally, isometrically, and freely on a manifold MùëÄM. Let Œì~~Œì\widetilde{\Gamma} be the group of lifts of ŒìŒì\Gamma to the universal cover M~~ùëÄ\widetilde{M} of MùëÄM. Then for every t‚â´r‚â´1much-greater-thanùë°ùëümuch-greater-than1t\gg r\gg 1 and p0‚ààMsubscriptùëù0ùëÄp_{0}\in M, we have

œÄ1‚Äã(Mt,p0;r)‚âÖŒì~.subscriptùúã1subscriptùëÄùë°subscriptùëù0ùëü~Œì\pi_{1}(M_{t},p_{0};r)\cong\widetilde{\Gamma}.
Remark 3.2.

A computation of coarse fundamental groups of warped cones was independently and simultaneously obtained by Vigolo [Vig2]. Note that the setting there is much more general than the one we consider here, although the final answer is presented in a form that is not adapted to the relationship between Œì,œÄ1‚Äã(M)Œìsubscriptùúã1ùëÄ\Gamma,\pi_{1}(M) and œÄ1‚Äã(M;r)subscriptùúã1ùëÄùëü\pi_{1}(M;r) that we need at present.

The stabilization of the coarse fundamental group œÄ1‚Äã(Mt,p0;r)subscriptùúã1subscriptùëÄùë°subscriptùëù0ùëü\pi_{1}(M_{t},p_{0};r) as t‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùë°t\to\infty easily allows for the following computation of the fundamental group of geometric cones. However, the full geometric cone is coarsely contractible (because the manifold has been coned off, at least on the scale rùëür). To counteract this, we introduce a truncated geometric cone: For t0>0subscriptùë°00t_{0}>0, we write ùí¢t0‚Äã(Œì‚Ü∑M):=(M√ó[t0,‚àû)√óŒì)/Œìassignsubscriptùí¢subscriptt0‚Ü∑ŒìMùëÄsubscriptùë°0ŒìŒì\operatorname{\mathscr{G}_{t_{0}}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)}:=(M\times[t_{0},\infty)\times\Gamma)/\Gamma for the geometric cone truncated at level t0subscriptùë°0t_{0}. It is easy to see the projection ùí¢t0‚Äã(Œì‚Ü∑M)‚ÜíMt0‚Üísubscriptùí¢subscriptt0‚Ü∑ŒìMsubscriptùëÄsubscriptùë°0\operatorname{\mathscr{G}_{t_{0}}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)}\to M_{t_{0}} is a coarse deformation retract, so we have:

Corollary 3.3.

Let ŒìŒì\Gamma be a finitely presented group acting minimally, isometrically, and freely on a manifold MùëÄM. Then for t>t0‚â´r‚â´1ùë°subscriptùë°0much-greater-thanùëümuch-greater-than1t>t_{0}\gg r\gg 1, the inclusion Mt0‚Ü™ùí¢t0‚Äã(Œì‚Ü∑M)‚Ü™subscriptùëÄsubscriptùë°0subscriptùí¢subscriptt0‚Ü∑ŒìMM_{t_{0}}\hookrightarrow\operatorname{\mathscr{G}_{t_{0}}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)} induces an isomorphism on coarse fundamental groups at scale rùëür. In particular, we have œÄ1‚Äã(ùí¢t0‚Äã(Œì‚Ü∑M),[p0,t0];r)‚âÖŒì~.subscriptùúã1subscriptùí¢subscriptt0‚Ü∑ŒìMsubscriptùëù0subscriptùë°0ùëü~Œì\pi_{1}(\operatorname{\mathscr{G}_{t_{0}}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)},[p_{0},t_{0}];r)\cong\widetilde{\Gamma}.

We provide a brief outline of the proof of Proposition 3.1: In Section 3.2 we associate to every coarse loop an element of Œ≥ùõæ\gamma, based on the observation that given two sufficiently close points x,yùë•ùë¶x,y in MtsubscriptùëÄùë°M_{t}, there is a unique element of ŒìŒì\Gamma that translates xùë•x to a point near yùë¶y in MùëÄM. In this way we associate to a coarse loop finitely many elements of ŒìŒì\Gamma. By taking the product we obtain a map œÄ1‚Äã(M,p0;r)‚ÜíŒì‚Üísubscriptùúã1ùëÄsubscriptùëù0ùëüŒì\pi_{1}(M,p_{0};r)\to\Gamma. In Section 3.4 we show that discretization of continuous loops gives a map œÄ1‚Äã(M,p0)‚ÜíœÄ1‚Äã(M,p0;r)‚Üísubscriptùúã1ùëÄsubscriptùëù0subscriptùúã1ùëÄsubscriptùëù0ùëü\pi_{1}(M,p_{0})\to\pi_{1}(M,p_{0};r) that is an embedding for t‚â´r‚â´1much-greater-thanùë°ùëümuch-greater-than1t\gg r\gg 1. In Section 3.3, we introduce a technical tool that decomposes an arbitrary coarse path (up to coarse homotopy) into an orbital and spatial segment. Next, in Section 3.5, we use this to study the relationship between the contributions of the action and the manifold to the coarse fundamental group, and show œÄ1‚Äã(M,p0;r)subscriptùúã1ùëÄsubscriptùëù0ùëü\pi_{1}(M,p_{0};r) is an extension of ŒìŒì\Gamma by œÄ1‚Äã(M)subscriptùúã1ùëÄ\pi_{1}(M). Finally in Section 3.6 we show that this extension is in fact Œì~~Œì\widetilde{\Gamma}.

3.2. The contribution of the action

We start by associating an element of ŒìŒì\Gamma to every coarse loop in MtsubscriptùëÄùë°M_{t}. For R>0ùëÖ0R>0, set

Œ¥Œì‚Äã(R):=min‚ÄñŒ≥‚Äñ‚â§R‚Å°minx‚ààM‚Å°d‚Äã(x,Œ≥‚Äãx).assignsubscriptùõøŒìùëÖsubscriptnormùõæùëÖsubscriptùë•ùëÄùëëùë•ùõæùë•\delta_{\Gamma}(R):=\min_{\|\gamma\|\leq R}\,\min_{x\in M}d(x,\gamma x).
Construction 3.4.

Let t>2‚ÄãrŒ¥Œì‚Äã(2‚Äãr)ùë°2ùëüsubscriptùõøŒì2ùëüt>\frac{2r}{\delta_{\Gamma}(2r)}. Let Œ±=(p0,p1,‚Ä¶,p‚Ñì,p0)ùõºsubscriptùëù0subscriptùëù1‚Ä¶subscriptùëù‚Ñìsubscriptùëù0\alpha=(p_{0},p_{1},\dots,p_{\ell},p_{0}) be an rùëür-path based at p0subscriptùëù0p_{0}. Since

dtŒì‚Äã(pi,pi+1)=infŒ≥(‚ÄñŒ≥‚Äñ+t‚ÄãdM‚Äã(Œ≥‚Äãpi,pi+1))<r,superscriptsubscriptùëëùë°Œìsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëñ1subscriptinfimumùõænormùõæùë°subscriptùëëùëÄùõæsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëñ1ùëüd_{t}^{\Gamma}(p_{i},p_{i+1})=\inf_{\gamma}\left(\|\gamma\|+t\,d_{M}(\gamma p_{i},p_{i+1})\right)<r,

we see there exists some Œ≥‚ààBŒì‚Äã(r)ùõæsubscriptùêµŒìùëü\gamma\in B_{\Gamma}(r) with dM‚Äã(Œ≥‚Äãpi,pi+1)<rtsubscriptùëëùëÄùõæsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëñ1ùëüùë°d_{M}(\gamma p_{i},p_{i+1})<\frac{r}{t}. Further this element Œ≥ùõæ\gamma is unique, because if Œ∑ùúÇ\eta is another element with this property, then Œ≥‚àí1‚ÄãŒ∑superscriptùõæ1ùúÇ\gamma^{-1}\eta is an element of length at most 2‚Äãr2ùëü2r that displaces pisubscriptùëùùëñp_{i} by at most 2‚Äãrt2ùëüùë°\frac{2r}{t}. Since t>2‚ÄãrŒ¥Œì‚Äã(2‚Äãr)ùë°2ùëüsubscriptùõøŒì2ùëüt>\frac{2r}{\delta_{\Gamma}(2r)}, this forces Œ≥=Œ∑ùõæùúÇ\gamma=\eta, as desired.

Hence we can associate to the rùëür-path Œ±ùõº\alpha a sequence of elements Œ≥i‚Äã(Œ±)‚ààBŒì‚Äã(r)subscriptùõæùëñùõºsubscriptùêµŒìùëü\gamma_{i}(\alpha)\in B_{\Gamma}(r) such that dM‚Äã(Œ≥i‚Äãpi,pi+1)<rtsubscriptùëëùëÄsubscriptùõæùëñsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëñ1ùëüùë°d_{M}(\gamma_{i}p_{i},p_{i+1})<\frac{r}{t} for every iùëñi.

Definition 3.5.

Let t>2‚ÄãrŒ¥Œì‚Äã(2‚Äãr)ùë°2ùëüsubscriptùõøŒì2ùëüt>\frac{2r}{\delta_{\Gamma}(2r)}. Write P‚Äã(M;r)ùëÉùëÄùëüP(M;r) for the space of rùëür-paths. Also write F‚Äã(BŒì‚Äã(r))ùêπsubscriptùêµŒìùëüF(B_{\Gamma}(r)) for the free group on BŒì‚Äã(r)subscriptùêµŒìùëüB_{\Gamma}(r). Define

Q~:P‚Äã(M;r)‚ÜíF‚Äã(BŒì‚Äã(r)):~ùëÑ‚ÜíùëÉùëÄùëüùêπsubscriptùêµŒìùëü\widetilde{Q}:P(M;r)\to F(B_{\Gamma}(r))

by Q~‚Äã(Œ±):=Œ≥‚Ñì‚Äã(Œ±)‚Äã‚ãØ‚ÄãŒ≥0‚Äã(Œ±)assign~ùëÑùõºsubscriptùõæ‚Ñìùõº‚ãØsubscriptùõæ0ùõº\widetilde{Q}(\alpha):=\gamma_{\ell}(\alpha)\cdots\gamma_{0}(\alpha) for Œ±=(p0,p1,‚Ä¶,p‚Ñì)‚ààP‚Äã(M;r)ùõºsubscriptùëù0subscriptùëù1‚Ä¶subscriptùëù‚ÑìùëÉùëÄùëü\alpha=(p_{0},p_{1},\dots,p_{\ell})\in P(M;r).

Lemma 3.6.

Let t>4‚ÄãrŒ¥‚Äã(4‚Äãr)ùë°4ùëüùõø4ùëüt>\frac{4r}{\delta(4r)}. If Œ±ùõº\alpha and Œ≤ùõΩ\beta are rùëür-homotopic rùëür-loops based at p0subscriptùëù0p_{0}, then as elements of ŒìŒì\Gamma we have Q~‚Äã(Œ±)=Q~‚Äã(Œ≤)~ùëÑùõº~ùëÑùõΩ\widetilde{Q}(\alpha)=\widetilde{Q}(\beta). Hence Q~~ùëÑ\widetilde{Q} descends to a map

Q:œÄ1‚Äã(M,p0;r)‚ÜíŒì.:ùëÑ‚Üísubscriptùúã1ùëÄsubscriptùëù0ùëüŒìQ:\pi_{1}(M,p_{0};r)\to\Gamma.

For Œ±‚ààœÄ1‚Äã(M,p0;r)ùõºsubscriptùúã1ùëÄsubscriptùëù0ùëü\alpha\in\pi_{1}(M,p_{0};r), we say Q‚Äã(Œ±)‚ààŒìùëÑùõºŒìQ(\alpha)\in\Gamma is the orbital jump along Œ±ùõº\alpha.

Proof.

Clearly Q~~ùëÑ\widetilde{Q} is invariant under endpoint appends and deletions. Therefore it suffices to show the statement for a pair of rùëür-loops Œ±,Œ≤ùõºùõΩ\alpha,\beta based at p0subscriptùëù0p_{0} that are rùëür-close and of the same length. By Lemma 2.7, there is an rùëür-homotopy from Œ±ùõº\alpha to Œ≤ùõΩ\beta of the form

Œ±=Œ∑0,Œ∑1,‚Ä¶,Œ∑k=Œ≤formulae-sequenceùõºsubscriptùúÇ0subscriptùúÇ1‚Ä¶subscriptùúÇùëòùõΩ\alpha=\eta_{0},\,\eta_{1},\,\dots,\,\eta_{k}=\beta

where Œ∑isubscriptùúÇùëñ\eta_{i} and Œ∑i+1subscriptùúÇùëñ1\eta_{i+1} differ in at most two positions, and these are consecutive. Therefore it suffices to prove the statement assuming Œ≤=Œ∑1ùõΩsubscriptùúÇ1\beta=\eta_{1}.

So suppose

Œ±=(p0,‚Ä¶,pk‚àí1,pk,pk+1,pk+2,‚Ä¶,p‚Ñì)ùõºsubscriptùëù0‚Ä¶subscriptùëùùëò1subscriptùëùùëòsubscriptùëùùëò1subscriptùëùùëò2‚Ä¶subscriptùëù‚Ñì\alpha=(p_{0},\dots,p_{k-1},p_{k},p_{k+1},p_{k+2},\dots,p_{\ell})

and

Œ≤=(p0,‚Ä¶,pk‚àí1,qk,qk+1,pk+2,‚Ä¶,p‚Ñì).ùõΩsubscriptùëù0‚Ä¶subscriptùëùùëò1subscriptùëûùëòsubscriptùëûùëò1subscriptùëùùëò2‚Ä¶subscriptùëù‚Ñì\beta=(p_{0},\dots,p_{k-1},q_{k},q_{k+1},p_{k+2},\dots,p_{\ell}).

Let Œ≥k‚àí1,Œ≥k,Œ≥k+1subscriptùõæùëò1subscriptùõæùëòsubscriptùõæùëò1\gamma_{k-1},\gamma_{k},\gamma_{k+1} be defined as before, i.e. these are the unique elements of length at most rùëür such that

dM‚Äã(Œ≥i‚Äãpi,pi+1)<rt.subscriptùëëùëÄsubscriptùõæùëñsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëñ1ùëüùë°d_{M}(\gamma_{i}p_{i},p_{i+1})<\frac{r}{t}.

Likewise define Œ∑isubscriptùúÇùëñ\eta_{i} associated to the path Œ≤ùõΩ\beta. Since Œ±ùõº\alpha and Œ≤ùõΩ\beta coincide except for the kùëòk and (k+1)ùëò1(k+1)st position, we clearly have Œ≥i=Œ∑isubscriptùõæùëñsubscriptùúÇùëñ\gamma_{i}=\eta_{i} for |i‚àík|>1ùëñùëò1|i-k|>1. Therefore to prove the claim it suffices to show

Œ≥k+1‚ÄãŒ≥k‚ÄãŒ≥k‚àí1=Œ∑k+1‚ÄãŒ∑k‚ÄãŒ∑k‚àí1.subscriptùõæùëò1subscriptùõæùëòsubscriptùõæùëò1subscriptùúÇùëò1subscriptùúÇùëòsubscriptùúÇùëò1\gamma_{k+1}\gamma_{k}\gamma_{k-1}=\eta_{k+1}\eta_{k}\eta_{k-1}. (3.1)

Let Œæksubscriptùúâùëò\xi_{k} and Œæk+1subscriptùúâùëò1\xi_{k+1} be the unique elements of length at most rùëür such that

dM‚Äã(Œæi‚Äãqi,pi)<rt.subscriptùëëùëÄsubscriptùúâùëñsubscriptùëûùëñsubscriptùëùùëñùëüùë°d_{M}(\xi_{i}q_{i},p_{i})<\frac{r}{t}.

See Figure 2 for a schematic depiction of the situation. First observe that

Œ≥k‚àí1‚ÄãŒ∑k‚àí1‚àí1=ŒækandŒ≥k+1‚àí1‚ÄãŒ∑k+1=Œæk+1.formulae-sequencesubscriptùõæùëò1superscriptsubscriptùúÇùëò11subscriptùúâùëòandsuperscriptsubscriptùõæùëò11subscriptùúÇùëò1subscriptùúâùëò1\gamma_{k-1}\eta_{k-1}^{-1}=\xi_{k}\hskip 28.45274pt\text{and}\hskip 28.45274pt\gamma_{k+1}^{-1}\eta_{k+1}=\xi_{k+1}.

Indeed otherwise one would obtain a nontrivial element of ŒìŒì\Gamma of length at most 3r that displaces a point less than 3‚Äãrt3ùëüùë°\frac{3r}{t}, but this is impossible since

t>4‚ÄãrŒ¥Œì‚Äã(4‚Äãr)>3‚ÄãrŒ¥Œì‚Äã(3‚Äãr).ùë°4ùëüsubscriptùõøŒì4ùëü3ùëüsubscriptùõøŒì3ùëüt>\frac{4r}{\delta_{\Gamma}(4r)}>\frac{3r}{\delta_{\Gamma}(3r)}.

Hence to prove Equation (3.1), it suffices to show Œ≥k‚ÄãŒæk=Œæk+1‚ÄãŒ∑k.subscriptùõæùëòsubscriptùúâùëòsubscriptùúâùëò1subscriptùúÇùëò\gamma_{k}\xi_{k}=\xi_{k+1}\eta_{k}. Indeed, (Œæk+1‚ÄãŒ∑k)‚àí1‚ÄãŒ≥k‚ÄãŒæksuperscriptsubscriptùúâùëò1subscriptùúÇùëò1subscriptùõæùëòsubscriptùúâùëò(\xi_{k+1}\eta_{k})^{-1}\gamma_{k}\xi_{k} is an element of length at most 4‚Äãr4ùëü4r that displaces qksubscriptùëûùëòq_{k} by less than 4‚Äãrt4ùëüùë°\frac{4r}{t}. Since t>4‚ÄãrŒ¥Œì‚Äã(4‚Äãr)ùë°4ùëüsubscriptùõøŒì4ùëüt>\frac{4r}{\delta_{\Gamma}(4r)}, we must have (Œæk+1‚ÄãŒ∑k)‚àí1‚ÄãŒ≥k‚ÄãŒæk=esuperscriptsubscriptùúâùëò1subscriptùúÇùëò1subscriptùõæùëòsubscriptùúâùëòùëí(\xi_{k+1}\eta_{k})^{-1}\gamma_{k}\xi_{k}=e, as desired. ‚àé

We make a new definition that will be useful for showing QùëÑQ is surjective. For Œ≥‚ààŒìùõæŒì\gamma\in\Gamma, we define an rùëür-loop based at p0subscriptùëù0p_{0} that first performs orbital jumps whose product in ŒìŒì\Gamma is Œ≥ùõæ\gamma, and then follows a discretization of a continuous path in MùëÄM from Œ≥‚Äãp0ùõæsubscriptùëù0\gamma p_{0} to p0subscriptùëù0p_{0}.

Definition 3.7.

For each Œ≥‚ààŒìùõæŒì\gamma\in\Gamma, make a choice of writing Œ≥=sik‚Äã‚ãØ‚Äãsi1ùõæsubscriptùë†subscriptùëñùëò‚ãØsubscriptùë†subscriptùëñ1\gamma=s_{i_{k}}\cdots s_{i_{1}} as a product of generators, and a choice of path cŒ≥subscriptùëêùõæc_{\gamma} from Œ≥‚Äãp0ùõæsubscriptùëù0\gamma p_{0} to p0subscriptùëù0p_{0}. Further choose a discretization (q0,q1,‚Ä¶,q‚Ñì)subscriptùëû0subscriptùëû1‚Ä¶subscriptùëû‚Ñì(q_{0},q_{1},\dots,q_{\ell}) on the scale rtùëüùë°\frac{r}{t} of cŒ≥subscriptùëêùõæc_{\gamma}, and such that q0=Œ≥‚Äãp0subscriptùëû0ùõæsubscriptùëù0q_{0}=\gamma p_{0} and q‚Ñì=p0subscriptùëû‚Ñìsubscriptùëù0q_{\ell}=p_{0}. Define »∑~Œì:Œì‚ÜíŒ©‚Äã(M,p0;r):subscript~italic-»∑Œì‚ÜíŒìŒ©ùëÄsubscriptùëù0ùëü\widetilde{\jmath}_{\Gamma}:\Gamma\to\Omega(M,p_{0};r) by »∑~‚Äã(Œ≥)‚Äã(0):=p0assign~italic-»∑ùõæ0subscriptùëù0\widetilde{\jmath}(\gamma)(0):=p_{0} and

»∑~‚Äã(Œ≥)‚Äã(j):=(‚àè1‚â§l‚â§jsil)‚Äãp0assign~italic-»∑ùõæùëósubscriptproduct1ùëôùëósubscriptùë†subscriptùëñùëôsubscriptùëù0\widetilde{\jmath}(\gamma)(j):=\left(\prod_{1\leq l\leq j}s_{i_{l}}\right)p_{0}

if 1‚â§l‚â§k1ùëôùëò1\leq l\leq k, and »∑~‚Äã(Œ≥)‚Äã(k+j)=qj~italic-»∑ùõæùëòùëósubscriptùëûùëó\widetilde{\jmath}(\gamma)(k+j)=q_{j} if k<j‚â§k+‚Ñìùëòùëóùëò‚Ñìk<j\leq k+\ell. Write »∑Œì:Œì‚ÜíœÄ1‚Äã(M,p0;r):subscriptitalic-»∑Œì‚ÜíŒìsubscriptùúã1ùëÄsubscriptùëù0ùëü\jmath_{\Gamma}:\Gamma\to\pi_{1}(M,p_{0};r) for the map that assigns the coarse homotopy class.

Warning 3.8.

»∑Œìsubscriptitalic-»∑Œì\jmath_{\Gamma} need not be a homomorphism.

Lemma 3.9.

Q‚àò»∑Œì=idŒìùëÑsubscriptitalic-»∑ŒìsubscriptidŒìQ\circ\jmath_{\Gamma}=\text{id}_{\Gamma}. Hence »∑Œìsubscriptitalic-»∑Œì\jmath_{\Gamma} is injective and QùëÑQ is surjective.

Proof.

This is a straightforward verification.‚àé

3.3. Canonical forms for coarse paths

We briefly interrupt the computation of the coarse fundamental group to discuss a useful tool for the rest of the computation. Namely, we can reorder the jumps in an rùëür-path so that all the orbital jumps occur at the start, and all the spatial ones at the end.

Definition 3.10.

Let Œ±ùõº\alpha be an rùëür-path. Define the orbital component of Œ±ùõº\alpha

ùí™‚Äã(Œ±):=(p0,Œ≥0‚Äãp0,Œ≥1‚ÄãŒ≥0‚Äãp0,‚Ä¶,Q‚Äã(Œ±)‚Äãp0)assignùí™ùõºsubscriptùëù0subscriptùõæ0subscriptùëù0subscriptùõæ1subscriptùõæ0subscriptùëù0‚Ä¶ùëÑùõºsubscriptùëù0\mathcal{O}(\alpha):=(p_{0},\gamma_{0}p_{0},\gamma_{1}\gamma_{0}p_{0},\dots,Q(\alpha)p_{0})

and the spatial component

ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ±):=(Q‚Äã(Œ±)‚Äãp0,Œ≥‚Ñì‚Äã‚ãØ‚ÄãŒ≥1‚Äãp1,‚Ä¶,p‚Ñì)assignùíÆùõºùëÑùõºsubscriptùëù0subscriptùõæ‚Ñì‚ãØsubscriptùõæ1subscriptùëù1‚Ä¶subscriptùëù‚Ñì\mathcal{S}(\alpha):=(Q(\alpha)p_{0},\gamma_{\ell}\cdots\gamma_{1}p_{1},\dots,p_{\ell})

of Œ±ùõº\alpha. The canonical form of Œ±ùõº\alpha is ùíû‚Äã(Œ±):=ùí™‚Äã(Œ±)‚àóùíÆ‚Äã(Œ±)assignùíûùõº‚àóùí™ùõºùíÆùõº\mathcal{C}(\alpha):=\mathcal{O}(\alpha)\ast\mathcal{S}(\alpha).

The relevance for the present computation of coarse fundamental groups is that this operation does not change the coarse homotopy class.

Lemma 3.11.

Let t‚â´r‚â´1much-greater-thanùë°ùëümuch-greater-than1t\gg r\gg 1. Then any rùëür-path Œ±ùõº\alpha is rùëür-homotopic rel endpoints to its canonical form ùíû‚Äã(Œ±)ùíûùõº\mathcal{C}(\alpha).

Proof.

This is straightforward. For the idea to to construct the homotopy from Œ±ùõº\alpha to ùíû‚Äã(Œ±)ùíûùõº\mathcal{C}(\alpha), see Figure 3.

‚àé

For later use, we record the following elementary property of canonical forms:

Lemma 3.12.

Let t‚â´r‚â´1much-greater-thanùë°ùëümuch-greater-than1t\gg r\gg 1. Then an rùëür-path and its canonical form have the same length.

Proof.

Let Œ±ùõº\alpha be an rùëür-path. We keep the notation of Definition 3.10. Note that for each iùëñi, we have

dtŒì‚Äã(pi,pi+1)=‚ÄñŒ≥i‚Äñ+t‚ÄãdM‚Äã(Œ≥i‚Äãpi,Œ≥i+1),superscriptsubscriptùëëùë°Œìsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëñ1normsubscriptùõæùëñùë°subscriptùëëùëÄsubscriptùõæùëñsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùõæùëñ1d_{t}^{\Gamma}(p_{i},p_{i+1})=\|\gamma_{i}\|+t\,d_{M}(\gamma_{i}p_{i}\,,\gamma_{i+1}),

so

‚Ñì‚Äã(Œ±)=‚àëi(‚ÄñŒ≥i‚Äñ+t‚ÄãdM‚Äã(Œ≥i‚Äãpi,Œ≥i+1)).‚Ñìùõºsubscriptùëñnormsubscriptùõæùëñùë°subscriptùëëùëÄsubscriptùõæùëñsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùõæùëñ1\ell(\alpha)=\sum_{i}(\|\gamma_{i}\|+t\,d_{M}(\gamma_{i}p_{i}\,,\gamma_{i+1})).

On the other hand, it is easy to see that ‚Ñì‚Äã(ùí™‚Äã(Œ±))=‚àëi‚ÄñŒ≥i‚Äñ‚Ñìùí™ùõºsubscriptùëñnormsubscriptùõæùëñ\ell(\mathcal{O}(\alpha))=\sum_{i}\|\gamma_{i}\| and ‚Ñì‚Äã(ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ±))=‚àëit‚ÄãdM‚Äã(Œ≥i‚Äãpi,pi+1).‚ÑìùíÆùõºsubscriptùëñùë°subscriptùëëùëÄsubscriptùõæùëñsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëñ1\ell(\mathcal{S}(\alpha))=\sum_{i}t\,d_{M}(\gamma_{i}p_{i}\,,p_{i+1}). ‚àé

It is easy to verify the following cocycle-type behavior of canonical forms with respect to concatenation:

Lemma 3.13.

Let Œ±ùõº\alpha and Œ≤ùõΩ\beta be rùëür-paths such that the endpoint of Œ±ùõº\alpha is distance at most rùëür from the starting point of Œ≤ùõΩ\beta. Then

ùí™‚Äã(Œ±‚àóŒ≤)=ùí™‚Äã(Œ±)‚àóùí™‚Äã(Œ≤)ùí™‚àóùõºùõΩ‚àóùí™ùõºùí™ùõΩ\mathcal{O}(\alpha\ast\beta)=\mathcal{O}(\alpha)\ast\mathcal{O}(\beta)

and

ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ±‚àóŒ≤)=(Q‚Äã(Œ≤)‚ÄãùíÆ‚Äã(Œ±))‚àóùíÆ‚Äã(Œ≤).ùíÆ‚àóùõºùõΩ‚àóùëÑùõΩùíÆùõºùíÆùõΩ\mathcal{S}(\alpha\ast\beta)=(Q(\beta)\,\mathcal{S}(\alpha))\ast\mathcal{S}(\beta).

3.4. The contribution of the manifold

We will now work to explain the relationship between œÄ1‚Äã(M)subscriptùúã1ùëÄ\pi_{1}(M) and œÄ1‚Äã(M;r)subscriptùúã1ùëÄùëü\pi_{1}(M;r). Consider the natural discretization map

»∑M:œÄ1‚Äã(M)‚Ü™œÄ1‚Äã(Mt;r).:subscriptitalic-»∑ùëÄ‚Ü™subscriptùúã1ùëÄsubscriptùúã1subscriptùëÄùë°ùëü\jmath_{M}:\pi_{1}(M)\hookrightarrow\pi_{1}(M_{t};r).

See Section 2.2 for the definition. We aim to show this is an embedding whose image is a normal subgroup.

Lemma 3.14.

For t‚â´r‚â´1much-greater-thanùë°ùëümuch-greater-than1t\gg r\gg 1, the map »∑Msubscriptitalic-»∑ùëÄ\jmath_{M} is injective.

Proof.

Let c‚ààœÄ1‚Äã(M)ùëêsubscriptùúã1ùëÄc\in\pi_{1}(M) be a nontrivial (continuous) homotopy class of loops. Let Œ∏ùúÉ\theta be a discretization on the scale rtùëüùë°\frac{r}{t} of an element of cùëêc. Suppose Œ∏ùúÉ\theta were rùëür‚Äìnullhomotopic. By Lemma 2.7, we can choose an rùëür‚Äìnullhomotopy of Œ∏ùúÉ\theta such that any two consecutive curves in the homotopy differ in at most two positions, and these are consecutive. Let Œ±ùõº\alpha and Œ≤ùõΩ\beta be any two consecutive curves in the nullhomotopy. We claim that ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ±)ùíÆùõº\mathcal{S}(\alpha) and ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ≤)ùíÆùõΩ\mathcal{S}(\beta) are 4‚Äãrt4ùëüùë°\frac{4r}{t}‚Äìclose as coarse paths in MùëÄM.

To see this, retain the notation of the proof of Lemma 3.12 (see Figure 2). Note that since Q‚Äã(Œ∏)=eùëÑùúÉùëíQ(\theta)=e, and hence also Q‚Äã(Œ±)=Q‚Äã(Œ≤)=eùëÑùõºùëÑùõΩùëíQ(\alpha)=Q(\beta)=e, we know that ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ±)ùíÆùõº\mathcal{S}(\alpha) and ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ≤)ùíÆùõΩ\mathcal{S}(\beta) start at p0subscriptùëù0p_{0}. Now we have

ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ±)=(Œ≥‚Ñì‚Äã‚ãØ‚ÄãŒ≥0‚Äãp0,Œ≥‚Ñì‚Äã‚ãØ‚ÄãŒ≥1‚Äãp1,Œ≥‚Ñì‚Äã‚ãØ‚ÄãŒ≥2‚Äãp2,‚Ä¶,Œ≥‚Ñì‚Äãp‚Ñì)ùíÆùõºsubscriptùõæ‚Ñì‚ãØsubscriptùõæ0subscriptùëù0subscriptùõæ‚Ñì‚ãØsubscriptùõæ1subscriptùëù1subscriptùõæ‚Ñì‚ãØsubscriptùõæ2subscriptùëù2‚Ä¶subscriptùõæ‚Ñìsubscriptùëù‚Ñì\mathcal{S}(\alpha)=(\gamma_{\ell}\cdots\gamma_{0}p_{0},\gamma_{\ell}\cdots\gamma_{1}p_{1},\gamma_{\ell}\cdots\gamma_{2}p_{2},\dots,\gamma_{\ell}p_{\ell})

and similarly for ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ≤)ùíÆùõΩ\mathcal{S}(\beta). Now since Œ∑j=Œ≥jsubscriptùúÇùëósubscriptùõæùëó\eta_{j}=\gamma_{j} whenever |j‚àík|>1ùëóùëò1|j-k|>1, we see that ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ±)ùíÆùõº\mathcal{S}(\alpha) and ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ≤)ùíÆùõΩ\mathcal{S}(\beta) agree for the last ‚Ñì‚àí(k+1)‚Ñìùëò1\ell-(k+1) terms. Further we have Œ≥k+1‚ÄãŒ≥k‚ÄãŒ≥k‚àí1=Œ∑k+1‚ÄãŒ∑k‚ÄãŒ∑k‚àí1subscriptùõæùëò1subscriptùõæùëòsubscriptùõæùëò1subscriptùúÇùëò1subscriptùúÇùëòsubscriptùúÇùëò1\gamma_{k+1}\gamma_{k}\gamma_{k-1}=\eta_{k+1}\eta_{k}\eta_{k-1} (see Equation (3.1)), so ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ±)ùíÆùõº\mathcal{S}(\alpha) and ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ≤)ùíÆùõΩ\mathcal{S}(\beta) also agree for the first kùëòk terms. To finish the proof, we will show

dM‚Äã(Œ≥‚Ñì‚Äã‚ãØ‚ÄãŒ≥k+2‚ÄãŒ≥k+1‚Äãpk+1,Œ≥‚Ñì‚Äã‚ãØ‚ÄãŒ≥k+2‚ÄãŒ∑k+1‚Äãqk+1)<2‚ÄãrtsubscriptùëëùëÄsubscriptùõæ‚Ñì‚ãØsubscriptùõæùëò2subscriptùõæùëò1subscriptùëùùëò1subscriptùõæ‚Ñì‚ãØsubscriptùõæùëò2subscriptùúÇùëò1subscriptùëûùëò12ùëüùë°d_{M}(\gamma_{\ell}\cdots\gamma_{k+2}\gamma_{k+1}p_{k+1}\,,\,\gamma_{\ell}\cdots\gamma_{k+2}\eta_{k+1}q_{k+1})<\frac{2r}{t}

and

dM‚Äã(Œ≥‚Ñì‚Äã‚ãØ‚ÄãŒ≥k+2‚ÄãŒ≥k+1‚ÄãŒ≥k‚Äãpk,Œ≥‚Ñì‚Äã‚ãØ‚ÄãŒ≥k+2‚ÄãŒ∑k+1‚ÄãŒ∑k‚Äãqk)<4‚Äãrt.subscriptùëëùëÄsubscriptùõæ‚Ñì‚ãØsubscriptùõæùëò2subscriptùõæùëò1subscriptùõæùëòsubscriptùëùùëòsubscriptùõæ‚Ñì‚ãØsubscriptùõæùëò2subscriptùúÇùëò1subscriptùúÇùëòsubscriptùëûùëò4ùëüùë°d_{M}(\gamma_{\ell}\cdots\gamma_{k+2}\gamma_{k+1}\gamma_{k}p_{k}\,,\,\gamma_{\ell}\cdots\gamma_{k+2}\eta_{k+1}\eta_{k}q_{k})<\frac{4r}{t}.

The first inequality is equivalent to proving

dM‚Äã(Œ≥k+1‚Äãpk+1,Œ∑k+1‚Äãqk+1)<2‚Äãrt,subscriptùëëùëÄsubscriptùõæùëò1subscriptùëùùëò1subscriptùúÇùëò1subscriptùëûùëò12ùëüùë°d_{M}(\gamma_{k+1}p_{k+1}\,,\,\eta_{k+1}q_{k+1})<\frac{2r}{t},

which is true because both are distance at most rtùëüùë°\frac{r}{t} from pk+2subscriptùëùùëò2p_{k+2}. The second is equivalent to proving

dM‚Äã(Œ≥k+1‚ÄãŒ≥k‚Äãpk,Œ∑k+1‚ÄãŒ∑k‚Äãqk)<4‚Äãrt,subscriptùëëùëÄsubscriptùõæùëò1subscriptùõæùëòsubscriptùëùùëòsubscriptùúÇùëò1subscriptùúÇùëòsubscriptùëûùëò4ùëüùë°d_{M}(\gamma_{k+1}\gamma_{k}p_{k}\,,\,\eta_{k+1}\eta_{k}q_{k})<\frac{4r}{t},

which is true because both are distance at most 2‚Äãrt2ùëüùë°\frac{2r}{t} from pk+1subscriptùëùùëò1p_{k+1}.

By connecting the points in ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ±)ùíÆùõº\mathcal{S}(\alpha) (resp. ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ≤)ùíÆùõΩ\mathcal{S}(\beta)) by minimizing geodesic segments, we obtain a continuous loop cŒ±subscriptùëêùõºc_{\alpha} (resp. cŒ≤subscriptùëêùõΩc_{\beta}) in MùëÄM. Since cŒ±subscriptùëêùõºc_{\alpha} and cŒ≤subscriptùëêùõΩc_{\beta} are uniformly close, we see that for t‚â´r‚â´1much-greater-thanùë°ùëümuch-greater-than1t\gg r\gg 1, they are homotopic rel p0subscriptùëù0p_{0}.

It follows that for any coarse loop Œ±ùõº\alpha in the nullhomotopy of Œ∏ùúÉ\theta, we have that ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ±)ùíÆùõº\mathcal{S}(\alpha) is in the image under »∑Msubscriptitalic-»∑ùëÄ\jmath_{M} of the original loop [c]delimited-[]ùëê[c]. In particular, the length of ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ±)ùíÆùõº\mathcal{S}(\alpha) is uniformly bounded below. This contradicts the fact that we have a coarse nullhomotopy of Œ∏ùúÉ\theta.‚àé

3.5. Relationship between the two contributions

Let us now return to the computation of the coarse fundamental group.

Lemma 3.15.

»∑M‚Äã(œÄ1‚Äã(M))subscriptitalic-»∑ùëÄsubscriptùúã1ùëÄ\jmath_{M}(\pi_{1}(M)) and »∑Œì‚Äã(Œì)subscriptitalic-»∑ŒìŒì\jmath_{\Gamma}(\Gamma) generate œÄ1‚Äã(Mt,p0;r)subscriptùúã1subscriptùëÄùë°subscriptùëù0ùëü\pi_{1}(M_{t},p_{0};r) and have trivial intersection.

Proof.

Let Œ±ùõº\alpha be an rùëür‚Äìloop based at p0subscriptùëù0p_{0}. By Lemma 3.11, Œ±ùõº\alpha is rùëür-homotopic rel endpoints to its canonical form ùíû‚Äã(Œ±)=ùí™‚Äã(Œ±)‚àóùíÆ‚Äã(Œ±)ùíûùõº‚àóùí™ùõºùíÆùõº\mathcal{C}(\alpha)=\mathcal{O}(\alpha)\ast\,\mathcal{S}(\alpha). Consider »∑~Œì‚Äã(Q‚Äã(Œ±)‚àí1)‚àóùíû‚Äã(Œ±)‚àósubscript~italic-»∑ŒìùëÑsuperscriptùõº1ùíûùõº\widetilde{\jmath}_{\Gamma}(Q(\alpha)^{-1})\ast\mathcal{C}(\alpha). Note that »∑~Œì‚Äã(Q‚Äã(Œ±)‚àí1)subscript~italic-»∑ŒìùëÑsuperscriptùõº1\widetilde{\jmath}_{\Gamma}(Q(\alpha)^{-1}) ends in a sequence of orbital jumps ùí™‚Äã(»∑~Œì‚Äã(Q‚Äã(Œ±)‚àí1))ùí™subscript~italic-»∑ŒìùëÑsuperscriptùõº1\mathcal{O}(\widetilde{\jmath}_{\Gamma}(Q(\alpha)^{-1})) whose product in ŒìŒì\Gamma is Q‚Äã(Œ±)‚àí1ùëÑsuperscriptùõº1Q(\alpha)^{-1} and hence

ùí™‚Äã(»∑~Œì‚Äã(Q‚Äã(Œ±)))‚àóùí™‚Äã(Œ±)‚àóùí™subscript~italic-»∑ŒìùëÑùõºùí™ùõº\mathcal{O}(\widetilde{\jmath}_{\Gamma}(Q(\alpha)))\ast\mathcal{O}(\alpha)

is a sequence of orbital jumps by products of conjugates of relators. Since rùëür is larger than the length of any relator, we can cancel these out and hence »∑~Œì‚Äã(Q‚Äã(Œ±)‚àí1)‚àóùíû‚Äã(Œ±)‚àósubscript~italic-»∑ŒìùëÑsuperscriptùõº1ùíûùõº\widetilde{\jmath}_{\Gamma}(Q(\alpha)^{-1})\ast\mathcal{C}(\alpha) is rùëür-homotopic to a spatial loop, i.e. is in the image of »∑Msubscriptitalic-»∑ùëÄ\jmath_{M}.

Finally, we show »∑M‚Äã(œÄ1‚Äã(M))subscriptitalic-»∑ùëÄsubscriptùúã1ùëÄ\jmath_{M}(\pi_{1}(M)) and »∑Œì‚Äã(Œì)subscriptitalic-»∑ŒìŒì\jmath_{\Gamma}(\Gamma) intersect trivially. Indeed, we clearly have Q‚àò»∑M=1ùëÑsubscriptitalic-»∑ùëÄ1Q\circ\jmath_{M}=1. On the other hand, if Œ≥‚ààŒìùõæŒì\gamma\in\Gamma is nontrivial, then Q‚Äã(»∑Œì‚Äã(Œ≥))=Œ≥ùëÑsubscriptitalic-»∑ŒìùõæùõæQ(\jmath_{\Gamma}(\gamma))=\gamma, so »∑Œì‚Äã(Œ≥)‚àâ»∑M‚Äã(œÄ1‚Äã(M))subscriptitalic-»∑Œìùõæsubscriptitalic-»∑ùëÄsubscriptùúã1ùëÄ\jmath_{\Gamma}(\gamma)\notin\jmath_{M}(\pi_{1}(M)). ‚àé

Lemma 3.16.

»∑M‚Äã(œÄ1‚Äã(M))subscriptitalic-»∑ùëÄsubscriptùúã1ùëÄ\jmath_{M}(\pi_{1}(M)) is normal in œÄ1‚Äã(M,p0;r)subscriptùúã1ùëÄsubscriptùëù0ùëü\pi_{1}(M,p_{0};r).

Proof.

We claim that »∑M‚Äã(œÄ1‚Äã(M))=ker‚Å°(Q)subscriptitalic-»∑ùëÄsubscriptùúã1ùëÄkernelùëÑ\jmath_{M}(\pi_{1}(M))=\ker(Q), which will suffice to show »∑M‚Äã(œÄ1‚Äã(M))subscriptitalic-»∑ùëÄsubscriptùúã1ùëÄ\jmath_{M}(\pi_{1}(M)) is normal. Indeed, it is clear that »∑M‚Äã(œÄ1‚Äã(M))‚äÜker‚Å°(Q)subscriptitalic-»∑ùëÄsubscriptùúã1ùëÄkernelùëÑ\jmath_{M}(\pi_{1}(M))\subseteq\ker(Q). To show the other direction, suppose Œ±ùõº\alpha is an rùëür-loop based at p0subscriptùëù0p_{0} with [Œ±]‚ààker‚Å°(Q)delimited-[]ùõºkernelùëÑ[\alpha]\in\ker(Q). Let Œ±~~ùõº\widetilde{\alpha} be the canonical representative, where the initial sequence of jumps is

Œ≥0,Œ≥1,‚Ä¶,Œ≥‚Ñìsubscriptùõæ0subscriptùõæ1‚Ä¶subscriptùõæ‚Ñì\gamma_{0},\gamma_{1},\dots,\gamma_{\ell}

and Œ≥i‚ààSsubscriptùõæùëñùëÜ\gamma_{i}\in S, the generators for ŒìŒì\Gamma, and after that Œ±~‚Äã(i)=pi~ùõºùëñsubscriptùëùùëñ\widetilde{\alpha}(i)=p_{i}, so dM‚Äã(pi,pi+1)<rtsubscriptùëëùëÄsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëñ1ùëüùë°d_{M}(p_{i},p_{i+1})<\frac{r}{t}.
