We know that Q‚Äã(Œ±)=‚àèiŒ≥iùëÑùõºsubscriptproductùëñsubscriptùõæùëñQ(\alpha)=\prod_{i}\gamma_{i} is trivial, so as a word in F‚Äã(S)ùêπùëÜF(S), we have that ‚àèiŒ≥isubscriptproductùëñsubscriptùõæùëñ\prod_{i}\gamma_{i} is a product of conjugates of relators. Since rùëür is larger than the maximal size of a relator, and r>2ùëü2r>2 (so that for any generator sùë†s, a jump sequence of the form s‚Äãs‚àí1ùë†superscriptùë†1ss^{-1} can be canceled), we see that Œ±~~ùõº\widetilde{\alpha} is rùëür-homotopic to the loop that omits the initial sequence of jumps and then performs the rest of Œ±~~ùõº\widetilde{\alpha}, i.e. ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ±~)ùíÆ~ùõº\mathcal{S}(\widetilde{\alpha}). This loop is in »∑M‚Äã(œÄ1‚Äã(M))subscriptitalic-»∑ùëÄsubscriptùúã1ùëÄ\jmath_{M}(\pi_{1}(M)), as desired. ‚àé

3.6. End of the proof

At this point we know that for t‚â´r‚â´1much-greater-thanùë°ùëümuch-greater-than1t\gg r\gg 1, the group œÄ1‚Äã(Mt,p0;r)subscriptùúã1subscriptùëÄùë°subscriptùëù0ùëü\pi_{1}(M_{t},p_{0};r) is an extension

1‚ÜíœÄ1‚Äã(M,p0)‚Äã‚ü∂»∑M‚ÄãœÄ1‚Äã(Mt,p0;r)‚Äã‚ü∂ùëÑ‚ÄãŒì‚Üí1.‚Üí1subscriptùúã1ùëÄsubscriptùëù0subscriptitalic-»∑ùëÄ‚ü∂subscriptùúã1subscriptùëÄùë°subscriptùëù0ùëüùëÑ‚ü∂Œì‚Üí11\to\pi_{1}(M,p_{0})\overset{\jmath_{M}}{\longrightarrow}\pi_{1}(M_{t},p_{0};r)\overset{Q}{\longrightarrow}\Gamma\to 1. (3.2)

Further the action of ŒìŒì\Gamma by conjugation on œÄ1‚Äã(M,p0)subscriptùúã1ùëÄsubscriptùëù0\pi_{1}(M,p_{0}) is induced from Œì‚Ü∑M‚Ü∑ŒìùëÄ\Gamma\curvearrowright M. We want to show œÄ1‚Äã(Mt;r)subscriptùúã1subscriptùëÄùë°ùëü\pi_{1}(M_{t};r) is given by the group of lifts Œì~~Œì\widetilde{\Gamma} of ŒìŒì\Gamma to the universal cover M~~ùëÄ\widetilde{M} of MùëÄM. Note that Œì~~Œì\widetilde{\Gamma} is also an extension

1‚ÜíœÄ1‚Äã(M)‚Äã‚ü∂ùúÑ‚ÄãŒì~‚Äã‚ü∂ùúã‚ÄãŒì‚Üí1,‚Üí1subscriptùúã1ùëÄùúÑ‚ü∂~Œìùúã‚ü∂Œì‚Üí11\to\pi_{1}(M)\overset{\iota}{\longrightarrow}\widetilde{\Gamma}\overset{\pi}{\longrightarrow}\Gamma\to 1, (3.3)

with the action of ŒìŒì\Gamma on œÄ1‚Äã(M)subscriptùúã1ùëÄ\pi_{1}(M) by conjugation induced from ŒìŒì\Gamma acting on MùëÄM. We will need the following straightforward fact:

Lemma 3.17.

The action of Œì~~Œì\widetilde{\Gamma} on M~~ùëÄ\widetilde{M} is free.

Proof.

This is immediate from the fact that ŒìŒì\Gamma acts freely on MùëÄM, and œÄ1‚Äã(M)subscriptùúã1ùëÄ\pi_{1}(M) acts freely on M~~ùëÄ\widetilde{M}. Indeed, suppose Œ≥~‚ààŒì~~ùõæ~Œì\widetilde{\gamma}\in\widetilde{\Gamma} fixes p~‚ààM~~ùëù~ùëÄ\widetilde{p}\in\widetilde{M}. Let Œ≥=œÄ‚Äã(Œ≥~)ùõæùúã~ùõæ\gamma=\pi(\widetilde{\gamma}) be the image of Œ≥~~ùõæ\widetilde{\gamma} in ŒìŒì\Gamma and let pùëùp be the image of p~~ùëù\widetilde{p} in MùëÄM. Then Œ≥ùõæ\gamma fixes pùëùp. Since ŒìŒì\Gamma acts freely, it follows Œ≥=eùõæùëí\gamma=e, and hence Œ≥~‚ààœÄ1‚Äã(M)~ùõæsubscriptùúã1ùëÄ\widetilde{\gamma}\in\pi_{1}(M). But œÄ1‚Äã(M)subscriptùúã1ùëÄ\pi_{1}(M) acts freely on M~~ùëÄ\widetilde{M}, so Œ≥~=e~ùõæùëí\widetilde{\gamma}=e.‚àé

Construction 3.18.

Fix a basepoint p~0‚ààM~subscript~ùëù0~ùëÄ\widetilde{p}_{0}\in\widetilde{M} that maps to p0‚ààMsubscriptùëù0ùëÄp_{0}\in M. We define a map

Œò:œÄ1‚Äã(M,p0;r)‚ÜíŒì~:Œò‚Üísubscriptùúã1ùëÄsubscriptùëù0ùëü~Œì\Theta:\pi_{1}(M,p_{0};r)\to\widetilde{\Gamma}

as follows. Let Œ±‚ààœÄ1‚Äã(M,p0;r)ùõºsubscriptùúã1ùëÄsubscriptùëù0ùëü\alpha\in\pi_{1}(M,p_{0};r). We assume Œ±=ùí™‚Äã(Œ±)‚àóùíÆ‚Äã(Œ±)ùõº‚àóùí™ùõºùíÆùõº\alpha=\mathcal{O}(\alpha)\ast\mathcal{S}(\alpha) is in canonical form and write Œ≥:=Q‚Äã(Œ±)assignùõæùëÑùõº\gamma:=Q(\alpha). Write cùëêc for the piecewise geodesic path in MùëÄM from p0subscriptùëù0p_{0} to Œ≥‚Äãp0ùõæsubscriptùëù0\gamma p_{0} obtained by connecting the points in the spatial path ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ±)ùíÆùõº\mathcal{S}(\alpha) by minimizing geodesic segments (observe that since rt<injrad‚Äã(M)ùëüùë°injradùëÄ\frac{r}{t}<\text{injrad}(M), we can do this in a unique way). Now lift cùëêc to a path c~~ùëê\widetilde{c} in the universal cover M~~ùëÄ\widetilde{M} that starts at p~0subscript~ùëù0\widetilde{p}_{0}. Note that c~‚Äã(1)~ùëê1\widetilde{c}(1) maps to c‚Äã(1)=Œ≥‚Äãp0‚ààMùëê1ùõæsubscriptùëù0ùëÄc(1)=\gamma p_{0}\in M. Hence there exists an element Œ≥~‚ààŒì~~ùõæ~Œì\widetilde{\gamma}\in\widetilde{\Gamma} with Œ≥~‚Äãp~0=c~‚Äã(1)~ùõæsubscript~ùëù0~ùëê1\widetilde{\gamma}\widetilde{p}_{0}=\widetilde{c}(1). Since Œì~~Œì\widetilde{\Gamma} acts freely on M~~ùëÄ\widetilde{M} (by the previous claim), Œ≥~~ùõæ\widetilde{\gamma} is unique. Define

Œò‚Äã(Œ±):=Œ≥~.assignŒòùõº~ùõæ\Theta(\alpha):=\widetilde{\gamma}.

Recall that Œì~~Œì\widetilde{\Gamma} is an extension

1‚ÜíœÄ1‚Äã(M)‚Äã‚ü∂ùúÑ‚ÄãŒì~‚Äã‚ü∂ùúã‚ÄãŒì‚Üí1.‚Üí1subscriptùúã1ùëÄùúÑ‚ü∂~Œìùúã‚ü∂Œì‚Üí11\to\pi_{1}(M)\overset{\iota}{\longrightarrow}\widetilde{\Gamma}\overset{\pi}{\longrightarrow}\Gamma\to 1. (3.4)
Lemma 3.19.

œÄ‚àòŒò=QùúãŒòùëÑ\pi\circ\Theta=Q and Œò‚àò»∑M=ŒπŒòsubscriptitalic-»∑ùëÄùúÑ\Theta\circ\jmath_{M}=\iota.

Proof.

Retain the notation of Construction 3.18. For the first claim: Since ŒìŒì\Gamma acts freely, it suffices to show that the image of Œò‚Äã(Œ±)‚Äãp~0Œòùõºsubscript~ùëù0\Theta(\alpha)\widetilde{p}_{0} in MùëÄM is exactly Œ≥‚Äãp0ùõæsubscriptùëù0\gamma p_{0}. But Œò‚Äã(Œ±)‚Äãp~0=c~‚Äã(1)Œòùõºsubscript~ùëù0~ùëê1\Theta(\alpha)\widetilde{p}_{0}=\widetilde{c}(1) projects to c‚Äã(1)=Œ≥‚Äãp0ùëê1ùõæsubscriptùëù0c(1)=\gamma p_{0} in MùëÄM, as desired.

The second claim is clear because a lift of c‚ààœÄ1‚Äã(M,p0)ùëêsubscriptùúã1ùëÄsubscriptùëù0c\in\pi_{1}(M,p_{0}) starting at p~0subscript~ùëù0\widetilde{p}_{0} has endpoint given by Œπ‚Äã(c)‚Äãp~0ùúÑùëêsubscript~ùëù0\iota(c)\widetilde{p}_{0}.‚àé

Lemma 3.20.

ŒòŒò\Theta is an antihomomorphism.

Proof.

Let Œ±,Œ≤ùõºùõΩ\alpha,\beta be rùëür‚Äìloops based at p0subscriptùëù0p_{0} and assume they are in canonical form. Recall from Lemma 3.13 that ùí™‚Äã(Œ±‚àóŒ≤)=ùí™‚Äã(Œ±)‚àóùí™‚Äã(Œ≤)ùí™‚àóùõºùõΩ‚àóùí™ùõºùí™ùõΩ\mathcal{O}(\alpha\ast\beta)=\mathcal{O}(\alpha)\ast\mathcal{O}(\beta) and ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ±‚àóŒ≤)=(Q‚Äã(Œ≤)‚ÄãùíÆ‚Äã(Œ±))‚àóùíÆ‚Äã(Œ≤)ùíÆ‚àóùõºùõΩ‚àóùëÑùõΩùíÆùõºùíÆùõΩ\mathcal{S}(\alpha\ast\beta)=(Q(\beta)\,\mathcal{S}(\alpha))\ast\mathcal{S}(\beta). Let cŒ±subscriptùëêùõºc_{\alpha} (resp. cŒ≤subscriptùëêùõΩc_{\beta}) be the (continuous) path in MùëÄM obtained by connecting the points of ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ±)ùíÆùõº\mathcal{S}(\alpha) (resp. ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ≤)ùíÆùõΩ\mathcal{S}(\beta)) by minimizing geodesic segments.

The lift of the path Œ≥Œ≤‚ÄãcŒ±‚àócŒ≤‚àósubscriptùõæùõΩsubscriptùëêùõºsubscriptùëêùõΩ\gamma_{\beta}\,c_{\alpha}\ast c_{\beta} to M~~ùëÄ\widetilde{M} that starts at p~0subscript~ùëù0\widetilde{p}_{0} starts with c~Œ≤subscript~ùëêùõΩ\widetilde{c}_{\beta}, and then takes the lift of Œ≥Œ≤‚ÄãcŒ±subscriptùõæùõΩsubscriptùëêùõº\gamma_{\beta}\,c_{\alpha} that starts at c~Œ≤‚Äã(1):=Œò‚Äã(Œ≤)‚Äãp~0assignsubscript~ùëêùõΩ1ŒòùõΩsubscript~ùëù0\widetilde{c}_{\beta}(1):=\Theta(\beta)\,\widetilde{p}_{0}. Therefore the lift of Œ≥Œ≤‚ÄãcŒ±subscriptùõæùõΩsubscriptùëêùõº\gamma_{\beta}\,c_{\alpha} that is taken is Œò‚Äã(Œ≤)‚Äãc~Œ±ŒòùõΩsubscript~ùëêùõº\Theta(\beta)\,\widetilde{c}_{\alpha}. The endpoint is therefore Œò‚Äã(Œ≤)‚Äãc~Œ±‚Äã(1)=Œò‚Äã(Œ≤)‚ÄãŒò‚Äã(Œ±)‚Äãp~0ŒòùõΩsubscript~ùëêùõº1ŒòùõΩŒòùõºsubscript~ùëù0\Theta(\beta)\,\widetilde{c}_{\alpha}(1)=\Theta(\beta)\,\Theta(\alpha)\widetilde{p}_{0}. Hence we see Œò‚Äã(Œ±‚ÄãŒ≤)=Œò‚Äã(Œ≤)‚ÄãŒò‚Äã(Œ±)ŒòùõºùõΩŒòùõΩŒòùõº\Theta(\alpha\beta)=\Theta(\beta)\,\Theta(\alpha). ‚àé

Finally we are able to prove that œÄ1‚Äã(Mt;r)‚âÖŒì~subscriptùúã1subscriptùëÄùë°ùëü~Œì\pi_{1}(M_{t};r)\cong\widetilde{\Gamma}, thereby finishing the proof of Proposition 3.1.

Lemma 3.21.

ŒòŒò\Theta is an anti-isomorphism.

Proof.

We first show ŒòŒò\Theta is injective. Let Œ±‚ààker‚Å°(Œò)ùõºkernelŒò\alpha\in\ker(\Theta). Since Œò‚Äã(Œ±)Œòùõº\Theta(\alpha) lifts Q‚Äã(Œ±)ùëÑùõºQ(\alpha) and Œò‚Äã(Œ±)=eŒòùõºùëí\Theta(\alpha)=e, we see Œ≥=eùõæùëí\gamma=e, so Œ±‚àà»∑M‚Äã(œÄ1‚Äã(M))ùõºsubscriptitalic-»∑ùëÄsubscriptùúã1ùëÄ\alpha\in\jmath_{M}(\pi_{1}(M)). But by Claim 3.19, we have Œò‚àò»∑M=ŒπŒòsubscriptitalic-»∑ùëÄùúÑ\Theta\circ\jmath_{M}=\iota, and ŒπùúÑ\iota is injective. It follows that ker‚Å°Œò‚à©»∑M‚Äã(œÄ1‚Äã(M))=1kernelŒòsubscriptitalic-»∑ùëÄsubscriptùúã1ùëÄ1\ker\Theta\cap\jmath_{M}(\pi_{1}(M))=1. This proves ŒòŒò\Theta is injective.

Finally we show ŒòŒò\Theta is surjective. Let Œ≥~‚ààŒì~~ùõæ~Œì\widetilde{\gamma}\in\widetilde{\Gamma}, and write Œ≥=œÄ‚Äã(Œ≥~)ùõæùúã~ùõæ\gamma=\pi(\widetilde{\gamma}) for the image of Œ≥~~ùõæ\widetilde{\gamma} in ŒìŒì\Gamma. Note that Œò‚Äã(»∑Œì‚Äã(Œ≥))Œòsubscriptitalic-»∑Œìùõæ\Theta(\jmath_{\Gamma}(\gamma)) is characterized by the property that Œò‚Äã(»∑Œì‚Äã(Œ≥))‚Äãp~0=c~Œ≥‚Äã(1)Œòsubscriptitalic-»∑Œìùõæsubscript~ùëù0subscript~ùëêùõæ1\Theta(\jmath_{\Gamma}(\gamma))\widetilde{p}_{0}=\widetilde{c}_{\gamma}(1), where cŒ≥subscriptùëêùõæc_{\gamma} is the arbitrary choice of continuous path from p0subscriptùëù0p_{0} to Œ≥‚Äãp0ùõæsubscriptùëù0\gamma p_{0} made in the definition of »∑italic-»∑\jmath, see Definition 3.7. Since c~Œ≥‚Äã(1)subscript~ùëêùõæ1\widetilde{c}_{\gamma}(1) and Œ≥~‚Äãp~0~ùõæsubscript~ùëù0\widetilde{\gamma}\widetilde{p}_{0} both project to Œ≥‚Äãp0‚ààMùõæsubscriptùëù0ùëÄ\gamma p_{0}\in M, there is Œ∑‚ààœÄ1‚Äã(M,p0)ùúÇsubscriptùúã1ùëÄsubscriptùëù0\eta\in\pi_{1}(M,p_{0}) such that Œπ‚Äã(Œ∑)‚Äãc~Œ≥‚Äã(1)=Œ≥~‚Äãp~0ùúÑùúÇsubscript~ùëêùõæ1~ùõæsubscript~ùëù0\iota(\eta)\widetilde{c}_{\gamma}(1)=\widetilde{\gamma}\widetilde{p}_{0}. Hence we have

Œ∑‚ÄãŒò‚Äã(»∑Œì‚Äã(Œ≥))=Œ≥~.ùúÇŒòsubscriptitalic-»∑Œìùõæ~ùõæ\eta\,\Theta(\jmath_{\Gamma}(\gamma))=\widetilde{\gamma}.

On the other hand Œπ‚Äã(Œ∑)=Œò‚Äã(»∑M‚Äã(Œ∑))ùúÑùúÇŒòsubscriptitalic-»∑ùëÄùúÇ\iota(\eta)=\Theta(\jmath_{M}(\eta)) by Lemma 3.19. Hence we see

Œò‚Äã(»∑M‚Äã(Œ∑))‚ÄãŒò‚Äã(»∑Œì‚Äã(Œ≥))=Œ≥~,Œòsubscriptitalic-»∑ùëÄùúÇŒòsubscriptitalic-»∑Œìùõæ~ùõæ\Theta(\jmath_{M}(\eta))\,\Theta(\jmath_{\Gamma}(\gamma))=\widetilde{\gamma},

so ŒòŒò\Theta is surjective.‚àé

3.7. Coarse homotopical behavior of quasi-isometries

The stabilization of œÄ1‚Äã(Mt;r)subscriptùúã1subscriptùëÄùë°ùëü\pi_{1}(M_{t};r) to Œì~~Œì\widetilde{\Gamma} as rùëür is fixed and t‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùë°t\to\infty immediately implies that the change-of-scale map becomes an isomorphism. More precisely, let us decorate the isomorphism ŒòŒò\Theta defined above with the scale rùëür, so that Œòr:œÄ1‚Äã(Mt;r)‚ÜíŒì~:subscriptŒòùëü‚Üísubscriptùúã1subscriptùëÄùë°ùëü~Œì\Theta_{r}:\pi_{1}(M_{t};r)\to\widetilde{\Gamma} is the above isomorphism, and let Œºr,r‚Ä≤subscriptùúáùëüsuperscriptùëü‚Ä≤\mu_{r,r^{\prime}} be change-of-scale from rùëür to r‚Ä≤superscriptùëü‚Ä≤r^{\prime}. Then whenever t‚â´r‚Ä≤>r‚â´1much-greater-thanùë°superscriptùëü‚Ä≤ùëümuch-greater-than1t\gg r^{\prime}>r\gg 1, we have Œòr‚Ä≤‚àòŒºr,r‚Ä≤=Œòr.subscriptŒòsuperscriptùëü‚Ä≤subscriptùúáùëüsuperscriptùëü‚Ä≤subscriptŒòùëü\Theta_{r^{\prime}}\circ\mu_{r,r^{\prime}}=\Theta_{r}. In particular Œºr,r‚Ä≤subscriptùúáùëüsuperscriptùëü‚Ä≤\mu_{r,r^{\prime}} is an isomorphism. This has the following interesting consequence for the behavior of quasi-isometries of level sets of warped cones.

Lemma 3.22.

Fix L‚â•1ùêø1L\geq 1 and C‚â•0ùê∂0C\geq 0. For s,t‚â´r‚â´1much-greater-thanùë†ùë°ùëümuch-greater-than1s,t\gg r\gg 1, any (L,C)ùêøùê∂(L,C)‚Äìquasi-isometry f:Mt‚ÜíNs:ùëì‚ÜísubscriptùëÄùë°subscriptùëÅùë†f:M_{t}\to N_{s} induces an isomorphism Œ¶:œÄ1‚Äã(Mt;r)‚ÜíœÄ1‚Äã(Ns;L‚Äãr+C):Œ¶‚Üísubscriptùúã1subscriptùëÄùë°ùëüsubscriptùúã1subscriptùëÅùë†ùêøùëüùê∂\Phi:\pi_{1}(M_{t};r)\to\pi_{1}(N_{s};Lr+C) on coarse fundamental groups.

Proof.

Write g:Ns‚ÜíMt:ùëî‚ÜísubscriptùëÅùë†subscriptùëÄùë°g:N_{s}\to M_{t} for the coarse inverse of fùëìf, so gùëîg is also an (L,C)ùêøùê∂(L,C)‚Äìquasi-isometry and f‚àògùëìùëîf\circ g and g‚àòfùëîùëìg\circ f displace points by at most Cùê∂C. Then

g‚àó‚Äãf‚àó=(g‚àòf)‚àó:œÄ1‚Äã(Mt;r)‚ÜíœÄ1‚Äã(Mt;L2‚Äãr+L‚ÄãC+C):subscriptùëî‚àósubscriptùëì‚àósubscriptùëîùëì‚àó‚Üísubscriptùúã1subscriptùëÄùë°ùëüsubscriptùúã1subscriptùëÄùë°superscriptùêø2ùëüùêøùê∂ùê∂g_{\ast}f_{\ast}=(g\circ f)_{\ast}:\pi_{1}(M_{t};r)\to\pi_{1}(M_{t};L^{2}r+LC+C)

is given by change-of-scale (because g‚àòfùëîùëìg\circ f displaces points at most Cùê∂C and the scale in the target is at least Cùê∂C), and hence g‚àó‚Äãf‚àósubscriptùëî‚àósubscriptùëì‚àóg_{\ast}f_{\ast} is an isomorphism. Likewise f‚àó‚Äãg‚àósubscriptùëì‚àósubscriptùëî‚àóf_{\ast}g_{\ast} is an isomorphism, so f‚àósubscriptùëì‚àóf_{\ast} is an isomorphism. ‚àé

4. Coarse homotopy invariance of group contributions

4.1. Setup

For the rest of this section, let ŒìŒì\Gamma (resp. ŒõŒõ\Lambda) be a finitely presented group acting minimally, isometrically, and freely on a closed manifold MùëÄM (resp. NùëÅN), and assume that ŒìŒì\Gamma and ŒõŒõ\Lambda are not commensurable to a group with a free abelian factor. Further f:Mt‚ÜíNs:ùëì‚ÜísubscriptùëÄùë°subscriptùëÅùë†f:M_{t}\to N_{s} will denote an (L,C)ùêøùê∂(L,C)‚Äìquasi-isometry.

4.2. Statement of result

In this section, we aim to define, for every s,t‚â´r‚â´L+Cmuch-greater-thanùë†ùë°ùëümuch-greater-thanùêøùê∂s,t\gg r\gg L+C, an invariant of an (L,C)ùêøùê∂(L,C)-quasi-isometry f:Mt‚ÜíNs:ùëì‚ÜísubscriptùëÄùë°subscriptùëÅùë†f:M_{t}\to N_{s} that measures the extent to which fùëìf (coarsely) preserves the action and manifold contributions to the coarse fundamental group, i.e. the data of the extensions

1‚ÜíœÄ1‚Äã(M)‚ÜíœÄ1‚Äã(Mt;r)‚ÜíŒì‚Üí1‚Üí1subscriptùúã1ùëÄ‚Üísubscriptùúã1subscriptùëÄùë°ùëü‚ÜíŒì‚Üí11\to\pi_{1}(M)\to\pi_{1}(M_{t};r)\to\Gamma\to 1

and the corresponding extension for NssubscriptùëÅùë†N_{s}. To start, recall that we defined for an rùëür-loop Œ±ùõº\alpha in MùëÄM, its orbital jump Q~‚Äã(Œ±)~ùëÑùõº\widetilde{Q}(\alpha) (see Definition 3.5). We intend to show:

Proposition 4.1.

There are commensurations M‚Ä≤superscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤M^{\prime} of MùëÄM and N‚Ä≤superscriptùëÅ‚Ä≤N^{\prime} of NùëÅN, such that the following holds for any s,t‚â´r‚â´1much-greater-thanùë†ùë°ùëümuch-greater-than1s,t\gg r\gg 1: Let Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime} (resp. Œõ‚Ä≤superscriptŒõ‚Ä≤\Lambda^{\prime}) be the group of lifts of ŒìŒì\Gamma (resp. ŒõŒõ\Lambda) to M‚Ä≤superscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤M^{\prime} (resp. N‚Ä≤superscriptùëÅ‚Ä≤N^{\prime}), and let f‚Ä≤:Mt‚Ä≤‚ÜíNs‚Ä≤:superscriptùëì‚Ä≤‚ÜísuperscriptsubscriptùëÄùë°‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùëÅùë†‚Ä≤f^{\prime}:M_{t}^{\prime}\to N_{s}^{\prime} be an (L,C)ùêøùê∂(L,C)‚Äìquasi-isometry. Let p,q‚ààM‚Ä≤ùëùùëûsuperscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤p,q\in M^{\prime} and let Œ±ùõº\alpha be a (continuous) path in M‚Ä≤superscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤M^{\prime} from pùëùp to qùëûq. Then QŒõ‚Ä≤‚Äã(f‚Ä≤‚àò»∑M‚Äã(Œ±))subscriptùëÑsuperscriptŒõ‚Ä≤superscriptùëì‚Ä≤subscriptitalic-»∑ùëÄùõºQ_{\Lambda^{\prime}}(f^{\prime}\circ\jmath_{M}(\alpha)) only depends on pùëùp and qùëûq, and not on the path Œ±ùõº\alpha chosen.

This will use in an essential way that the groups ŒìŒì\Gamma and ŒõŒõ\Lambda are complicated (namely not commensurable to any group with a free abelian factor), and is false otherwise.

4.3. Construction of the commensurable spaces

We start by finding the right covers M‚Ä≤superscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤M^{\prime} and N‚Ä≤superscriptùëÅ‚Ä≤N^{\prime} to prove Proposition 4.1.

Proposition 4.2.

ŒìŒì\Gamma contains a maximal finite normal subgroup. The same holds for ŒõŒõ\Lambda.

It clearly suffices to prove the statement for ŒìŒì\Gamma. We prove this in two steps. We will start by proving this for a finite-index subgroup of ŒìŒì\Gamma. Namely, let G=Œì¬Øùê∫¬ØŒìG=\overline{\Gamma} denote the closure of ŒìŒì\Gamma in Isom‚Å°(M)IsomùëÄ\operatorname{Isom}(M), let G0superscriptùê∫0G^{0} be the connected component of the identity of Gùê∫G, and set Œì0:=Œì‚à©G0assignsubscriptŒì0Œìsuperscriptùê∫0\Gamma_{0}:=\Gamma\cap G^{0}. Note that Œì0subscriptŒì0\Gamma_{0} is a finite-index subgroup of ŒìŒì\Gamma.

Lemma 4.3.

Œì0subscriptŒì0\Gamma_{0} contains a maximal finite normal subgroup.

Proof.

Note that any finite normal subgroup FùêπF of Œì0subscriptŒì0\Gamma_{0} is central, because G0superscriptùê∫0G^{0} normalizes FùêπF and by connectedness must centralize it. Since a pair of finite central subgroups generates a finite central subgroup, we see the union FùêπF of all finite normal subgroups is a central locally finite subgroup of ŒìŒì\Gamma. We want to show it is finite.

Indeed, F¬Ø0superscript¬Øùêπ0\overline{F}^{0} is a compact connected normal abelian subgroup of the compact connected Lie group G0superscriptùê∫0G^{0}, potentially trivial, and contains a dense locally finite group F0:=S‚à©F¬Ø0assignsubscriptùêπ0ùëÜsuperscript¬Øùêπ0F_{0}:=S\cap\overline{F}^{0}. Then F¬Ø0superscript¬Øùêπ0\overline{F}^{0} is a local torus factor of Gùê∫G. Consider the projection onto this factor, i.e.

G0‚ÜíF¬Ø0/A‚Üísuperscriptùê∫0superscript¬Øùêπ0ùê¥G^{0}\to\overline{F}^{0}/A

where Aùê¥A is a finite group. The image of ŒìŒì\Gamma is then a finitely generated abelian group in the torus F¬Ø0/Asuperscript¬Øùêπ0ùê¥\overline{F}^{0}/A and contains the image of F0subscriptùêπ0F_{0}, which is isomorphic to F0/(F0‚à©A)subscriptùêπ0subscriptùêπ0ùê¥F_{0}/(F_{0}\cap A). But any locally finite subgroup of a finitely generated abelian group is finite, so F0/(F0‚à©A)subscriptùêπ0subscriptùêπ0ùê¥F_{0}/(F_{0}\cap A) is finite. Since Aùê¥A is also finite, it follows that F0subscriptùêπ0F_{0} is finite. Finally, F¬Ø¬Øùêπ\overline{F} has finitely many components given by the group F/F0ùêπsubscriptùêπ0F/F_{0}, so that FùêπF is an extension of the finite group F/F0ùêπsubscriptùêπ0F/F_{0} by the finite group F0subscriptùêπ0F_{0}, and hence FùêπF is finite, as desired.‚àé

We can now show ŒìŒì\Gamma contains a maximal finite normal subgroup.

Proof of Proposition 4.2.

Let F0subscriptùêπ0F_{0} be the maximal finite normal subgroup of Œì0subscriptŒì0\Gamma_{0}, which exists by the above Lemma 4.3. Since any pair of finite normal subgroups generates a finite normal subgroup, the union FùêπF of all finite normal subgroups of ŒìŒì\Gamma is well-defined.

We have to show FùêπF is finite. Clearly F0‚äÜFsubscriptùêπ0ùêπF_{0}\subseteq F and F‚à©G0ùêπsuperscriptùê∫0F\cap G^{0} is a finite normal subgroup of Œì0subscriptŒì0\Gamma_{0}, so we must have F‚à©G0=F0ùêπsuperscriptùê∫0subscriptùêπ0F\cap G^{0}=F_{0}. Therefore projection mod G0superscriptùê∫0G^{0} gives an embedding

F/F0‚Ü™G/G0,‚Ü™ùêπsubscriptùêπ0ùê∫superscriptùê∫0F/F_{0}\hookrightarrow G/G^{0},

and hence

|F|‚â§|F0|‚ãÖ|G/G0|<‚àû,ùêπ‚ãÖsubscriptùêπ0ùê∫superscriptùê∫0|F|\leq|F_{0}|\cdot|G/G^{0}|<\infty,

as desired.‚àé

Armed with Proposition 4.2, we can construct the right homogeneous spaces for the proof of Proposition 4.1.

Construction 4.4.

Let FŒìsubscriptùêπŒìF_{\Gamma} be the maximal finite normal subgroup of ŒìŒì\Gamma. Then Œì/FŒìŒìsubscriptùêπŒì\Gamma/F_{\Gamma} has no finite normal subgroup. Further since FŒìsubscriptùêπŒìF_{\Gamma} is normal, the action of ŒìŒì\Gamma descends to a minimal, isometric, free action of Œì‚Ä≤:=Œì/FŒìassignsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤ŒìsubscriptùêπŒì\Gamma^{\prime}:=\Gamma/F_{\Gamma} on M‚Ä≤:=M/FŒìassignsuperscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤ùëÄsubscriptùêπŒìM^{\prime}:=M/F_{\Gamma}. Likewise we set Œõ‚Ä≤:=Œõ/FŒõassignsuperscriptŒõ‚Ä≤ŒõsubscriptùêπŒõ\Lambda^{\prime}:=\Lambda/F_{\Lambda} and N‚Ä≤:=N/FŒõassignsuperscriptùëÅ‚Ä≤ùëÅsubscriptùêπŒõN^{\prime}:=N/F_{\Lambda}. By Lemma 2.3, the warped cone over a finite quotient is uniformly quasi-isometric to the original warped cone.

4.4. Proof of Proposition 4.1

We now replace our initial actions by the commensurable quotients just constructed and so denote these quotients Œì‚Ä≤,M‚Ä≤,Œõ‚Ä≤,N‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤superscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤superscriptŒõ‚Ä≤superscriptùëÅ‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime},M^{\prime},\Lambda^{\prime},N^{\prime} by Œì,M,Œõ,NŒìùëÄŒõùëÅ\Gamma,M,\Lambda,N. The proof proceeds in several steps. We start by reducing Proposition 4.1 to a statement on coarse fundamental groups (i.e. about loops, not paths).

Lemma 4.5.

To prove Proposition 4.1, it suffices to show that for any (continuous) loop Œ±ùõº\alpha in MùëÄM, we have QŒõ‚Äã(f‚àò»∑~M‚Äã(Œ±))=esubscriptùëÑŒõùëìsubscript~italic-»∑ùëÄùõºùëíQ_{\Lambda}(f\circ\widetilde{\jmath}_{M}(\alpha))=e.

Proof.

Let p,q‚ààMùëùùëûùëÄp,q\in M and let Œ±,Œ≤ùõºùõΩ\alpha,\beta be two paths from pùëùp to qùëûq. Recall that Œ≤¬Ø¬ØùõΩ\overline{\beta} denotes the reverse of Œ≤ùõΩ\beta. It is immediate from the definition that QŒõ‚Äã(f‚àòŒ≤¬Ø)=QŒõ‚Äã(f‚àòŒ≤)‚àí1subscriptùëÑŒõùëì¬ØùõΩsubscriptùëÑŒõsuperscriptùëìùõΩ1Q_{\Lambda}(f\circ\overline{\beta})=Q_{\Lambda}(f\circ\beta)^{-1} and

QŒõ‚Äã(f‚àòŒ≤)‚àí1‚ÄãQŒõ‚Äã(f‚àòŒ±)=QŒõ‚Äã(f‚àòŒ≤¬Ø)‚ÄãQŒõ‚Äã(f‚àòŒ±)=QŒõ‚Äã(f‚àò(Œ≤¬Ø‚àóŒ±)).subscriptùëÑŒõsuperscriptùëìùõΩ1subscriptùëÑŒõùëìùõºsubscriptùëÑŒõùëì¬ØùõΩsubscriptùëÑŒõùëìùõºsubscriptùëÑŒõùëì‚àó¬ØùõΩùõºQ_{\Lambda}(f\circ\beta)^{-1}\,Q_{\Lambda}(f\circ\alpha)=Q_{\Lambda}(f\circ\overline{\beta})\,Q_{\Lambda}(f\circ\alpha)=Q_{\Lambda}(f\circ(\overline{\beta}\ast\alpha)).

Since Œ≤¬Ø‚àóŒ±‚àó¬ØùõΩùõº\overline{\beta}\ast\alpha is a loop in MùëÄM, we have QŒõ‚Äã(f‚àò(Œ≤¬Ø‚àóŒ±))=esubscriptùëÑŒõùëì‚àó¬ØùõΩùõºùëíQ_{\Lambda}(f\circ(\overline{\beta}\ast\alpha))=e by assumption and hence QŒõ‚Äã(f‚àòŒ±)=QŒõ‚Äã(f‚àòŒ≤)subscriptùëÑŒõùëìùõºsubscriptùëÑŒõùëìùõΩQ_{\Lambda}(f\circ\alpha)=Q_{\Lambda}(f\circ\beta). ‚àé

Let Œ¶:=f‚àóassignŒ¶subscriptùëì‚àó\Phi:=f_{\ast} be the map on coarse fundamental groups induced by the quasi-isometry f:Mt‚ÜíNs:ùëì‚ÜísubscriptùëÄùë°subscriptùëÅùë†f:M_{t}\to N_{s}. Consider the composition

a:œÄ1‚Äã(M,p0)‚Äã‚Ü™»∑M‚ÄãœÄ1‚Äã(Mt,p0;r)‚Äã‚ü∂Œ¶‚ÄãœÄ1‚Äã(Ns,f‚Äã(p0);L‚Äãr+C)‚Äã‚Ü†QŒõ‚ÄãŒõ.:ùëésubscriptùúã1ùëÄsubscriptùëù0subscriptitalic-»∑ùëÄ‚Ü™subscriptùúã1subscriptùëÄùë°subscriptùëù0ùëüŒ¶‚ü∂subscriptùúã1subscriptùëÅùë†ùëìsubscriptùëù0ùêøùëüùê∂subscriptùëÑŒõ‚Ü†Œõa:\pi_{1}(M,p_{0})\overset{\jmath_{M}}{\hookrightarrow}\pi_{1}(M_{t},p_{0};r)\overset{\Phi}{\longrightarrow}\pi_{1}(N_{s},f(p_{0});Lr+C)\overset{Q_{\Lambda}}{\twoheadrightarrow}\Lambda.

To prove Proposition 4.1, it therefore suffices to show:

Lemma 4.6.

aùëéa is trivial.

Before we prove this, let us just note:

Remark 4.7.

This is the key place in the proof of Theorem 1.4 where we use that ŒìŒì\Gamma and ŒõŒõ\Lambda have no free abelian factor (up to commensuration). In a sense to be made precise below, the isomorphism on coarse fundamental group induced by ftsubscriptùëìùë°f_{t} preserves the manifold contribution »∑M‚Äã(œÄ1‚Äã(M))subscriptitalic-»∑ùëÄsubscriptùúã1ùëÄ\jmath_{M}(\pi_{1}(M)) and the group contribution »∑Œì‚Äã(Œì)subscriptitalic-»∑ŒìŒì\jmath_{\Gamma}(\Gamma) to the coarse fundamental group.

This fails disastrously for actions of free abelian groups, and gives rise to the examples of Kim and Kielak‚ÄìSawicki of quasi-isometric warped cones for actions of groups that are not commensurable.

Proof of Lemma 4.6.

Since »∑M‚Äã(œÄ1‚Äã(M))subscriptitalic-»∑ùëÄsubscriptùúã1ùëÄ\jmath_{M}(\pi_{1}(M)) is normal in œÄ1‚Äã(Mt;r)subscriptùúã1subscriptùëÄùë°ùëü\pi_{1}(M_{t};r), it is clear that the image of aùëéa is normal in ŒõŒõ\Lambda. Since ŒõŒõ\Lambda does not contain any nontrivial finite normal subgroup (see Construction 4.4), it therefore suffices to show that the image of aùëéa is also finite.

Since MùëÄM is a compact homogeneous space, œÄ1‚Äã(M)subscriptùúã1ùëÄ\pi_{1}(M) contains a finite-index central free abelian subgroup Aùê¥A. We claim that there is a finite-index subgroup ŒîŒî\Delta of œÄ1‚Äã(Mt;r)subscriptùúã1subscriptùëÄùë°ùëü\pi_{1}(M_{t};r) such that Aùê¥A is also central in ŒîŒî\Delta. To see this, recall that œÄ1‚Äã(Mt;r)subscriptùúã1subscriptùëÄùë°ùëü\pi_{1}(M_{t};r) is isomorphic to the group of lifts of ŒìŒì\Gamma to MùëÄM and hence is given by an extension

1‚ÜíœÄ1‚Äã(M)‚ÜíœÄ1‚Äã(Mt;r)‚ÜíŒì‚Üí1.‚Üí1subscriptùúã1ùëÄ‚Üísubscriptùúã1subscriptùëÄùë°ùëü‚ÜíŒì‚Üí11\to\pi_{1}(M)\to\pi_{1}(M_{t};r)\to\Gamma\to 1.

Since ŒìŒì\Gamma acts isometrically on MùëÄM, the conjugation action œÄ1‚Äã(Mt;r)‚ÜíŒì‚ÜíOut‚Å°(œÄ1‚Äã(M))‚Üísubscriptùúã1subscriptùëÄùë°ùëüŒì‚ÜíOutsubscriptùúã1ùëÄ\pi_{1}(M_{t};r)\to\Gamma\to\operatorname{Out}(\pi_{1}(M)) has finite image. Let ŒîŒî\Delta be the kernel, so ŒîŒî\Delta is of finite index in œÄ1‚Äã(Mt;r)subscriptùúã1subscriptùëÄùë°ùëü\pi_{1}(M_{t};r) and centralizes Aùê¥A. Let Œõ‚Ä≤:=QŒõ‚Äã(Œ¶‚Äã(Œî))assignsuperscriptŒõ‚Ä≤subscriptùëÑŒõŒ¶Œî\Lambda^{\prime}:=Q_{\Lambda}(\Phi(\Delta)) be the image of ŒîŒî\Delta in ŒõŒõ\Lambda and write B:=a‚Äã(A)assignùêµùëéùê¥B:=a(A). So Œõ‚Ä≤superscriptŒõ‚Ä≤\Lambda^{\prime} is a finite-index subgroup of ŒõŒõ\Lambda that centralizes BùêµB.

In order to show aùëéa has finite image, it suffices to show BùêµB is finite (since Aùê¥A is of finite index in œÄ1‚Äã(M)subscriptùúã1ùëÄ\pi_{1}(M)). To see this, we claim that a finite-index subgroup of BùêµB is a (necessarily abelian) factor of a finite-index subgroup of Œõ‚Ä≤superscriptŒõ‚Ä≤\Lambda^{\prime}. Since no finite-index subgroup of ŒõŒõ\Lambda has an abelian factor, it follows that BùêµB must have been finite. To produce this factor of Œõ‚Ä≤superscriptŒõ‚Ä≤\Lambda^{\prime}, it suffices to find a projection of a finite-index subgroup of Œõ‚Ä≤superscriptŒõ‚Ä≤\Lambda^{\prime} onto a finite-index subgroup of BùêµB.

To find this projection, consider the closure B¬Ø¬Øùêµ\overline{B} of BùêµB in Isom(N)ùëÅ(N). If BùêµB is infinite, then B¬Ø¬Øùêµ\overline{B} has nontrivial connected component B¬Ø0superscript¬Øùêµ0\overline{B}^{0}. Further B¬Ø0superscript¬Øùêµ0\overline{B}^{0} is central in the compact Lie group Œõ‚Ä≤¬Ø0superscript¬ØsuperscriptŒõ‚Ä≤0\overline{\Lambda^{\prime}}^{0}. Hence B¬Ø0superscript¬Øùêµ0\overline{B}^{0} is a local torus factor of Œõ‚Ä≤¬Ø0superscript¬ØsuperscriptŒõ‚Ä≤0\overline{\Lambda^{\prime}}^{0}. Write œÄ:Œõ‚Ä≤¬Ø0‚ÜíB¬Ø0/F:ùúã‚Üísuperscript¬ØsuperscriptŒõ‚Ä≤0superscript¬Øùêµ0ùêπ\pi:\overline{\Lambda^{\prime}}^{0}\to\overline{B}^{0}/F (where FùêπF is a finite group) for the projection to this torus factor, and write T:=B¬Ø0/Fassignùëásuperscript¬Øùêµ0ùêπT:=\overline{B}^{0}/F for the quotient.

Then œÄ‚Äã(Œõ‚Ä≤)ùúãsuperscriptŒõ‚Ä≤\pi(\Lambda^{\prime}) is a finitely generated abelian subgroup of TùëáT containing the image B/(B‚à©F)ùêµùêµùêπB/(B\cap F) of BùêµB, which is also finitely generated and abelian. There is a finite-index subgroup B‚Ä≤superscriptùêµ‚Ä≤B^{\prime} of BùêµB that intersects FùêπF trivially and hence projects isomorphically to B/(B‚à©F)ùêµùêµùêπB/(B\cap F). Therefore the following fact finishes the proof:

Fact. Let A1subscriptùê¥1A_{1} be a finitely generated abelian group with a subgroup A2subscriptùê¥2A_{2}. Then some finite-index subgroup of A2subscriptùê¥2A_{2} is a factor of some finite-index subgroup of A1subscriptùê¥1A_{1}. ‚àé

Vanishing of aùëéa has the following immediate consequence:

Construction 4.8.

The map Œ¶:Œì~‚ÜíŒõ~:Œ¶‚Üí~Œì~Œõ\Phi:\widetilde{\Gamma}\to\widetilde{\Lambda} induced by fùëìf on coarse fundamental groups restricts to an isomorphism Œ¶|œÄ1‚Äã(M):œÄ1‚Äã(M)‚ÜíœÄ1‚Äã(N):evaluated-atŒ¶subscriptùúã1ùëÄ‚Üísubscriptùúã1ùëÄsubscriptùúã1ùëÅ\Phi|_{\pi_{1}(M)}:\pi_{1}(M)\to\pi_{1}(N) and hence descends to an isomorphism œÜ:Œì‚ÜíŒõ:ùúë‚ÜíŒìŒõ\varphi:\Gamma\to\Lambda.

5. Stabilization of maps on coarse fundamental groups

At this point we are able to state the full version of Theorem 1.5, which requires some technical assumptions.

Theorem 5.1.

Let ŒìŒì\Gamma and ŒõŒõ\Lambda be finitely presented groups acting isometrically, freely and minimally on compact manifolds MùëÄM and NùëÅN (respectively). Assume

  1. (i)

    neither of ŒìŒì\Gamma and ŒõŒõ\Lambda is commensurable to a group with a nontrivial free abelian factor,

  2. (ii)

    there exist uniform quasi-isometries fn:Mtn‚ÜíNsn:subscriptùëìùëõ‚ÜísubscriptùëÄsubscriptùë°ùëõsubscriptùëÅsubscriptùë†ùëõf_{n}:M_{t_{n}}\to N_{s_{n}} for two sequences tn,sn‚Üí‚àû‚Üísubscriptùë°ùëõsubscriptùë†ùëõt_{n},s_{n}\to\infty , and

  3. (iii)

    letting œÜn:Œì‚ÜíŒõ:subscriptùúëùëõ‚ÜíŒìŒõ\varphi_{n}:\Gamma\to\Lambda be the isomorphisms defined in Construction 4.8, assume these stabilize up to conjugacy along a subsequence.

Then there is an affine commensuration of the action of ŒìŒì\Gamma on MùëÄM and the action of ŒõŒõ\Lambda on NùëÅN.

In general, the sequences {tn}nsubscriptsubscriptùë°ùëõùëõ\{t_{n}\}_{n} and {sn}nsubscriptsubscriptùë†ùëõùëõ\{s_{n}\}_{n} could be extremely sparse, and hence without the coarse homotopical stabilization hypothesis (iii), there is no relationship between the maps fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n}. Of course, if the maps fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n} are all induced by a single quasi-isometry f:ùí¢‚Äã(Œì‚Ü∑M)‚Üíùí¢‚Äã(Œõ‚Ü∑N):ùëì‚Üíùí¢‚Ü∑ŒìMùí¢‚Ü∑ŒõNf:\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)}\to\operatorname{\mathscr{G}(\Lambda\curvearrowright N)} of the geometric cones, then there is an extremely close connection between the different fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n} (although they are only uniformly coarsely Lipschitz, see Lemma 2.4), and we will show this indeed implies that the maps œÜnsubscriptùúëùëõ\varphi_{n} stabilize in this case (see Section 5.6 below). After establishing this stabilization phenomenon, the proofs of Theorem 1.4, which shows affine commensurability of actions with quasi-isometric geometric cones, and Theorem 5.1, which shows affine commensurability only assuming quasi-isometric sequences of level sets but under the additional coarse stabilization hypothesis 5.1(iii), will proceed completely parallel to each other (see Sections 7 and 8).

In the next subsection, we will show that if ŒìŒì\Gamma has Property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL}, then a sequence of uniform quasi-isometries satisfies the coarse stabilization hypothesis 5.1(iii). Therefore Theorem 1.5, obtaining affine commensurability for assuming quasi-isometric sequences of level sets under the additional assumption of Property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL}, is a direct consequence of Theorem 5.1 and the results of the next subsection.

Theorem 1.4, which assumes quasi-isometric geometric cones, does not follow from Theorem 5.1, because quasi-isometries of geometric cones do not yield uniform quasi-isometries of level sets, but only uniformly coarsely Lipschitz maps as described in Lemma 2.4. It turns out that condition suffices to construct the conjugacy in both Theorem 1.4 and 5.1 and we carry this out in Section 7 and 8.

On the other hand, for the study of the geometry of expanders, and in particular for the proof of Theorems 1.7 and 1.8, we need to control the behavior of subsequences of level sets of warped cones, which could be very sparse. Hence for these results Theorem 1.4 does not suffice, and one needs Theorem 1.5 and therefore Theorem 5.1 and the results of the next few sections.

In this section, we will prove that in many cases, the stabilization hypothesis (iii) is satisfied. In addition to the setting of the geometric cone discussed above, we will consider several easily checked group-theoretic assumptions on ŒìŒì\Gamma and ŒõŒõ\Lambda that imply stabilization. We introduce an abstract property of a finitely generated group which we call FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL} which implies stabilization and provide many examples of groups satisfying FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL}. We make no attempt to be exhaustive and simply prove FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL} in several cases related to applications. The following groups have FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL}:

  1. (1)

    Any ŒìŒì\Gamma with Out‚Å°(Œì)OutŒì\operatorname{Out}(\Gamma) finite.

  2. (2)

    Surface groups.

  3. (3)

    Free groups.

  4. (4)

    Certain free products.

  5. (5)

    Certain direct products.

We will use the first or third, and fifth criterion in the proof of Theorem 1.7 and the first and fifth in the proof of Theorem 1.8. We believe one can give slightly different proofs of those theorems using the fourth condition in place of the fifith, but as the proof using the fifth is shorter, we only include it here. Since we are willing to pass to subsequences, stabilization is trivial in the first case and we will not comment on it further. Property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL} is really only needed to check (‚Äã2‚Äã)‚àí(‚Äã5‚Äã)italic-(2italic-)italic-(5italic-)\eqref{item:surface}-\eqref{item:direct_prod}.

5.1. Uniform bounds on stable norms

Recall the definition of stable norm in a group:

Definition 5.2.

Let ŒìŒì\Gamma be a finitely generated group, equipped with a word metric with respect to a finite symmetric generating set SùëÜS. Then for any Œ≥‚ààŒìùõæŒì\gamma\in\Gamma, the stable norm of Œ≥ùõæ\gamma is

‚ÄñŒ≥‚Äñ‚àû:=limn‚Üí‚àû‚ÄñŒ≥n‚Äñn.assignsubscriptnormùõæsubscript‚Üíùëõnormsuperscriptùõæùëõùëõ\|\gamma\|_{\infty}:=\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac{\|\gamma^{n}\|}{n}.
Remark 5.3.

Because of submultiplicativity, the stable norm is well-defined and finite (in fact bounded by ‚ÄñŒ≥‚Äñnormùõæ\|\gamma\|).

Remark 5.4.

Stable norm is conjugation invariant.

The remarks leads us to consider the following sets of automorphisms of ŒìŒì\Gamma. For any D>0ùê∑0D>0 define the set ùíüùíü\mathcal{D} of automorphisms œàùúì\psi of ŒìŒì\Gamma which satisfy

‚Äñœà‚Äã(Œ≥)‚Äñ‚àû‚â§D‚Äã‚ÄñŒ≥‚Äñ‚àûsubscriptnormùúìùõæùê∑subscriptnormùõæ\|\psi(\gamma)\|_{\infty}\leq D\|\gamma\|_{\infty}

for every Œ≥ùõæ\gamma in ŒìŒì\Gamma. Since conjugation preserves stable norm, ùíüùíü\mathcal{D} is a union of fibers of the map Aut‚Å°(Œì)‚ÜíOut‚Å°(Œì)‚ÜíAutŒìOutŒì\operatorname{Aut}(\Gamma)\rightarrow\operatorname{Out}(\Gamma) and it is more natural to consider the projection of ùíüùíü\mathcal{D} to Out‚Å°(Œì)OutŒì\operatorname{Out}(\Gamma). We refer to ùíüùíü\mathcal{D} as the set of automorphisms which are Dùê∑D‚ÄìLipschitz for the stable norm.

Definition 5.5.

We say ŒìŒì\Gamma has FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL} if the projection of ùíüùíü\mathcal{D} to Out‚Å°(Œì)OutŒì\operatorname{Out}(\Gamma) is finite for all D>1ùê∑1D>1.

We assume the setting of Theorem 5.1. The following proposition relates FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL} to the problem of stabilization.

Proposition 5.6.

For any Œ≥‚ààŒìùõæŒì\gamma\in\Gamma, we have

‚ÄñœÜn‚Äã(Œ≥)‚Äñ‚àû‚â§(L+2)‚Äã‚ÄñŒ≥‚Äñ‚àû.subscriptnormsubscriptùúëùëõùõæùêø2subscriptnormùõæ\|\varphi_{n}(\gamma)\|_{\infty}\leq(L+2)\|\gamma\|_{\infty}.
Proof.

Let Œ≥‚ààŒìùõæŒì\gamma\in\Gamma. The shortest loop in MtnsubscriptùëÄsubscriptùë°ùëõM_{t_{n}} representing Œ≥‚ààœÄ1‚Äã(Mtn,p0;r)ùõæsubscriptùúã1subscriptùëÄsubscriptùë°ùëõsubscriptùëù0ùëü\gamma\in\pi_{1}(M_{t_{n}},p_{0};r) has length ‚ÄñŒ≥‚Äñ+tn‚ÄãdM‚Äã(p0,Œ≥‚Äãp0)normùõæsubscriptùë°ùëõsubscriptùëëùëÄsubscriptùëù0ùõæsubscriptùëù0\|\gamma\|+t_{n}d_{M}(p_{0},\gamma p_{0}) for tnsubscriptùë°ùëõt_{n} large enough. Consider the image under fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n} of any such loop. Of course, it represents œÜn‚Äã(Œ≥)‚ààœÄ1‚Äã(Nsn,fn‚Äã(p0);L‚Äãr+C)subscriptùúëùëõùõæsubscriptùúã1subscriptùëÅsubscriptùë†ùëõsubscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëù0ùêøùëüùê∂\varphi_{n}(\gamma)\in\pi_{1}(N_{s_{n}},f_{n}(p_{0});Lr+C) and hence has length at least ‚ÄñœÜn‚Äã(Œ≥)‚Äñ+sn‚ÄãdN‚Äã(fn‚Äã(p0),œÜn‚Äã(Œ≥)‚Äãfn‚Äã(p0))normsubscriptùúëùëõùõæsubscriptùë†ùëõsubscriptùëëùëÅsubscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëù0subscriptùúëùëõùõæsubscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëù0\|\varphi_{n}(\gamma)\|+s_{n}d_{N}(f_{n}(p_{0}),\varphi_{n}(\gamma)f_{n}(p_{0})). On the other hand by the quasi-isometry property, and the fact that the original loop could be represented by roughly ‚ÄñŒ≥‚Äñr+tnr‚ÄãdM‚Äã(p0,Œ≥‚Äãp0)normùõæùëüsubscriptùë°ùëõùëüsubscriptùëëùëÄsubscriptùëù0ùõæsubscriptùëù0\frac{\|\gamma\|}{r}+\frac{t_{n}}{r}d_{M}(p_{0},\gamma p_{0}) points where under application by fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n}, each segment (of length roughly rùëür) gets stretched to a segment of length at most L‚Äãr+Cùêøùëüùê∂Lr+C, the image has length at most

(L‚Äãr+C)‚Äã(‚ÄñŒ≥‚Äñr+tnr‚ÄãdM‚Äã(p0,Œ≥‚Äãp0)).ùêøùëüùê∂normùõæùëüsubscriptùë°ùëõùëüsubscriptùëëùëÄsubscriptùëù0ùõæsubscriptùëù0(Lr+C)\left(\frac{\|\gamma\|}{r}+\frac{t_{n}}{r}d_{M}(p_{0},\gamma p_{0})\right).

Hence we conclude (for r‚â•Cùëüùê∂r\geq C, which we can assume), that

‚ÄñœÜn‚Äã(Œ≥)‚Äñ+sn‚ÄãdN‚Äã(fn‚Äã(p0),œÜn‚Äã(Œ≥)‚Äãfn‚Äã(p0))‚â§(L+1)‚Äã(‚ÄñŒ≥‚Äñ+tn‚ÄãdM‚Äã(p0,Œ≥‚Äãp0)).normsubscriptùúëùëõùõæsubscriptùë†ùëõsubscriptùëëùëÅsubscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëù0subscriptùúëùëõùõæsubscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëù0ùêø1normùõæsubscriptùë°ùëõsubscriptùëëùëÄsubscriptùëù0ùõæsubscriptùëù0\|\varphi_{n}(\gamma)\|+s_{n}d_{N}(f_{n}(p_{0}),\varphi_{n}(\gamma)f_{n}(p_{0}))\leq(L+1)\left(\|\gamma\|+t_{n}d_{M}(p_{0},\gamma p_{0})\right).

Now consider the above identity for Œ≥msuperscriptùõæùëö\gamma^{m} as m‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùëöm\to\infty. If Œ≥ùõæ\gamma has infinite order, then for m‚â´1much-greater-thanùëö1m\gg 1 we have ‚ÄñŒ≥m‚Äñ‚â•tn‚Äãdiam‚Å°(M)normsuperscriptùõæùëösubscriptùë°ùëõdiamùëÄ\|\gamma^{m}\|\geq t_{n}\operatorname{diam}(M), so

‚ÄñœÜn‚Äã(Œ≥m)‚Äñnormsubscriptùúëùëõsuperscriptùõæùëö\displaystyle\|\varphi_{n}(\gamma^{m})\| ‚â§‚ÄñœÜn‚Äã(Œ≥m)‚Äñ+sn‚ÄãdN‚Äã(fn‚Äã(p0),œÜn‚Äã(Œ≥m)‚Äãfn‚Äã(p0))absentnormsubscriptùúëùëõsuperscriptùõæùëösubscriptùë†ùëõsubscriptùëëùëÅsubscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëù0subscriptùúëùëõsuperscriptùõæùëösubscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëù0\displaystyle\leq\|\varphi_{n}(\gamma^{m})\|+s_{n}d_{N}(f_{n}(p_{0}),\varphi_{n}(\gamma^{m})f_{n}(p_{0}))
‚â§(L+1)‚Äã(‚ÄñŒ≥m‚Äñ+tn‚ÄãdM‚Äã(p0,Œ≥m‚Äãp0))absentùêø1normsuperscriptùõæùëösubscriptùë°ùëõsubscriptùëëùëÄsubscriptùëù0superscriptùõæùëösubscriptùëù0\displaystyle\leq(L+1)\left(\|\gamma^{m}\|+t_{n}d_{M}(p_{0},\gamma^{m}p_{0})\right)
‚â§(L+2)‚Äã‚ÄñŒ≥m‚Äñ.absentùêø2normsuperscriptùõæùëö\displaystyle\leq(L+2)\|\gamma^{m}\|.

Now divide by mùëöm on both sides and take the limit to get ‚ÄñœÜn‚Äã(Œ≥)‚Äñ‚àû‚â§(L+2)‚Äã‚ÄñŒ≥‚Äñ‚àûsubscriptnormsubscriptùúëùëõùõæùêø2subscriptnormùõæ\|\varphi_{n}(\gamma)\|_{\infty}\leq(L+2)\|\gamma\|_{\infty}, as desired.

The above applied for Œ≥ùõæ\gamma of infinite order. If Œ≥ùõæ\gamma has torsion, then so does œÜn‚Äã(Œ≥)subscriptùúëùëõùõæ\varphi_{n}(\gamma). Further the stable norm of torsion elements vanishes, so the desired bound is immediate. ‚àé

Retaining the terminology of Theorem 5.1, the following is now obvious.

Corollary 5.7.

If ŒìŒì\Gamma has FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL} then the maps œïnsubscriptitalic-œïùëõ\phi_{n} stabilize up to conjugacy on a subsequence.

5.2. Hyperbolic groups

In this subsection we prove:

Proposition 5.8.

Hyperbolic groups have Property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL}.

If stable norm is replaced with conjugacy length (i.e. the minimal word length of a conjugate), then this result is established for torsion-free hyperbolic groups in [Can, Proposition 2.3 ]. Throughout this subsection, we let ŒìŒì\Gamma be a hyperbolic group, generated by a finite set SùëÜS. We denote the Cayley graph of ŒìŒì\Gamma with respect to SùëÜS by Cay(Œì)Œì(\Gamma), and let Œ¥ùõø\delta be the hyperbolicity constant of Cay(Œì)Œì(\Gamma). We recall that in hyperbolic groups, stable norm essentially detects conjugacy classes:

Lemma 5.9 (see e.g. [BH, Proposition III.F.3.15]).

For every R>0ùëÖ0R>0, there are only finitely many conjugacy classes with stable norm bounded by RùëÖR. In fact, there is a constant C,D>0ùê∂ùê∑0C,D>0 depending only on Œ¥ùõø\delta such that if ‚ÄñŒ≥‚Äñ‚àû<RsubscriptnormùõæùëÖ\|\gamma\|_{\infty}<R then there is w‚ààŒìùë§Œìw\in\Gamma in the conjugacy class of Œ≥ùõæ\gamma with |w|<C‚ÄãR+Dùë§ùê∂ùëÖùê∑|w|<CR+D.

We now establish a basic fact about isometries of hyperbolic spaces: displacement of a point zùëßz under an isometry is relatively comparable to distance from zùëßz to a point with small displacement. This will be helpful in showing existence of fixed points for limit actions on trees.

Lemma 5.10.

Let s‚ààŒìùë†Œìs\in\Gamma and x,y‚ààCay‚Äã(Œì)ùë•ùë¶CayŒìx,y\in\text{Cay}(\Gamma) such that d‚Äã(x,s‚Äãx)<Cùëëùë•ùë†ùë•ùê∂d(x,sx)<C and d‚Äã(y,s‚Äãy)<dùëëùë¶ùë†ùë¶ùëëd(y,sy)<d for some constants d,C>Œ¥ùëëùê∂ùõød,C>\delta. Then there is a point zùëßz on a geodesic segment [x,y]ùë•ùë¶[x,y] which satisfies d‚Äã(z,s‚Äãz)<10‚ÄãCùëëùëßùë†ùëß10ùê∂d(z,sz)<10C and d‚Äã(y,z)<10‚Äãdùëëùë¶ùëß10ùëëd(y,z)<10d.

Proof.

If d‚Äã(x,y)‚â§4‚Äãmin‚Å°{d,C}ùëëùë•ùë¶4ùëëùê∂d(x,y)\leq 4\min\{d,C\} we can choose z:=xassignùëßùë•z:=x. Hence we assume that d‚Äã(x,y)>4‚Äãdùëëùë•ùë¶4ùëëd(x,y)>4d and d‚Äã(x,y)>4‚ÄãCùëëùë•ùë¶4ùê∂d(x,y)>4C. Pick z‚àà[x,y]ùëßùë•ùë¶z\in[x,y] such that d‚Äã(z,y)=2‚Äãdùëëùëßùë¶2ùëëd(z,y)=2d. Let w‚àà[x,s‚Äãy]ùë§ùë•ùë†ùë¶w\in[x,sy] such that d‚Äã(x,w)=d‚Äã(x,z)=d‚Äã(x,y)‚àí2‚Äãdùëëùë•ùë§ùëëùë•ùëßùëëùë•ùë¶2ùëëd(x,w)=d(x,z)=d(x,y)-2d. By Œ¥ùõø\delta-hyperbolicity, d‚Äã(z,w)<2‚ÄãŒ¥ùëëùëßùë§2ùõød(z,w)<2\delta. Let t‚àà[s‚Äãx,s‚Äãy]ùë°ùë†ùë•ùë†ùë¶t\in[sx,sy] such that

d‚Äã(s‚Äãy,t)=d‚Äã(s‚Äãy,w)ùëëùë†ùë¶ùë°ùëëùë†ùë¶ùë§\displaystyle d(sy,t)=d(sy,w) =d‚Äã(x,s‚Äãy)‚àí(d‚Äã(x,y)‚àí2‚Äãd)absentùëëùë•ùë†ùë¶ùëëùë•ùë¶2ùëë\displaystyle=d(x,sy)-(d(x,y)-2d)
=d‚Äã(x,s‚Äãy)‚àíd‚Äã(s‚Äãx,s‚Äãy)+2‚Äãd.absentùëëùë•ùë†ùë¶ùëëùë†ùë•ùë†ùë¶2ùëë\displaystyle=d(x,sy)-d(sx,sy)+2d.

By Œ¥ùõø\delta-hyperbolicity, d‚Äã(t,w)<2‚ÄãŒ¥ùëëùë°ùë§2ùõød(t,w)<2\delta. On the other hand, since s‚Äãz‚àà[s‚Äãx,s‚Äãy]ùë†ùëßùë†ùë•ùë†ùë¶sz\in[sx,sy] and d‚Äã(s‚Äãz,s‚Äãy)=2‚Äãdùëëùë†ùëßùë†ùë¶2ùëëd(sz,sy)=2d, we get d‚Äã(s‚Äãz,t)<|d‚Äã(x,s‚Äãy)‚àíd‚Äã(s‚Äãx,s‚Äãy)|‚â§Cùëëùë†ùëßùë°ùëëùë•ùë†ùë¶ùëëùë†ùë•ùë†ùë¶ùê∂d(sz,t)<|d(x,sy)-d(sx,sy)|\leq C. By the triangle inequality, we see d‚Äã(z,s‚Äãz)<4‚ÄãŒ¥+C<10‚ÄãCùëëùëßùë†ùëß4ùõøùê∂10ùê∂d(z,sz)<4\delta+C<10C. ‚àé

We also need the following lemma about isometric actions on trees. The proof can be found in Serre‚Äôs [Ser]. We note that Serre considers simplicial trees but the proof is valid for general ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R}-trees as well.

Lemma 5.11.

[Ser, Proposition 26, section I.6] Let ŒõŒõ\Lambda be a group acting on a tree TùëáT by isometries and let s1,s2‚ààŒõsubscriptùë†1subscriptùë†2Œõs_{1},s_{2}\in\Lambda be elements with fixed points. Let F‚Äãi‚Äãx‚Äã(s1)ùêπùëñùë•subscriptùë†1Fix(s_{1}) and F‚Äãi‚Äãx‚Äã(s2)ùêπùëñùë•subscriptùë†2Fix(s_{2}) be the fixed point sets of s1subscriptùë†1s_{1} and s2subscriptùë†2s_{2}. If F‚Äãi‚Äãx‚Äã(s1)‚à©F‚Äãi‚Äãx‚Äã(s2)=‚àÖùêπùëñùë•subscriptùë†1ùêπùëñùë•subscriptùë†2Fix(s_{1})\cap Fix(s_{2})=\varnothing then s1‚Äãs2subscriptùë†1subscriptùë†2s_{1}s_{2} does not have fixed point on TùëáT.

We will now prove that hyperbolic groups have Property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL}.

Proof of Proposition 5.8.

Let œÅn:Œì‚ÜíŒì:subscriptùúåùëõ‚ÜíŒìŒì\rho_{n}:\Gamma\to\Gamma be automorphisms that are Lipschitz with respect to stable norm. Consider the sequence of action of ŒìŒì\Gamma on Cay‚Äã(Œì)CayŒì\text{Cay}(\Gamma) obtained by precomposing the action with œÅnsubscriptùúåùëõ\rho_{n}. Define displacement functions dnsubscriptùëëùëõd_{n} by dn‚Äã(x)=maxs‚ààS‚Å°d‚Äã(œÅn‚Äã(s)‚Äãx,x)subscriptùëëùëõùë•subscriptùë†ùëÜùëësubscriptùúåùëõùë†ùë•ùë•d_{n}(x)=\max_{s\in S}d(\rho_{n}(s)x,x). Choose xn‚ààCay‚Äã(Œì)subscriptùë•ùëõCayŒìx_{n}\in\text{Cay}(\Gamma) that minimize dnsubscriptùëëùëõd_{n}.

We prove that dn‚Äã(xn)subscriptùëëùëõsubscriptùë•ùëõd_{n}(x_{n}) is uniformly bounded. Suppose for the sake of contradiction that dn‚Äã(xn)subscriptùëëùëõsubscriptùë•ùëõd_{n}(x_{n}) diverges. Consider the asymptotic cone of Cay‚Äã(Œì)CayŒì\text{Cay}(\Gamma) with respect to the basepoints (xn)nsubscriptsubscriptùë•ùëõùëõ(x_{n})_{n} and rescaling sequence (dn‚Äã(xn))nsubscriptsubscriptùëëùëõsubscriptùë•ùëõùëõ(d_{n}(x_{n}))_{n}. The limit is an ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R}-tree TùëáT and the action of ŒìŒì\Gamma on TùëáT does not have a global fixed point by our choice of scaling sequence and basepoints. On the other hand, by Lemma 5.9, for every s‚ààSùë†ùëÜs\in S, and n‚àà‚Ñïùëõ‚Ñïn\in\mathbb{N}, there exists wn‚ààCay‚Äã(Œì)subscriptùë§ùëõCayŒìw_{n}\in\text{Cay}(\Gamma) such that d‚Äã(œÅn‚Äã(s)‚Äãwn,wn)<Cùëësubscriptùúåùëõùë†subscriptùë§ùëõsubscriptùë§ùëõùê∂d(\rho_{n}(s)w_{n},w_{n})<C for some universal constant Cùê∂C because œÅnsubscriptùúåùëõ\rho_{n} is Lipschitz with respect to stable norm. By Lemma 5.10, there exists wn‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùë§ùëõ‚Ä≤w_{n}^{\prime} on the geodesic segment [wn,xn]subscriptùë§ùëõsubscriptùë•ùëõ[w_{n},x_{n}] such that d‚Äã(xn,wn‚Ä≤)<10‚Äãdn‚Äã(xn)ùëësubscriptùë•ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëõ‚Ä≤10subscriptùëëùëõsubscriptùë•ùëõd(x_{n},w_{n}^{\prime})<10d_{n}(x_{n}) and d‚Äã(wn‚Ä≤,œÅn‚Äã(s)‚Äãwn‚Ä≤)<10‚ÄãCùëësuperscriptsubscriptùë§ùëõ‚Ä≤subscriptùúåùëõùë†superscriptsubscriptùë§ùëõ‚Ä≤10ùê∂d(w_{n}^{\prime},\rho_{n}(s)w_{n}^{\prime})<10C. The sequence (wn‚Ä≤)superscriptsubscriptùë§ùëõ‚Ä≤(w_{n}^{\prime}) converges to a fixed point of sùë†s on TùëáT. Thus every element of SùëÜS acts with fixed point on TùëáT. Moreover, this argument also produces fixed points for the product of any pair of generators.

On the other hand, since ŒìŒì\Gamma acts on TùëáT without global fixed point, there exist s1,s2‚ààSsubscriptùë†1subscriptùë†2ùëÜs_{1},s_{2}\in S whose fixed point sets are disjoint. It follows from Lemma 5.11 that s1‚Äãs2subscriptùë†1subscriptùë†2s_{1}s_{2} does not have a fixed point on TùëáT, which is a contradiction. Therefore, there exist xn‚ààCay‚Äã(Œì)subscriptùë•ùëõCayŒìx_{n}\in\text{Cay}(\Gamma) such that dn‚Äã(xn)subscriptùëëùëõsubscriptùë•ùëõd_{n}(x_{n}) is uniformly bounded.

Now pick such a sequence (xn)subscriptùë•ùëõ(x_{n}). Then d‚Äã(xn‚àí1‚ÄãœÅn‚Äã(s)‚Äãxn,1)ùëësuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëõ1subscriptùúåùëõùë†subscriptùë•ùëõ1d(x_{n}^{-1}\rho_{n}(s)x_{n},1) is uniformly bounded for all s‚ààSùë†ùëÜs\in S and n‚àà‚Ñïùëõ‚Ñïn\in\mathbb{N}. Therefore the œÅnsubscriptùúåùëõ\rho_{n} are all conjugate to a finite collection of homomorphisms and so stabilize on a subsequence. ‚àé

5.3. Free groups

In this subsection we prove:

Proposition 5.12.

The free group FksubscriptùêπùëòF_{k} on kùëòk generators has Property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL}.

We note that free groups are hyperbolic so have property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL} from the results of the last subsection. We present here a more explicit proof, both because free groups are more essential for applications, and since the basic idea is applied to free products in the next subsection.

We start by recalling that in a free group, word length and stable word length are closely related via cyclically reduced words. Recall that a reduced word w=si1‚Äã‚ãØ‚Äãsikùë§subscriptùë†subscriptùëñ1‚ãØsubscriptùë†subscriptùëñùëòw=s_{i_{1}}\cdots s_{i_{k}} is cyclically reduced if sik‚â†si1‚àí1subscriptùë†subscriptùëñùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùë†subscriptùëñ11s_{i_{k}}\neq s_{i_{1}}^{-1}. This is to say that in w2superscriptùë§2w^{2} there is no cancellation between the last letter of the first copy of wùë§w and the first letter of the second copy of wùë§w.

Lemma 5.13.

Let wùë§w be a cyclically reduced word. Then ‚Äñw‚Äñ‚àû=‚Äñw‚Äñsubscriptnormùë§normùë§\|w\|_{\infty}=\|w\|.

Proof.

It is obvious that ‚Äñwn‚Äñ=n‚Äã‚Äñw‚Äñnormsuperscriptùë§ùëõùëõnormùë§\|w^{n}\|=n\|w\| if wùë§w is cyclically reduced. This immediately implies the claim.‚àé

Now we obtain stabilization for free groups:

Proof of Proposition 5.12.

Given an automorphism œÜùúë\varphi, change it by conjugation if necessary to ensure that ‚ÄñœÜ‚Äã(si)‚Äñnormùúësubscriptùë†ùëñ\|\varphi(s_{i})\| are minimal (in lexicographical ordering). We are not claiming such a representative is unique, merely take one. We assume œÜùúë\varphi is Dùê∑D‚ÄìLipschitz for the stable norm and give a uniform bound on ‚ÄñœÜ‚Äã(si)‚Äñnormùúësubscriptùë†ùëñ\|\varphi(s_{i})\|. This clearly shows ùíüùíü\mathcal{D} projects to a finite set in Out‚Å°(Fk)Outsubscriptùêπùëò\operatorname{Out}(F_{k}).

So let sùë†s be any generator. If œÜ‚Äã(s)ùúëùë†\varphi(s) is cyclically reduced, we have

‚ÄñœÜ‚Äã(s)‚Äñ=‚ÄñœÜ‚Äã(s)‚Äñ‚àû‚â§D.normùúëùë†subscriptnormùúëùë†ùê∑\|\varphi(s)\|=\|\varphi(s)\|_{\infty}\leq D.

If œÜ‚Äã(s)ùúëùë†\varphi(s) is not cyclically reduced, we can write (in reduced form)

œÜ‚Äã(s)=si‚Äãw‚Äãsi‚àí1ùúëùë†subscriptùë†ùëñùë§superscriptsubscriptùë†ùëñ1\varphi(s)=s_{i}ws_{i}^{-1}

for some iùëñi and word wùë§w that does not start with si‚àí1superscriptsubscriptùë†ùëñ1s_{i}^{-1} and does not end with sisubscriptùë†ùëñs_{i}. Now there is some jùëój such that œÜ‚Äã(sj)ùúësubscriptùë†ùëó\varphi(s_{j}) does not start with sisubscriptùë†ùëñs_{i} and does not end with si‚àí1superscriptsubscriptùë†ùëñ1s_{i}^{-1}.

Indeed, if for every jùëój, we would have that œÜ‚Äã(sj)ùúësubscriptùë†ùëó\varphi(s_{j}) either started with sisubscriptùë†ùëñs_{i} or ended with si‚àí1superscriptsubscriptùë†ùëñ1s_{i}^{-1}, then consider œà:=si‚àí1‚ÄãœÜ‚Äãsiassignùúìsuperscriptsubscriptùë†ùëñ1ùúësubscriptùë†ùëñ\psi:=s_{i}^{-1}\varphi s_{i}. We have, for every jùëój:

‚Äñœà‚Äã(sj)‚Äñ‚â§‚ÄñœÜ‚Äã(sj)‚Äñnormùúìsubscriptùë†ùëónormùúësubscriptùë†ùëó\|\psi(s_{j})\|\leq\|\varphi(s_{j})\|

and further ‚Äñœà‚Äã(s)‚Äñ<‚ÄñœÜ‚Äã(s)‚Äñnormùúìùë†normùúëùë†\|\psi(s)\|<\|\varphi(s)\|. This contradicts minimality of œÜùúë\varphi.

Hence we can choose jùëój such that œÜ‚Äã(sj)ùúësubscriptùë†ùëó\varphi(s_{j}) does not start with sisubscriptùë†ùëñs_{i} and does not end with si‚àí1superscriptsubscriptùë†ùëñ1s_{i}^{-1}. Then œÜ‚Äã(s)‚ÄãœÜ‚Äã(sj)ùúëùë†ùúësubscriptùë†ùëó\varphi(s)\varphi(s_{j}) is cyclically reduced and hence

‚ÄñœÜ‚Äã(s)‚Äñ‚â§‚ÄñœÜ‚Äã(s)‚ÄãœÜ‚Äã(sj)‚Äñnormùúëùë†normùúëùë†ùúësubscriptùë†ùëó\displaystyle\|\varphi(s)\|\leq\|\varphi(s)\varphi(s_{j})\| =‚ÄñœÜ‚Äã(s)‚ÄãœÜ‚Äã(sj)‚Äñ‚àûabsentsubscriptnormùúëùë†ùúësubscriptùë†ùëó\displaystyle=\|\varphi(s)\varphi(s_{j})\|_{\infty}
‚â§D‚Äã‚Äñs‚Äãsj‚Äñ‚àûabsentùê∑subscriptnormùë†subscriptùë†ùëó\displaystyle\leq D\|ss_{j}\|_{\infty}
‚â§2‚ÄãD.absent2ùê∑\displaystyle\leq 2D.

‚àé

5.4. Free products

In this subsection we show that taking free products with ‚Ñ§‚Ñ§\mathbb{Z} preserves FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL} for co-Hopfian groups ŒîŒî\Delta. It is most likely the case that other hypotheses on ŒîŒî\Delta suffice as well. Our motivation for considering co-Hopfian groups is that higher rank lattices, and particularly all groups known to have strong property (T)ùëá(T), are co-Hopfian.

Proposition 5.14.

Let ŒîŒî\Delta be a finitely generated co-Hopfian group without a free cyclic factor. Set Œì=Œî‚àó‚Ñ§Œì‚àóŒî‚Ñ§\Gamma=\Delta\ast\mathbb{Z}. Then ŒìŒì\Gamma has FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL}.

Recall that a group Gùê∫G is co-Hopfian if whenever H‚äÜGùêªùê∫H\subseteq G is a subgroup with H‚âÖGùêªùê∫H\cong G, then H=Gùêªùê∫H=G.

Proof.

Again fix an automorphism œÜùúë\varphi of ŒìŒì\Gamma and assume œÜùúë\varphi is Dùê∑D‚ÄìLipschitz for the stable norm. Again we will, after correcting by œÜùúë\varphi by conjugation, bound the word length of images of generators under œÜùúë\varphi. This suffices to see the projection of ùíüùíü\mathcal{D} to Out‚Å°(Œì)OutŒì\operatorname{Out}(\Gamma) is finite. Let tùë°t be the generator of the free cyclic factor and consider a generating set S=SŒî‚à™{t,t‚àí1}ùëÜsubscriptùëÜŒîùë°superscriptùë°1S=S_{\Delta}\cup\{t,t^{-1}\} where SŒîsubscriptùëÜŒîS_{\Delta} is a symmetric generating set for ŒîŒî\Delta. First note that because ŒîŒî\Delta has no free cyclic factor, by the Kurosh subgroup theorem, we can conjugate œÜùúë\varphi so that œÜ‚Äã(Œî)‚äÜŒîùúëŒîŒî\varphi(\Delta)\subseteq\Delta. Since ŒîŒî\Delta is co-Hopfian, it follows that œÜ‚Äã(Œî)=ŒîùúëŒîŒî\varphi(\Delta)=\Delta.

Claim 5.15.

If œÜ:Œî‚àó‚Ñ§‚ÜíŒî‚àó‚Ñ§:ùúë‚Üí‚àóŒî‚Ñ§‚àóŒî‚Ñ§\varphi:\Delta\ast\mathbb{Z}\to\Delta\ast\mathbb{Z} is an automorphism such that œÜ‚Äã(Œî)=ŒîùúëŒîŒî\varphi(\Delta)=\Delta then there are Œ¥1,Œ¥2‚ààŒîsubscriptùõø1subscriptùõø2Œî\delta_{1},\delta_{2}\in\Delta such that œÜ‚Äã(t)=Œ¥1‚Äãt¬±1‚ÄãŒ¥2ùúëùë°subscriptùõø1superscriptùë°plus-or-minus1subscriptùõø2\varphi(t)=\delta_{1}t^{\pm 1}\delta_{2}.

Proof.

We note that for an automorphism œÜùúë\varphi satisfying œÜ‚Äã(Œî)=ŒîùúëŒîŒî\varphi(\Delta)=\Delta and Œ¥1‚ààŒîsubscriptùõø1Œî\delta_{1}\in\Delta, then œÜ1:Œî‚àó‚Ñ§‚ÜíŒî‚àó‚Ñ§:subscriptùúë1‚Üí‚àóŒî‚Ñ§‚àóŒî‚Ñ§\varphi_{1}:\Delta\ast\mathbb{Z}\to\Delta\ast\mathbb{Z} defined by œÜ1‚Äã(Œ¥)=œÜ‚Äã(Œ¥)subscriptùúë1ùõøùúëùõø\varphi_{1}(\delta)=\varphi(\delta) for all Œ¥‚ààŒîùõøŒî\delta\in\Delta, and œÜ1‚Äã(t)=Œ¥1‚ÄãœÜ‚Äã(t)subscriptùúë1ùë°subscriptùõø1ùúëùë°\varphi_{1}(t)=\delta_{1}\varphi(t) is also an automorphism of Œî‚àó‚Ñ§‚àóŒî‚Ñ§\Delta\ast\mathbb{Z} satisfying œÜ1‚Äã(Œî)=Œîsubscriptùúë1ŒîŒî\varphi_{1}(\Delta)=\Delta. Similarly for œÜ2subscriptùúë2\varphi_{2} defined by œÜ2|Œî=œÜ|Œîevaluated-atsubscriptùúë2Œîevaluated-atùúëŒî\varphi_{2}|_{\Delta}=\varphi|_{\Delta} and œÜ2‚Äã(t)=œÜ‚Äã(t)‚ÄãŒ¥2subscriptùúë2ùë°ùúëùë°subscriptùõø2\varphi_{2}(t)=\varphi(t)\delta_{2} for some Œ¥2‚ààŒîsubscriptùõø2Œî\delta_{2}\in\Delta. Therefore, we can assume that œÜ‚Äã(t)ùúëùë°\varphi(t) is of the form tk‚Äãw‚Äãtlsuperscriptùë°ùëòùë§superscriptùë°ùëôt^{k}wt^{l} where wùë§w is an element in Œî‚àó‚Ñ§‚àóŒî‚Ñ§\Delta\ast\mathbb{Z} which does not start and end by nonzero powers of tùë°t. If k+l=0ùëòùëô0k+l=0, then the image of any word containing t¬±1superscriptùë°plus-or-minus1t^{\pm 1} contains both tksuperscriptùë°ùëòt^{k} and t‚àíksuperscriptùë°ùëòt^{-k} in its reduced word representation. In particular, tùë°t cannot be generated from œÜ‚Äã(Œî‚àó‚Ñ§)ùúë‚àóŒî‚Ñ§\varphi(\Delta\ast\mathbb{Z}). Thus, k+l‚â†0ùëòùëô0k+l\neq 0.

We show that w=1ùë§1w=1 and k+l=¬±1ùëòùëôplus-or-minus1k+l=\pm 1. Indeed, since k+l‚â†0ùëòùëô0k+l\neq 0, wùë§w cannot be canceled out in image of any reduced word containing tùë°t in Œî‚àó‚Ñ§‚àóŒî‚Ñ§\Delta\ast\mathbb{Z}. In particular, tùë°t cannot be generated from image of œÜ‚Äã(Œî‚àó‚Ñ§)ùúë‚àóŒî‚Ñ§\varphi(\Delta\ast\mathbb{Z}), a contradiction. Thus, w=1ùë§1w=1, and it follows that k+l=¬±1ùëòùëôplus-or-minus1k+l=\pm 1.‚àé

By Claim 5.15, we now conjugate œÜùúë\varphi by elements of ŒîŒî\Delta and assume that œÜ‚Äã(Œî)=ŒîùúëŒîŒî\varphi(\Delta)=\Delta and œÜ‚Äã(t)=t¬±1‚ÄãŒ¥ùúëùë°superscriptùë°plus-or-minus1ùõø\varphi(t)=t^{\pm 1}\delta, for some Œ¥‚ààŒîùõøŒî\delta\in\Delta. Since ‚ÄñœÜ‚Äã(t)‚Äñ‚àû=1+‚ÄñŒ¥‚Äñsubscriptnormùúëùë°1normùõø\|\varphi(t)\|_{\infty}=1+\|\delta\|, we get ‚ÄñŒ¥‚Äñ<Dnormùõøùê∑\|\delta\|<D. On the other hand, for s‚ààSŒîùë†subscriptùëÜŒîs\in S_{\Delta}, ‚ÄñœÜ‚Äã(t‚Äãs)‚Äñ‚àû=1+‚ÄñŒ¥‚ÄãœÜ‚Äã(s)‚Äñsubscriptnormùúëùë°ùë†1normùõøùúëùë†\|\varphi(ts)\|_{\infty}=1+\|\delta\varphi(s)\|. It follows that ‚ÄñŒ¥‚ÄãœÜ‚Äã(s)‚Äñnormùõøùúëùë†\|\delta\varphi(s)\| is uniformly bounded, hence so is ‚ÄñœÜ‚Äã(s)‚Äñnormùúëùë†\|\varphi(s)\|.‚àé

5.5. Direct products

Finally we record the case of products such that automorphisms preserve or interchange the factors, and each factor is of the above type. Mild conditions are required, which motivates:

Definition 5.16.

A group Gùê∫G is called highly non-commutative if for any nontrivial proper subgroup HùêªH, the group H‚ÄãZ‚Äã(H)ùêªùëçùêªHZ(H) is also proper where Z‚Äã(H)ùëçùêªZ(H) is the centralizer of HùêªH in Gùê∫G.

Free groups, hyperbolic groups and irreducible higher rank lattices are all easily to be highly non-commutative. The following is now quite easy

Proposition 5.17.

Let Œî1,‚Ä¶,ŒîksubscriptŒî1‚Ä¶subscriptŒîùëò\Delta_{1},\dots,\Delta_{k} be highly non-commutative groups with FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL}. Then Œì=‚àèiŒîiŒìsubscriptproductùëñsubscriptŒîùëñ\Gamma=\prod_{i}\Delta_{i} has F‚ÄãS‚ÄãLùêπùëÜùêøFSL.

The proof of the proposition is the following easy exercise: use that the ŒîisubscriptŒîùëñ\Delta_{i} are highly non-commutative to show that any automorphism of ŒìŒì\Gamma permutes the factors. We will only use the following special case.

Corollary 5.18.

Let G=‚àèIùîæi‚Äã(ki)ùê∫subscriptproductùêºsubscriptùîæùëñsubscriptùëòùëñG=\prod_{I}\mathbb{G}_{i}(k_{i}) where |I|<‚àûùêº|I|<\infty, each kisubscriptùëòùëñk_{i} is a local field and each ùîæ‚Äã(ki)ùîæsubscriptùëòùëñ\mathbb{G}(k_{i}) is a simple algebraic group defined over kisubscriptùëòùëñk_{i}. Let Œì<GŒìùê∫\Gamma<G be a lattice. Then ŒìŒì\Gamma has Property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL}.

Remark 5.19.

We will actually only need Corollary 5.18 in the special case where |I|=2ùêº2|I|=2, the lattice Œì=Œì1√óŒì2ŒìsubscriptŒì1subscriptŒì2\Gamma=\Gamma_{1}\times\Gamma_{2} is reducible and one factor Œì1subscriptŒì1\Gamma_{1} is a free group, viewed, for example, as a lattice in S‚ÄãL‚Äã(2,‚Ñù)ùëÜùêø2‚ÑùSL(2,\mathbb{R}) or S‚ÄãL‚Äã(2,‚Ñöp)ùëÜùêø2subscript‚ÑöùëùSL(2,\mathbb{Q}_{p}). To construct superexpanders, the other factor Œì2subscriptŒì2\Gamma_{2} will be a lattice in a higher rank simple pùëùp-adic Lie group. To construct expanders, the choice of the second factor will be almost arbitrary.

5.6. Geometric cone

Finally, we prove stabilization up to conjugacy in the setting of a quasi-isometry of geometric cones, i.e. in the setting of Theorem 1.4. This proof is unrelated to the last few sections and to property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL}.

Recall that for t>0ùë°0t>0, we have defined the maps

ft:Mt‚ÜíNt:subscriptùëìùë°‚ÜísubscriptùëÄùë°subscriptùëÅùë°f_{t}:M_{t}\to N_{t}

and found there is t0>0subscriptùë°00t_{0}>0 such that for any t‚â•t0ùë°subscriptùë°0t\geq t_{0}, the maps ftsubscriptùëìùë°f_{t} are uniformly coarsely Lipschitz (see Lemma 2.4). We obtain the following description for the induced maps Œ¶t:=ft‚Å£‚àóassignsubscriptŒ¶ùë°subscriptùëìùë°‚àó\Phi_{t}:=f_{t\ast} on coarse fundamental groups. Recall that the coarse fundamental group of a truncated cone is given by the group of lifts of the acting group (see Corollary 3.3). Therefore we can view Œ¶Œ¶\Phi and Œ¶tsubscriptŒ¶ùë°\Phi_{t} as maps Œì~‚ÜíŒõ~‚Üí~Œì~Œõ\widetilde{\Gamma}\to\widetilde{\Lambda}.

Proposition 5.20.

For t‚â´r‚â´1much-greater-thanùë°ùëümuch-greater-than1t\gg r\gg 1, we have Œ¶t=Œ¶subscriptŒ¶ùë°Œ¶\Phi_{t}=\Phi. In particular {œÜt}tsubscriptsubscriptùúëùë°ùë°\{\varphi_{t}\}_{t} stabilize.

Proof.

Recall that for t0>0subscriptùë°00t_{0}>0, we have the truncated geometric cone ùí¢t0‚Äã(Œì‚Ü∑M):=(M√ó[t0,‚àû)√óŒì)/Œìassignsubscriptùí¢subscriptt0‚Ü∑ŒìMùëÄsubscriptùë°0ŒìŒì\operatorname{\mathscr{G}_{t_{0}}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)}:=(M\times[t_{0},\infty)\times\Gamma)/\Gamma. By Corollary 3.3, for any t>t0‚â´r‚â´1ùë°subscriptùë°0much-greater-thanùëümuch-greater-than1t>t_{0}\gg r\gg 1, the inclusion map it:Mt‚Ü™ùí¢t0‚Äã(Œì‚Ü∑M):subscriptùëñùë°‚Ü™subscriptùëÄùë°subscriptùí¢subscriptt0‚Ü∑ŒìMi_{t}:M_{t}\hookrightarrow\operatorname{\mathscr{G}_{t_{0}}(\Gamma\curvearrowright M)} induces an isomorphism on coarse fundamental group. It follows immediately that œÜt:Œì‚ÜíŒõ:subscriptùúëùë°‚ÜíŒìŒõ\varphi_{t}:\Gamma\to\Lambda is given by the map œÜ:Œì‚ÜíŒõ:ùúë‚ÜíŒìŒõ\varphi:\Gamma\to\Lambda induced by fùëìf, and hence is independent of t>t0ùë°subscriptùë°0t>t_{0}. ‚àé

6. Identification of growth rate by quasi-isometry

We will now start the proof of the Main Theorem 5.1. Therefore we assume we have (L,C)ùêøùê∂(L,C)‚Äìquasi-isometries fn:Mtn‚ÜíNsn:subscriptùëìùëõ‚ÜísubscriptùëÄsubscriptùë°ùëõsubscriptùëÅsubscriptùë†ùëõf_{n}:M_{t_{n}}\to N_{s_{n}} such that the induced maps œÜn:Œì‚ÜíŒõ:subscriptùúëùëõ‚ÜíŒìŒõ\varphi_{n}:\Gamma\to\Lambda stabilize up to conjugation. In this section, we aim to prove tnsubscriptùë°ùëõt_{n} and snsubscriptùë†ùëõs_{n} grow at the same rate:

Proposition 6.1.

Assume the setting of Theorem 5.1. Then there exists K‚â•1ùêæ1K\geq 1 such that

1K‚â§sntn‚â§K.1ùêæsubscriptùë†ùëõsubscriptùë°ùëõùêæ\frac{1}{K}\leq\frac{s_{n}}{t_{n}}\leq K.
Proof.

It suffices to find an upper bound for sntnsubscriptùë†ùëõsubscriptùë°ùëõ\frac{s_{n}}{t_{n}}, since then a lower bound can be obtained by interchanging MùëÄM and NùëÅN. Fix basepoints p0‚ààMsubscriptùëù0ùëÄp_{0}\in M and q0‚ààNsubscriptùëû0ùëÅq_{0}\in N. By assumption, there are Œªn‚ààŒõsubscriptùúÜùëõŒõ\lambda_{n}\in\Lambda such that the morphisms

Œªn‚ÄãœÜn‚ÄãŒªn‚àí1:Œì‚ÜíŒõ:subscriptùúÜùëõsubscriptùúëùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëõ1‚ÜíŒìŒõ\lambda_{n}\varphi_{n}\lambda_{n}^{-1}:\Gamma\to\Lambda

lie in a finite set. Let œÜ^^ùúë\widehat{\varphi} be one of these morphisms and pass to the subsequence such that Œªn‚ÄãœÜn‚ÄãŒªn‚àí1=œÜ^subscriptùúÜùëõsubscriptùúëùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëõ1^ùúë\lambda_{n}\varphi_{n}\lambda_{n}^{-1}=\widehat{\varphi}. Now let Œ≥‚ààŒìùõæŒì\gamma\in\Gamma be a generator and consider the rùëür‚Äìloop

»∑~Œì‚Äã(Œ≥)=(p0,Œ≥‚Äãp0,p1,‚Ä¶,p‚Ñì,p0)subscript~italic-»∑Œìùõæsubscriptùëù0ùõæsubscriptùëù0subscriptùëù1‚Ä¶subscriptùëù‚Ñìsubscriptùëù0\widetilde{\jmath}_{\Gamma}(\gamma)=(p_{0},\gamma p_{0},p_{1},\dots,p_{\ell},p_{0})

where p1:=Œ≥‚Äãp0assignsubscriptùëù1ùõæsubscriptùëù0p_{1}:=\gamma p_{0} and (p1,‚Ä¶,p‚Ñì,p0)subscriptùëù1‚Ä¶subscriptùëù‚Ñìsubscriptùëù0(p_{1},\dots,p_{\ell},p_{0}) is a discretization on the scale rtnùëüsubscriptùë°ùëõ\frac{r}{t_{n}} of a minimizing geodesic from Œ≥‚Äãp0ùõæsubscriptùëù0\gamma p_{0} to p0subscriptùëù0p_{0} in MùëÄM, and such that dM‚Äã(pi,pi+1)=rtnsubscriptùëëùëÄsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëñ1ùëüsubscriptùë°ùëõd_{M}(p_{i},p_{i+1})=\frac{r}{t_{n}} for every 1‚â§i<‚Ñì1ùëñ‚Ñì1\leq i<\ell. In particular, we have

dM‚Äã(p0,Œ≥‚Äãp0)subscriptùëëùëÄsubscriptùëù0ùõæsubscriptùëù0\displaystyle d_{M}(p_{0},\gamma p_{0}) =dM‚Äã(p‚Ñì,p0)+‚àë1‚â§i<‚ÑìdM‚Äã(pi,pi+1)absentsubscriptùëëùëÄsubscriptùëù‚Ñìsubscriptùëù0subscript1ùëñ‚ÑìsubscriptùëëùëÄsubscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëùùëñ1\displaystyle=d_{M}(p_{\ell},p_{0})+\sum_{1\leq i<\ell}d_{M}(p_{i},p_{i+1})
‚â•(‚Ñì‚àí1)‚Äãrtn.absent‚Ñì1ùëüsubscriptùë°ùëõ\displaystyle\geq(\ell-1)\frac{r}{t_{n}}.

Let Dùê∑D be the maximal displacement of a point under Œ≥ùõæ\gamma. Rewriting the above inequality, we obtain

‚Ñì‚â§1+tn‚ÄãDr.‚Ñì1subscriptùë°ùëõùê∑ùëü\ell\leq 1+t_{n}\frac{D}{r}. (6.1)

Applying fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n} to »∑Œìsubscriptitalic-»∑Œì\jmath_{\Gamma} , we obtain a loop Œ≤‚ààœÄ1‚Äã(Nsn,fn‚Äã(p0);L‚Äãr+C)ùõΩsubscriptùúã1subscriptùëÅsubscriptùë†ùëõsubscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëù0ùêøùëüùê∂\beta\in\pi_{1}(N_{s_{n}},f_{n}(p_{0});Lr+C) with QŒõ‚Äã(Œ≤)=œÜn‚Äã(Œ≥)subscriptùëÑŒõùõΩsubscriptùúëùëõùõæQ_{\Lambda}(\beta)=\varphi_{n}(\gamma). Consider its canonical form (see Definition 3.10)

ùíû‚Äã(Œ≤)=ùí™‚Äã(Œ≤)‚àóùíÆ‚Äã(Œ≤).ùíûùõΩ‚àóùí™ùõΩùíÆùõΩ\mathcal{C}(\beta)=\mathcal{O}(\beta)\ast\mathcal{S}(\beta).

Since the spatial component ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ≤)ùíÆùõΩ\mathcal{S}(\beta) is a path from œÜn‚Äã(Œ≥)‚Äãfn‚Äã(p0)subscriptùúëùëõùõæsubscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëù0\varphi_{n}(\gamma)f_{n}(p_{0}) to p0subscriptùëù0p_{0}, its length is at least sn‚ÄãŒ¥subscriptùë†ùëõùõøs_{n}\delta, where Œ¥ùõø\delta is the minimal displacement of œÜn‚Äã(Œ≥)subscriptùúëùëõùõæ\varphi_{n}(\gamma). Note that œÜn‚Äã(Œ≥)subscriptùúëùëõùõæ\varphi_{n}(\gamma) is conjugate to œÜ^‚Äã(Œ≥)^ùúëùõæ\widehat{\varphi}(\gamma), so Œ¥ùõø\delta does not depend on nùëõn. Hence the (L‚Äãr+C)ùêøùëüùê∂(Lr+C)-path ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ≤)ùíÆùõΩ\mathcal{S}(\beta) consists of at least sn‚ÄãŒ¥L‚Äãr+Csubscriptùë†ùëõùõøùêøùëüùê∂\frac{s_{n}\delta}{Lr+C} points.

On the other hand, »∑Œì‚Äã(Œ≥)subscriptitalic-»∑Œìùõæ\jmath_{\Gamma}(\gamma) consists of ‚Ñì+3‚Ñì3\ell+3 points, so ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ≤)ùíÆùõΩ\mathcal{S}(\beta) consists of at most ‚Ñì+3‚Ñì3\ell+3 points. Combining these two bounds on the number of points of ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ≤)ùíÆùõΩ\mathcal{S}(\beta), and also using the bound on ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell from Equation (6.1), we obtain

sn‚ÄãŒ¥L‚Äãr+C‚â§‚Ñì+3‚â§4+tn‚ÄãDrsubscriptùë†ùëõùõøùêøùëüùê∂‚Ñì34subscriptùë°ùëõùê∑ùëü\frac{s_{n}\delta}{Lr+C}\leq\ell+3\leq 4+t_{n}\frac{D}{r}

and hence

sntn‚â§4‚Äã(L‚Äãr+C)tn+DŒ¥‚Äã(L+Cr)‚â§1+DŒ¥‚Äã(L+Cr),subscriptùë†ùëõsubscriptùë°ùëõ4ùêøùëüùê∂subscriptùë°ùëõùê∑ùõøùêøùê∂ùëü1ùê∑ùõøùêøùê∂ùëü\frac{s_{n}}{t_{n}}\leq\frac{4(Lr+C)}{t_{n}}+\frac{D}{\delta}\left(L+\frac{C}{r}\right)\leq 1+\frac{D}{\delta}\left(L+\frac{C}{r}\right),

(if tn‚â•4‚Äã(L‚Äãr+C)subscriptùë°ùëõ4ùêøùëüùê∂t_{n}\geq 4(Lr+C)). Note that there are only finitely many possibilities for Œ¥ùõø\delta, because there are only finitely many options for œÜ^^ùúë\widehat{\varphi}. Taking the maximum of 1+DŒ¥‚Äã(L+Cr)1ùê∑ùõøùêøùê∂ùëü1+\frac{D}{\delta}\left(L+\frac{C}{r}\right) over all these choices of œÜ^^ùúë\widehat{\varphi} yields the desired upper bound. ‚àé

7. Construction of a semiconjugacy

The goal of this section is to construct, under the assumptions of either Theorem 1.4 or Theorem 5.1, a semiconjugacy between the actions of ŒìŒì\Gamma on MùëÄM and ŒõŒõ\Lambda on NùëÅN. Recall that for t‚â´r‚â´1much-greater-thanùë°ùëümuch-greater-than1t\gg r\gg 1, we know that the coarse fundamental group of the level sets MtsubscriptùëÄùë°M_{t} (resp. NtsubscriptùëÅùë°N_{t}) is given by the group of lifts Œì~~Œì\widetilde{\Gamma} (resp. Œõ~~Œõ\widetilde{\Lambda}). By assumption, we have maps fn:Mtn‚ÜíNsn:subscriptùëìùëõ‚ÜísubscriptùëÄsubscriptùë°ùëõsubscriptùëÅsubscriptùë†ùëõf_{n}:M_{t_{n}}\to N_{s_{n}} that are uniformly coarsely Lipschitz (in the setting of Theorem 1.4) or even uniform quasi-isometries (in the setting of Theorem 5.1). In this section, we will only need the uniformly coarsely Lipschitz property.

Further fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n} induce morphisms on coarse fundamental group that descend to maps œÜn:Œì‚ÜíŒõ:subscriptùúëùëõ‚ÜíŒìŒõ\varphi_{n}:\Gamma\to\Lambda that stabilize up to conjugation to a map œÜ^:Œì‚ÜíŒõ:^ùúë‚ÜíŒìŒõ\widehat{\varphi}:\Gamma\to\Lambda. In case of the setting of Theorem 5.1, we know by the results of the previous section that tn‚âçsnasymptotically-equalssubscriptùë°ùëõsubscriptùë†ùëõt_{n}\asymp s_{n}. By modifying the quasi-isometry constants of fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n} a bounded amount, we can assume that tn=snsubscriptùë°ùëõsubscriptùë†ùëõt_{n}=s_{n}, which we will do for the rest of this section. We will refer to the coarse inverse of fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n} as gnsubscriptùëîùëõg_{n} and note that we all statements true of fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n} are true of gnsubscriptùëîùëõg_{n}. In this section we will prove:

Proposition 7.1.

Assume the setup of Theorem 1.4 or Theorem 5.1. Then there exists a œÜ^^ùúë\widehat{\varphi}-equivariant Lipschitz map f^:M‚ÜíN:^ùëì‚ÜíùëÄùëÅ\widehat{f}:M\to N. Moreover there is a Lipschitz map g^:N‚ÜíM:^ùëî‚ÜíùëÅùëÄ\widehat{g}:N\rightarrow M that we can construct to be œÜ^‚àí1\widehat{\varphi}{{}^{-1}}-equivariant so that the composition g^‚àòf^:M‚ÜíM:^ùëî^ùëì‚ÜíùëÄùëÄ\widehat{g}\circ\widehat{f}:M\rightarrow M is ŒìŒì\Gamma equivariant.

Note that we do not claim that f^^ùëì\widehat{f} is bi-Lipschitz. However, as noted by interchanging MùëÄM and NùëÅN, we also obtain an equivariant Lipschitz map N‚ÜíM‚ÜíùëÅùëÄN\to M. The real content of the last two sentences is that we can arrange for g^‚àòf^^ùëî^ùëì\widehat{g}\circ\widehat{f} to be equivariant for the fixed ŒìŒì\Gamma action and not equivariant up to some automorphism of ŒìŒì\Gamma. In the next section we will use this to show f^^ùëì\widehat{f} is not only invertible and bi-Lipschitz but also affine.

We provide a brief outline of the proof of Proposition 7.1. In Section 4 we showed that for n‚â´1much-greater-thanùëõ1n\gg 1, the maps fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n} respect the data of the extension

1‚ÜíœÄ1‚Äã(M)‚ÜíœÄ1‚Äã(Mtn;r)‚ÜíŒì.‚Üí1subscriptùúã1ùëÄ‚Üísubscriptùúã1subscriptùëÄsubscriptùë°ùëõùëü‚ÜíŒì1\to\pi_{1}(M)\to\pi_{1}(M_{t_{n}};r)\to\Gamma.

We use this to modify fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n} to maps f~nsubscript~ùëìùëõ\widetilde{f}_{n} that are approximately continuous on the scale rtnùëüsubscriptùë°ùëõ\frac{r}{t_{n}} (see Definition 7.2). More precisely, images under f~nsubscript~ùëìùëõ\widetilde{f}_{n} of points that are rtnùëüsubscriptùë°ùëõ\frac{r}{t_{n}} close in MùëÄM, are distance at most ‚àºrtnsimilar-toabsentùëüsubscriptùë°ùëõ\sim\frac{r}{t_{n}} apart (see Lemma 7.3). We modify these further to account for any inner automorphisms that are needed to obtain stabilization for œÜnsubscriptùúëùëõ\varphi_{n} (which are only assumed to stabilize up to conjugacy), which yields maps f^nsubscript^ùëìùëõ\widehat{f}_{n} that are still approximately continuous. The Arzel√†-Ascoli theorem allows us to take a limit of the maps f^nsubscript^ùëìùëõ\widehat{f}_{n} to obtain a continuous map f^^ùëì\widehat{f}. Finally we show this map is equivariant with respect to the stabilization œÜ^:Œì‚ÜíŒõ:^ùúë‚ÜíŒìŒõ\widehat{\varphi}:\Gamma\to\Lambda of the maps œÜnsubscriptùúëùëõ\varphi_{n}.

We will now start by adjusting the coarsely Lipschitz maps fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n} so that they are approximately continuous. Recall that for an rùëür-path Œ±ùõº\alpha in MùëÄM, we have defined QŒì‚Äã(Œ±)subscriptùëÑŒìùõºQ_{\Gamma}(\alpha) to be the product of the group elements that record local jumps along Œ±ùõº\alpha (see Definition 3.5).

Definition 7.2.

Let n‚â´1much-greater-thanùëõ1n\gg 1 such that QŒõsubscriptùëÑŒõQ_{\Lambda} is well-defined and let p0‚ààMsubscriptùëù0ùëÄp_{0}\in M. Define the global adjustment f~nsubscript~ùëìùëõ\widetilde{f}_{n} of fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n} based at p0subscriptùëù0p_{0} as follows: Let Œ±ùõº\alpha be a discretization at the scale rtnùëüsubscriptùë°ùëõ\frac{r}{t_{n}} of a path in MùëÄM from p0subscriptùëù0p_{0} to pùëùp. Then set

f~n‚Äã(p):=QŒõ‚Äã(fn‚àòŒ±)‚àí1‚Äãfn‚Äã(p).assignsubscript~ùëìùëõùëùsubscriptùëÑŒõsuperscriptsubscriptùëìùëõùõº1subscriptùëìùëõùëù\widetilde{f}_{n}(p):=Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\alpha)^{-1}f_{n}(p).

Now we can obtain the promised approximate continuity property of the global adjustment relative to the scale used. We start by showing that if two points in MùëÄM are nearby, their images under f~nsubscript~ùëìùëõ\widetilde{f}_{n} are close:

Lemma 7.3.

Assume that tn>2‚Äã(C+1)Œ¥Œõ‚Äã(2‚ÄãC)subscriptùë°ùëõ2ùê∂1subscriptùõøŒõ2ùê∂t_{n}>\frac{2(C+1)}{\delta_{\Lambda}(2C)}. Then for any x,y‚ààMùë•ùë¶ùëÄx,y\in M such that dM‚Äã(x,y)<1L‚ÄãtnsubscriptùëëùëÄùë•ùë¶1ùêøsubscriptùë°ùëõd_{M}(x,y)<\frac{1}{Lt_{n}}, we have

dN‚Äã(f~n‚Äã(x),f~n‚Äã(y))‚â§C+1tn.subscriptùëëùëÅsubscript~ùëìùëõùë•subscript~ùëìùëõùë¶ùê∂1subscriptùë°ùëõd_{N}(\widetilde{f}_{n}(x),\widetilde{f}_{n}(y))\leq\frac{C+1}{t_{n}}.
Proof.

Let Œ±ùõº\alpha be a discretization on the scale rtnùëüsubscriptùë°ùëõ\frac{r}{t_{n}} of a path in MùëÄM from p0subscriptùëù0p_{0} to xùë•x. Note that Œ±‚àó(y)‚àóùõºùë¶\alpha\ast(y) is an rùëür-path from p0subscriptùëù0p_{0} to yùë¶y, where we view (y)ùë¶(y) as a constant rùëür-path. Write Œ≥‚Äã(x,y):=QŒõ‚Äã(fn‚àò(x,y))assignùõæùë•ùë¶subscriptùëÑŒõsubscriptùëìùëõùë•ùë¶\gamma(x,y):=Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ(x,y)), where again (x,y)ùë•ùë¶(x,y) denotes an rùëür-path. Then we have

dN‚Äã(f~n‚Äã(x),f~n‚Äã(y))subscriptùëëùëÅsubscript~ùëìùëõùë•subscript~ùëìùëõùë¶\displaystyle d_{N}(\widetilde{f}_{n}(x),\widetilde{f}_{n}(y)) =dN‚Äã(QŒõ‚Äã(fn‚àòŒ±)‚àí1‚Äãfn‚Äã(x),QŒõ‚Äã(fn‚àò([Œ±],y))‚àí1‚Äãfn‚Äã(y))absentsubscriptùëëùëÅsubscriptùëÑŒõsuperscriptsubscriptùëìùëõùõº1subscriptùëìùëõùë•subscriptùëÑŒõsuperscriptsubscriptùëìùëõdelimited-[]ùõºùë¶1subscriptùëìùëõùë¶\displaystyle=d_{N}\left(Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\alpha)^{-1}f_{n}(x),Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ([\alpha],y))^{-1}f_{n}(y)\right)
=dN‚Äã(QŒõ‚Äã(fn‚àòŒ±)‚àí1‚Äãfn‚Äã(x),QŒõ‚Äã(fn‚àòŒ±)‚àí1‚ÄãŒ≥‚Äã(x,y)‚àí1‚Äãfn‚Äã(y))absentsubscriptùëëùëÅsubscriptùëÑŒõsuperscriptsubscriptùëìùëõùõº1subscriptùëìùëõùë•subscriptùëÑŒõsuperscriptsubscriptùëìùëõùõº1ùõæsuperscriptùë•ùë¶1subscriptùëìùëõùë¶\displaystyle=d_{N}\left(Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\alpha)^{-1}f_{n}(x),Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\alpha)^{-1}\gamma(x,y)^{-1}f_{n}(y)\right)
=dN‚Äã(fn‚Äã(x),Œ≥‚Äã(x,y)‚àí1‚Äãfn‚Äã(y))absentsubscriptùëëùëÅsubscriptùëìùëõùë•ùõæsuperscriptùë•ùë¶1subscriptùëìùëõùë¶\displaystyle=d_{N}\left(f_{n}(x),\gamma(x,y)^{-1}f_{n}(y)\right)
=dN‚Äã(Œ≥‚Äã(x,y)‚Äãfn‚Äã(x),fn‚Äã(y))absentsubscriptùëëùëÅùõæùë•ùë¶subscriptùëìùëõùë•subscriptùëìùëõùë¶\displaystyle=d_{N}(\gamma(x,y)f_{n}(x),f_{n}(y))
‚â§C+1tn.absentùê∂1subscriptùë°ùëõ\displaystyle\leq\frac{C+1}{t_{n}}.

This proves the lemma.‚àé

We globalize the local approximate continuity property of the previous lemma:

Lemma 7.4.

f~nsubscript~ùëìùëõ\widetilde{f}_{n} is (L‚Äã(C+1),C+1tn)ùêøùê∂1ùê∂1subscriptùë°ùëõ(L(C+1),\frac{C+1}{t_{n}})-coarsely Lipschitz as a map between the manifolds (with metrics dM,dNsubscriptùëëùëÄsubscriptùëëùëÅd_{M},d_{N}).

Proof.

Let p,q‚ààMùëùùëûùëÄp,q\in M. Let c:[0,D]‚ÜíM:ùëê‚Üí0ùê∑ùëÄc:[0,D]\to M be a distance-minimizing unit speed geodesic from pùëùp to qùëûq. We divide [0,D]0ùê∑[0,D] into segments of length 1L‚Äãtn1ùêøsubscriptùë°ùëõ\frac{1}{Lt_{n}}, i.e. set tj:=jL‚Äãtnassignsubscriptùë°ùëóùëóùêøsubscriptùë°ùëõt_{j}:=\frac{j}{Lt_{n}} with 0‚â§j‚â§‚Ñì0ùëó‚Ñì0\leq j\leq\ell where ‚Ñì=‚åäL‚ÄãD‚Äãtn‚åã‚Ñìùêøùê∑subscriptùë°ùëõ\ell=\lfloor LDt_{n}\rfloor. Set xj:=c‚Äã(tj)assignsubscriptùë•ùëóùëêsubscriptùë°ùëóx_{j}:=c(t_{j}). Then

dN‚Äã(f~n‚Äã(p),f~n‚Äã(q))‚â§‚àë0‚â§j<‚Ñì(dN‚Äã(f~n‚Äã(xj),f~n‚Äã(xj+1)))+dN‚Äã(f~n‚Äã(x‚Ñì),f~n‚Äã(q)).subscriptùëëùëÅsubscript~ùëìùëõùëùsubscript~ùëìùëõùëûsubscript0ùëó‚ÑìsubscriptùëëùëÅsubscript~ùëìùëõsubscriptùë•ùëósubscript~ùëìùëõsubscriptùë•ùëó1subscriptùëëùëÅsubscript~ùëìùëõsubscriptùë•‚Ñìsubscript~ùëìùëõùëûd_{N}(\widetilde{f}_{n}(p),\widetilde{f}_{n}(q))\leq\sum_{0\leq j<\ell}\left(d_{N}(\widetilde{f}_{n}(x_{j}),\widetilde{f}_{n}(x_{j+1}))\right)+d_{N}(\widetilde{f}_{n}(x_{\ell}),\widetilde{f}_{n}(q)). (7.1)

Since xj+1‚ààBM‚Äã(xj;1L‚Äãtn)subscriptùë•ùëó1subscriptùêµùëÄsubscriptùë•ùëó1ùêøsubscriptùë°ùëõx_{j+1}\in B_{M}(x_{j};\frac{1}{Lt_{n}}), by Lemma 7.3 we have

dN‚Äã(f~n‚Äã(xj),f~n‚Äã(xj+1))‚â§C+1tn.subscriptùëëùëÅsubscript~ùëìùëõsubscriptùë•ùëósubscript~ùëìùëõsubscriptùë•ùëó1ùê∂1subscriptùë°ùëõd_{N}(\widetilde{f}_{n}(x_{j}),\widetilde{f}_{n}(x_{j+1}))\leq\frac{C+1}{t_{n}}.

Similarly we have

dN‚Äã(f~n‚Äã(x‚Ñì),f~n‚Äã(q))‚â§C+1tn.subscriptùëëùëÅsubscript~ùëìùëõsubscriptùë•‚Ñìsubscript~ùëìùëõùëûùê∂1subscriptùë°ùëõd_{N}(\widetilde{f}_{n}(x_{\ell}),\widetilde{f}_{n}(q))\leq\frac{C+1}{t_{n}}.

Using these estimates for every term on the right-hand side of Equation (7.1), and also using ‚Ñì‚â§D‚ÄãL‚Äãtn‚Ñìùê∑ùêøsubscriptùë°ùëõ\ell\leq DLt_{n}, we obtain

dN‚Äã(f~n‚Äã(p),f~n‚Äã(q))subscriptùëëùëÅsubscript~ùëìùëõùëùsubscript~ùëìùëõùëû\displaystyle d_{N}(\widetilde{f}_{n}(p),\widetilde{f}_{n}(q)) ‚â§‚Ñì‚ÄãC+1tn+C+1tnabsent‚Ñìùê∂1subscriptùë°ùëõùê∂1subscriptùë°ùëõ\displaystyle\leq\ell\frac{C+1}{t_{n}}+\frac{C+1}{t_{n}}
‚â§L‚Äã(C+1)‚ÄãD+C+1tn,absentùêøùê∂1ùê∑ùê∂1subscriptùë°ùëõ\displaystyle\leq L(C+1)D+\frac{C+1}{t_{n}},

as desired. ‚àé

The maps f~nsubscript~ùëìùëõ\widetilde{f}_{n} are not very nicely related yet, because the maps œÜn:Œì‚ÜíŒõ:subscriptùúëùëõ‚ÜíŒìŒõ\varphi_{n}:\Gamma\to\Lambda do not coincide. However, by assumption œÜnsubscriptùúëùëõ\varphi_{n} stabilize up to conjugation, and we will use this to construct a better sequence of adjustments:

Construction 7.5.

Because œÜnsubscriptùúëùëõ\varphi_{n} stabilize up to conjugation, there exist Œªn‚ààŒõsubscriptùúÜùëõŒõ\lambda_{n}\in\Lambda such that {cŒªn‚àòœÜn}subscriptùëêsubscriptùúÜùëõsubscriptùúëùëõ\{c_{\lambda_{n}}\circ\varphi_{n}\} constitute a finite set of morphisms. Here cŒªnsubscriptùëêsubscriptùúÜùëõc_{\lambda_{n}} denotes conjugation by ŒªnsubscriptùúÜùëõ\lambda_{n}. After passing to a subsequence we can assume that œÜ^:=cŒªn‚àòœÜnassign^ùúësubscriptùëêsubscriptùúÜùëõsubscriptùúëùëõ\widehat{\varphi}:=c_{\lambda_{n}}\circ\varphi_{n} is independent of nùëõn. Also define f^n:M‚ÜíN:subscript^ùëìùëõ‚ÜíùëÄùëÅ\widehat{f}_{n}:M\to N by f^n‚Äã(p):=Œªn‚Äãf~n‚Äã(p)assignsubscript^ùëìùëõùëùsubscriptùúÜùëõsubscript~ùëìùëõùëù\widehat{f}_{n}(p):=\lambda_{n}\widetilde{f}_{n}(p).

Since ŒªnsubscriptùúÜùëõ\lambda_{n} acts isometrically on NùëÅN and f~nsubscript~ùëìùëõ\widetilde{f}_{n} are (L‚Äã(C+1),C+1tn)ùêøùê∂1ùê∂1subscriptùë°ùëõ(L(C+1),\frac{C+1}{t_{n}})-coarsely Lipschitz by Lemma 7.4, the new adjustments f^n:=Œªn‚Äãf~nassignsubscript^ùëìùëõsubscriptùúÜùëõsubscript~ùëìùëõ\widehat{f}_{n}:=\lambda_{n}\widetilde{f}_{n} are also (L‚Äã(C+1),C+1tn)ùêøùê∂1ùê∂1subscriptùë°ùëõ(L(C+1),\frac{C+1}{t_{n}})-coarsely Lipschitz. Note in particular that the multiplicative constants are uniformly bounded. Therefore if the additive constants all vanished, we could use the Arzel√†-Ascoli theorem to obtain a limit map (along a subsequence). Unfortunately the additive constants are in general nonzero ‚Äì however, they still tend to 0 as n‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùëõn\to\infty. This is enough to push through the proof of the Arzel√†-Ascoli theorem, and hence there is a subsequence such that

f^n‚Üíf^‚Üísubscript^ùëìùëõ^ùëì\widehat{f}_{n}\to\widehat{f}

uniformly. Further f^^ùëì\widehat{f} is L‚Äã(C+1)ùêøùê∂1L(C+1)-Lipschitz. The rest of the section is devoted to proving that f^^ùëì\widehat{f} is œÜ^^ùúë\widehat{\varphi}-equivariant, which completes the proof that f^^ùëì\widehat{f} is a semiconjugacy between Œì‚Ü∑M‚Ü∑ŒìùëÄ\Gamma\curvearrowright M and Œõ‚Ü∑N‚Ü∑ŒõùëÅ\Lambda\curvearrowright N. We start by showing that f~nsubscript~ùëìùëõ\widetilde{f}_{n} and f^nsubscript^ùëìùëõ\widehat{f}_{n} satisfy approximate equivariance properties on the orbit of the basepoint p0subscriptùëù0p_{0}:

Lemma 7.6.

Let Œ≥‚ààŒìùõæŒì\gamma\in\Gamma. Then for any n‚â•1ùëõ1n\geq 1, we have

(i)ùëñ\displaystyle(i)\qquad dN‚Äã(f~n‚Äã(Œ≥‚Äãp0),œÜn‚Äã(Œ≥)‚Äãf~n‚Äã(p0))‚â§(L+C)‚Äã‚ÄñŒ≥‚Äñtn,subscriptùëëùëÅsubscript~ùëìùëõùõæsubscriptùëù0subscriptùúëùëõùõæsubscript~ùëìùëõsubscriptùëù0ùêøùê∂normùõæsubscriptùë°ùëõ\displaystyle d_{N}\left(\widetilde{f}_{n}(\gamma p_{0}),\varphi_{n}(\gamma)\widetilde{f}_{n}(p_{0})\right)\leq\frac{(L+C)\|\gamma\|}{t_{n}},
(i‚Äãi)ùëñùëñ\displaystyle(ii)\qquad dN‚Äã(f^n‚Äã(Œ≥‚Äãp0),œÜ^‚Äã(Œ≥)‚Äãf^n‚Äã(p0))‚â§(L+C)‚Äã‚ÄñŒ≥‚Äñtn.subscriptùëëùëÅsubscript^ùëìùëõùõæsubscriptùëù0^ùúëùõæsubscript^ùëìùëõsubscriptùëù0ùêøùê∂normùõæsubscriptùë°ùëõ\displaystyle d_{N}\left(\widehat{f}_{n}(\gamma p_{0}),\widehat{\varphi}(\gamma)\widehat{f}_{n}(p_{0})\right)\enspace\leq\frac{(L+C)\|\gamma\|}{t_{n}}.
Proof.

We prove (i). We obtain two rùëür-paths Œ±ùõº\alpha and Œ≤ùõΩ\beta in MtnsubscriptùëÄsubscriptùë°ùëõM_{t_{n}} from p0subscriptùëù0p_{0} to Œ≥‚Äãp0ùõæsubscriptùëù0\gamma p_{0} as follows. Let Œ±ùõº\alpha be the discretization at the scale rtnùëüsubscriptùë°ùëõ\frac{r}{t_{n}} of a continuous path in MùëÄM from p0subscriptùëù0p_{0} to Œ≥‚Äãp0ùõæsubscriptùëù0\gamma p_{0}, and let Œ≤ùõΩ\beta be the shortest path in the ŒìŒì\Gamma‚Äìorbit of p0subscriptùëù0p_{0} obtained by writing Œ≥ùõæ\gamma as a word in the generators. As usual, Œ±¬Ø¬Øùõº\overline{\alpha} denotes the reverse of Œ±ùõº\alpha. The concatenation Œ≤‚àóŒ±¬Ø‚àóùõΩ¬Øùõº\beta\ast\overline{\alpha} is a loop based at p0subscriptùëù0p_{0} representing »∑Œì‚Äã(Œ≥)subscriptitalic-»∑Œìùõæ\jmath_{\Gamma}(\gamma) in œÄ1‚Äã(M,p0;r)subscriptùúã1ùëÄsubscriptùëù0ùëü\pi_{1}(M,p_{0};r). Hence we have
