f~n‚Äã(Œ≥‚Äãp0)=QŒõ‚Äã(fn‚àòŒ±)‚àí1‚Äãfn‚Äã(Œ≥‚Äãp0)=QŒõ‚Äã(fn‚àòŒ±¬Ø)‚Äãfn‚Äã(Œ≥‚Äãp0),subscript~ùëìùëõùõæsubscriptùëù0subscriptùëÑŒõsuperscriptsubscriptùëìùëõùõº1subscriptùëìùëõùõæsubscriptùëù0subscriptùëÑŒõsubscriptùëìùëõ¬Øùõºsubscriptùëìùëõùõæsubscriptùëù0\widetilde{f}_{n}(\gamma p_{0})=Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\alpha)^{-1}\,f_{n}(\gamma p_{0})=Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\overline{\alpha})\,f_{n}(\gamma p_{0}),

and

œÜn‚Äã(Œ≥)‚Äãf~n‚Äã(p0)=QŒõ‚Äã(fn‚àò(Œ≤‚àóŒ±¬Ø))‚Äãft‚Äã(p0)=QŒõ‚Äã(fn‚àòŒ±¬Ø)‚ÄãQŒõ‚Äã(fn‚àòŒ≤)‚Äãfn‚Äã(p0).subscriptùúëùëõùõæsubscript~ùëìùëõsubscriptùëù0subscriptùëÑŒõsubscriptùëìùëõùõΩ¬Øùõºsubscriptùëìùë°subscriptùëù0subscriptùëÑŒõsubscriptùëìùëõ¬ØùõºsubscriptùëÑŒõsubscriptùëìùëõùõΩsubscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëù0\varphi_{n}(\gamma)\,\widetilde{f}_{n}(p_{0})=Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ(\beta*\overline{\alpha}))\,f_{t}(p_{0})=Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\overline{\alpha})\,Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\beta)f_{n}(p_{0}).

Hence we have

dN‚Äã(f~n‚Äã(Œ≥‚Äãp0),œÜn‚Äã(Œ≥)‚Äãf~n‚Äã(p0))subscriptùëëùëÅsubscript~ùëìùëõùõæsubscriptùëù0subscriptùúëùëõùõæsubscript~ùëìùëõsubscriptùëù0\displaystyle d_{N}\left(\widetilde{f}_{n}(\gamma p_{0})\,,\,\varphi_{n}(\gamma)\widetilde{f}_{n}(p_{0})\right) =\displaystyle=
dN‚Äã(QŒõ‚Äã(fn‚àòŒ±¬Ø)‚Äãfn‚Äã(Œ≥‚Äãp0),QŒõ‚Äã(fn‚àòŒ±¬Ø)‚ÄãQŒõ‚Äã(fn‚àòŒ≤)‚Äãfn‚Äã(p0))subscriptùëëùëÅsubscriptùëÑŒõsubscriptùëìùëõ¬Øùõºsubscriptùëìùëõùõæsubscriptùëù0subscriptùëÑŒõsubscriptùëìùëõ¬ØùõºsubscriptùëÑŒõsubscriptùëìùëõùõΩsubscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëù0\displaystyle d_{N}(Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\overline{\alpha})\,f_{n}(\gamma p_{0})\,,\,Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\overline{\alpha})\,Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\beta)\,f_{n}(p_{0}))
=dN‚Äã(fn‚Äã(Œ≥‚Äãp0),QŒõ‚Äã(fn‚àòŒ≤)‚Äãfn‚Äã(p0)).absentsubscriptùëëùëÅsubscriptùëìùëõùõæsubscriptùëù0subscriptùëÑŒõsubscriptùëìùëõùõΩsubscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëù0\displaystyle=d_{N}(f_{n}(\gamma p_{0})\,,\,Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\beta)\,f_{n}(p_{0})).

We will now bound the latter quantity by exhibiting a path in NùëÅN from QŒõ‚Äã(fn‚àòŒ≤)‚Äãfn‚Äã(p0)subscriptùëÑŒõsubscriptùëìùëõùõΩsubscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëù0Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\beta)\,f_{n}(p_{0}) to fn‚Äã(Œ≥‚Äãp0)subscriptùëìùëõùõæsubscriptùëù0f_{n}(\gamma p_{0}) whose length we can bound. Indeed, consider the canonical form

ùíû‚Äã(fn‚àòŒ≤)=ùí™‚Äã(fn‚àòŒ≤)‚àóùíÆ‚Äã(fn‚àòŒ≤)ùíûsubscriptùëìùëõùõΩ‚àóùí™subscriptùëìùëõùõΩùíÆsubscriptùëìùëõùõΩ\mathcal{C}(f_{n}\circ\beta)=\mathcal{O}(f_{n}\circ\beta)\ast\mathcal{S}(f_{n}\circ\beta)

of fn‚àòŒ≤subscriptùëìùëõùõΩf_{n}\circ\beta (see Definition 3.10). Recall that ùíÆ‚Äã(fn‚àòŒ≤)ùíÆsubscriptùëìùëõùõΩ\mathcal{S}(f_{n}\circ\beta) starts at QŒõ‚Äã(fn‚àòŒ≤)‚Äãfn‚Äã(p0)subscriptùëÑŒõsubscriptùëìùëõùõΩsubscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëù0Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\beta)\,f_{n}(p_{0}), ends at fn‚Äã(Œ≥‚Äãp0)subscriptùëìùëõùõæsubscriptùëù0f_{n}(\gamma p_{0}), and by Lemma 3.12 has length at most

‚Ñì‚Äã(ùíÆ‚Äã(fn‚àòŒ≤))‚ÑìùíÆsubscriptùëìùëõùõΩ\displaystyle\ell(\mathcal{S}(f_{n}\circ\beta)) ‚â§‚Ñì‚Äã(fn‚àòŒ≤)absent‚ÑìsubscriptùëìùëõùõΩ\displaystyle\leq\ell(f_{n}\circ\beta)
‚â§‚Ñì‚Äã(Œ≤)‚Äã(L+C)=(L+C)‚Äã‚ÄñŒ≥‚Äñ.absent‚ÑìùõΩùêøùê∂ùêøùê∂normùõæ\displaystyle\leq\ell(\beta)(L+C)=(L+C)\|\gamma\|.

Therefore

dN‚Äã(fn‚Äã(Œ≥‚Äãp0),QŒõ‚Äã(fn‚àòŒ≤)‚Äãfn‚Äã(p0))‚â§(L+C)‚Äã‚ÄñŒ≥‚Äñtn,subscriptùëëùëÅsubscriptùëìùëõùõæsubscriptùëù0subscriptùëÑŒõsubscriptùëìùëõùõΩsubscriptùëìùëõsubscriptùëù0ùêøùê∂normùõæsubscriptùë°ùëõd_{N}(f_{n}(\gamma p_{0})\,,\,Q_{\Lambda}(f_{n}\circ\beta)\,f_{n}(p_{0}))\leq\frac{(L+C)\|\gamma\|}{t_{n}},

which completes the proof of (i). The bound in (ii) follows easily:

dN‚Äã(f^n‚Äã(Œ≥‚Äãp0),œÜ^‚Äã(Œ≥)‚Äãf^n‚Äã(p0))subscriptùëëùëÅsubscript^ùëìùëõùõæsubscriptùëù0^ùúëùõæsubscript^ùëìùëõsubscriptùëù0\displaystyle d_{N}\left(\widehat{f}_{n}(\gamma p_{0})\,,\,\widehat{\varphi}(\gamma)\,\widehat{f}_{n}(p_{0})\right) =dN‚Äã(Œªn‚Äãf~n‚Äã(Œ≥‚Äãp0),(Œªn‚ÄãœÜn‚Äã(Œ≥)‚ÄãŒªn‚àí1)‚ÄãŒªn‚Äãf~n‚Äã(p0))absentsubscriptùëëùëÅsubscriptùúÜùëõsubscript~ùëìùëõùõæsubscriptùëù0subscriptùúÜùëõsubscriptùúëùëõùõæsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëõ1subscriptùúÜùëõsubscript~ùëìùëõsubscriptùëù0\displaystyle=d_{N}\left(\lambda_{n}\,\widetilde{f}_{n}(\gamma p_{0})\,,\,(\lambda_{n}\,\varphi_{n}(\gamma)\,\lambda_{n}^{-1})\,\lambda_{n}\,\widetilde{f}_{n}(p_{0})\right)
=dN‚Äã(f~n‚Äã(Œ≥‚Äãp0),œÜn‚Äã(Œ≥)‚Äãf~n‚Äã(p0))absentsubscriptùëëùëÅsubscript~ùëìùëõùõæsubscriptùëù0subscriptùúëùëõùõæsubscript~ùëìùëõsubscriptùëù0\displaystyle=d_{N}\left(\widetilde{f}_{n}(\gamma p_{0})\,,\,\varphi_{n}(\gamma)\,\widetilde{f}_{n}(p_{0})\right)
‚â§(L+C)‚Äã‚ÄñŒ≥‚Äñtn.absentùêøùê∂normùõæsubscriptùë°ùëõ\displaystyle\leq\frac{(L+C)\|\gamma\|}{t_{n}}.

‚àé

We complete the proof that f^^ùëì\widehat{f} is a semiconjugacy between the actions by showing it is œÜ^^ùúë\widehat{\varphi}-equivariant.

Proof of Proposition 7.1.

By taking the limit as n‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùëõn\to\infty in Lemma 7.6.(ii), we see that f^^ùëì\widehat{f} is œÜ^^ùúë\widehat{\varphi}-equivariant on the orbit of p0subscriptùëù0p_{0}. Since Œì‚Äãp0Œìsubscriptùëù0\Gamma p_{0} is dense in MùëÄM, it follows immediately that f^^ùëì\widehat{f} is œÜ^^ùúë\widehat{\varphi}-equivariant.

We can construct a map g^‚Ä≤superscript^ùëî‚Ä≤\widehat{g}^{\prime} simply by applying the same process to the gnsubscriptùëîùëõg_{n} as we did to fnsubscriptùëìùëõf_{n}. We can do this for the same subsequence as used in Construction 7.5. We will use œàùúì\psi to denote the resulting map from Œõ‚ÜíŒì‚ÜíŒõŒì\Lambda\rightarrow\Gamma since at this point it is unclear that œàùúì\psi is œÜ^‚àí1\widehat{\varphi}{{}^{-1}}. By choosing the same subsequence as in Construction 7.5, we guarantee that œÜ^‚àòœï^^ùúë^italic-œï\widehat{\varphi}\circ\widehat{\phi} is an inner automorphism given by cŒ≥subscriptùëêùõæc_{\gamma} for some element Œ≥‚ààŒìùõæŒì\gamma\in\Gamma. Letting g^=Œ≥‚àòg^‚Ä≤^ùëîùõæsuperscript^ùëî‚Ä≤\widehat{g}=\gamma\circ\widehat{g}^{\prime}, we obtain the desired conclusion. ‚àé

8. Promotion of the semiconjugacy

In this section, we will complete the proofs of the Main Theorems 1.4 and 5.1. At this point we have an isomorphism œÜ^:Œì‚ÜíŒõ:^ùúë‚ÜíŒìŒõ\widehat{\varphi}:\Gamma\to\Lambda and a œÜ^^ùúë\widehat{\varphi}-equivariant Lipschitz map f^:M‚ÜíN:^ùëì‚ÜíùëÄùëÅ\widehat{f}:M\to N. We will use algebraic methods to promote the map f^^ùëì\widehat{f} to an affine conjugacy. Here we say a map is affine if it respects the structure of the homogeneous spaces. More precisely:

Definition 8.1.

Given homogeneous spaces G/Hùê∫ùêªG/H and K/Cùêæùê∂K/C, a map f:G/H‚ÜíK/C:ùëì‚Üíùê∫ùêªùêæùê∂f:G/H\rightarrow K/C is affine if there exists a homomorphism œÄ:G‚ÜíK:ùúã‚Üíùê∫ùêæ\pi:G\rightarrow K and an element k‚ààKùëòùêæk\in K such that f‚Äã(x‚ÄãH)=k‚ãÖœÄ‚Äã(x)‚ÄãHùëìùë•ùêª‚ãÖùëòùúãùë•ùêªf(xH)=k\cdot\pi(x)H. If fùëìf is surjective, we call the map an affine submersion, and if fùëìf is a diffeomorphism we call fùëìf an affine isomorphism.

The following result shows that in the setting of homogeneous dynamics, semiconjugacies are affine submersions.

Lemma 8.2.

Let Gùê∫G and KùêæK be compact groups, and let H<Gùêªùê∫H<G (resp. C<Kùê∂ùêæC<K) be a closed subgroup that contains no nontrivial closed normal subgroup of Gùê∫G (resp. KùêæK). Further let ŒìŒì\Gamma (resp. ŒõŒõ\Lambda) be a dense subgroup of Gùê∫G (resp. KùêæK) and assume f:G/H‚ÜíK/C:ùëì‚Üíùê∫ùêªùêæùê∂f:G/H\rightarrow K/C is a continuous map that is equivariant with respect to an isomorphism œÅ:Œì‚ÜíŒõ:ùúå‚ÜíŒìŒõ\rho:\Gamma\rightarrow\Lambda. Then fùëìf is an affine submersion.

Proof.

Since ŒõŒõ\Lambda is dense in KùêæK and œÅùúå\rho is an isomorphism, fùëìf is onto. The map œÅ:Œì‚ÜíK:ùúå‚ÜíŒìùêæ\rho:\Gamma\rightarrow K defines a map graph‚Å°(œÅ):Œì‚ÜíG√óK:graphùúå‚ÜíŒìùê∫ùêæ\operatorname{graph}(\rho):\Gamma\rightarrow G\times K. Let LùêøL be the closure of graph‚Å°(œÅ)‚Äã(Œì)graphùúåŒì\operatorname{graph}(\rho)(\Gamma). Then LùêøL projects onto both Gùê∫G and KùêæK as ŒìŒì\Gamma is dense in Gùê∫G and ŒõŒõ\Lambda is dense in KùêæK. We will see that LùêøL is the graph of a homomorphism from Gùê∫G to KùêæK. Note that we can also define graph‚Å°(f)graphùëì\operatorname{graph}(f) as the subset of G/H√óK/Cùê∫ùêªùêæùê∂G/H\times K/C of the form (x,f‚Äã(x))ùë•ùëìùë•(x,f(x)). As fùëìf is continuous and œÅùúå\rho‚Äìequivariant, graph‚Å°(f)graphùëì\operatorname{graph}(f) is closed and graph‚Å°(œÅ)graphùúå\operatorname{graph}(\rho)‚Äìinvariant, and therefore also LùêøL‚Äìinvariant. Consider the projections œÄ1:G√óK‚ÜíG:subscriptùúã1‚Üíùê∫ùêæùê∫\pi_{1}:G\times K\rightarrow G and œÄ2:G√óK‚ÜíK:subscriptùúã2‚Üíùê∫ùêæùêæ\pi_{2}:G\times K\rightarrow K and denote their restrictions to LùêøL by œÄiLsuperscriptsubscriptùúãùëñùêø\pi_{i}^{L}, i=1,2ùëñ12i=1,2. Also consider the projections p1:G/H√óK/C‚ÜíG/H:subscriptùëù1‚Üíùê∫ùêªùêæùê∂ùê∫ùêªp_{1}:G/H\times K/C\rightarrow G/H and p2:G/H√óK/C‚ÜíK/C:subscriptùëù2‚Üíùê∫ùêªùêæùê∂ùêæùê∂p_{2}:G/H\times K/C\rightarrow K/C and notice that p1subscriptùëù1p_{1} is one-to-one when restricted to graph‚Å°(f)graphùëì\operatorname{graph}(f). This immediately implies that ker‚Å°(œÄ1L)kernelsuperscriptsubscriptùúã1ùêø\ker(\pi_{1}^{L}) is trivial since LùêøL acts effectively on graph‚Å°(f)graphùëì\operatorname{graph}(f) by the assumption on the absence of normal subgroups in HùêªH and Cùê∂C. Now we can define a map œÅ^:œÄ2‚àò(œÄ1L):‚àí1G‚ÜíK\widehat{\rho}:\pi_{2}\circ(\pi^{L}_{1}){{}^{-1}}:G\rightarrow K which is a homomorphism extending œÅùúå\rho and whose graph is LùêøL. The graph‚Å°(œÅ^)graph^ùúå\operatorname{graph}(\widehat{\rho})‚Äìinvariance of graph‚Å°(f)graphùëì\operatorname{graph}(f) then exactly means that fùëìf is œÅ^^ùúå\widehat{\rho}‚Äìequivariant. ‚àé

The difficulty with Lemma 8.2 for applications is that it might be the case that G=G1√óG2ùê∫subscriptùê∫1subscriptùê∫2G=G_{1}\times G_{2} and K=G1ùêæsubscriptùê∫1K=G_{1} and the semiconjugacy is given by projection onto the first factor. In the setting of our theorems, the fact that the quasi-isometry has a coarse inverse allows us to rule out this kind of behavior because we also have a semiconjugacy in the other direction. In conjunction with the last statement in Proposition 7.1 the following result, which gives a criterion for promoting a semiconjugacy to an affine conjugacy, finishes the proofs of the Main Theorems 1.4 and 5.1.

Corollary 8.3.

Let Gùê∫G and KùêæK be compact groups, and let H<Gùêªùê∫H<G (resp. C<Kùê∂ùêæC<K) be a closed subgroup that contains no nontrivial closed normal subgroup of Gùê∫G (resp. KùêæK). Further let ŒìŒì\Gamma (resp. ŒõŒõ\Lambda) be a dense subgroup of Gùê∫G (resp. KùêæK) and assume there is a isomorphism œÅ:Œì‚ÜíŒõ:ùúå‚ÜíŒìŒõ\rho:\Gamma\rightarrow\Lambda and a continuous œÅùúå\rho-equivariant map f:G/H‚ÜíK/C:ùëì‚Üíùê∫ùêªùêæùê∂f:G/H\rightarrow K/C and also a continuous œÅ‚àí1\rho{{}^{-1}}-equivariant map h:K/C‚ÜíG/H:‚Ñé‚Üíùêæùê∂ùê∫ùêªh:K/C\rightarrow G/H. Then fùëìf and h‚Ñéh are affine isomorphisms.

Proof.

We consider the map f‚àòh:G/H‚ÜíG/H:ùëì‚Ñé‚Üíùê∫ùêªùê∫ùêªf\circ h:G/H\rightarrow G/H and follow the proof of Lemma 8.2. In this context, the map œÅùúå\rho is the identity map from ŒìŒì\Gamma to itself and so graph‚Å°(œÅ)graphùúå\operatorname{graph}(\rho) is the diagonal embedding of ŒìŒì\Gamma in G√óGùê∫ùê∫G\times G and the closure LùêøL of graph‚Å°(œÅ)graphùúå\operatorname{graph}(\rho) is Gùê∫G embedded diagonally in G√óGùê∫ùê∫G\times G. Therefore the map œÅ^^ùúå\widehat{\rho} is the identity map on Gùê∫G and this immediately implies f‚àòhùëì‚Ñéf\circ h is an affine isomorphism. By Lemma 8.2, both fùëìf and h‚Ñéh are affine submersions. If the composition of two affine submersions is an affine isomorphism, both maps are affine isomorphisms. ‚àé

9. Construction of families of expanders

In this section we show how to apply Theorem 5.1 to construct expanders with a wide variety of distinct geometries. The main point is to construct large families of group actions that are not conjugate for groups where we can show quasi-isometry of warped cones implies algebraic conjugacy of actions.

9.1. Outline

To construct a continuum of non-isomorphic actions with various spectral properties, we will use the following construction. Let KùêæK be a simple compact group and Œî<KŒîùêæ\Delta<K a fixed subgroup. We will consider a free group FnsubscriptùêπùëõF_{n} and recall that a generic homomorphism of FnsubscriptùêπùëõF_{n} to KùêæK is faithful with dense image. We then consider left-right actions Œî√óFnŒîsubscriptùêπùëõ\Delta\times F_{n} on KùêæK where ŒîŒî\Delta acts on the left and FnsubscriptùêπùëõF_{n} acts on the right. We observe that this action can also be written as a left action of Œî√óFnŒîsubscriptùêπùëõ\Delta\times F_{n} on (K√óK)/diag‚Å°(K)ùêæùêædiagùêæ(K\times K)/\operatorname{diag}(K), making it clear that the action fits into our setting of minimal isometric actions on homogeneous spaces. We will show that a generic choice of FnsubscriptùêπùëõF_{n} in KùêæK gives rise to a free action. Theorem 5.1 shows that any pair of such actions with quasi-isometric warped cones are conjugate by an affine map. By making judicious choices of ŒîŒî\Delta, we can guarantee sufficient spectral properties so that results of Sawicki and Vigolo allow us to show that the level sets of the cones are expanders or superexpanders [Saw1, Vig1].

9.2. Spectral gaps, (super)expanders, reductions to algebraic constructions

In this subsection we recall some definitions concerning spectral gaps, expanders and superexpanders and the connections between them and warped cones. At the end of the subsection we reduce the proofs of Theorems 1.7 and 1.8 to the existence of continuous families of non-conjugate actions of well-chosen groups. The more expert reader may choose to skip to Proposition 9.4 and read only reductions which follow easily from known results.

Definition 9.1.

Given a class of Banach spaces ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} of Banach spaces we say that a sequence of graphs Gn=(Vn,En)subscriptùê∫ùëõsubscriptùëâùëõsubscriptùê∏ùëõG_{n}=(V_{n},E_{n}) is an expander family for ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} if

  1. (1)

    |Vn|‚Üí‚àû‚Üísubscriptùëâùëõ|V_{n}|\rightarrow\infty, and there exists k>1ùëò1k>1 such that each Gnsubscriptùê∫ùëõG_{n} is has degree bounded by kùëòk, and

  2. (2)

    given any Eùê∏E in ‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞\mathcal{E} there are p,Œ∑>0ùëùùúÇ0p,\eta>0 such that for any family of maps fn:Vn‚ÜíE:subscriptùëìùëõ‚Üísubscriptùëâùëõùê∏f_{n}:V_{n}\rightarrow E we have

    1|Vn|2‚Äã‚àë(u,v)‚ààVn√óVn‚Äñ(fn‚Äã(u),fn‚Äã(v))‚ÄñEp‚â§Œ∑k‚Äã|Vn|‚Äã‚àë(u,v)‚ààEn‚Äñ(fn‚Äã(u),fn‚Äã(v))‚ÄñEp.1superscriptsubscriptùëâùëõ2subscriptùë¢ùë£subscriptùëâùëõsubscriptùëâùëõsuperscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptùëìùëõùë¢subscriptùëìùëõùë£ùê∏ùëùùúÇùëòsubscriptùëâùëõsubscriptùë¢ùë£subscriptùê∏ùëõsuperscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptùëìùëõùë¢subscriptùëìùëõùë£ùê∏ùëù\frac{1}{|V_{n}|^{2}}\sum_{(u,v)\in V_{n}\times V_{n}}\|(f_{n}(u),f_{n}(v))\|_{E}^{p}\leq\frac{\eta}{k|V_{n}|}\sum_{(u,v)\in E_{n}}\|(f_{n}(u),f_{n}(v))\|_{E}^{p}.

The standard definition of an expander or expander sequence is a family of graphs that is an expander for a separable Hilbert space. It is standard to call a family of graphs a superexpander if it is expander for the class Eùê∏E of uniformly convex Banach spaces. Our results here work equally well if a superexpander is defined to be an expander of the class Eùê∏E of all Banach spaces of nontrivial type.

Given an action of a group ŒìŒì\Gamma on a measure space (X,Œº)ùëãùúá(X,\mu), one has a natural unitary representation œÅùúå\rho on L2‚Äã(X,Œº)superscriptùêø2ùëãùúáL^{2}(X,\mu). Furthermore, given any Banach space Eùê∏E, one can form the space of square-integrable Eùê∏E-valued functions L2‚Äã(X,Œº,E)superscriptùêø2ùëãùúáùê∏L^{2}(X,\mu,E) and ŒìŒì\Gamma has a natural isometric representation œÅùúå\rho on L2‚Äã(X,Œº,E)superscriptùêø2ùëãùúáùê∏L^{2}(X,\mu,E) by pre-composition. The first representation is in fact the case of E=‚Ñùùê∏‚ÑùE=\mathbb{R} or ‚ÑÇ‚ÑÇ\mathbb{C}. For ŒìŒì\Gamma finitely generated by a set SùëÜS, we say that the ŒìŒì\Gamma‚Äìaction on L2‚Äã(X,Œº,E)superscriptùêø2ùëãùúáùê∏L^{2}(X,\mu,E) has a spectral gap if

supŒ≥‚ààS‚ÄñœÅ‚Äã(Œ≥)‚Äãv‚àív‚Äñ‚â•œµ‚Äã‚Äñv‚Äñ.subscriptsupremumùõæùëÜnormùúåùõæùë£ùë£italic-œµnormùë£\sup_{\gamma\in S}\|\rho(\gamma)v-v\|\geq\epsilon\|v\|.
Proposition 9.2.

If Œî<Œî‚Ä≤ŒîsuperscriptŒî‚Ä≤\Delta<\Delta^{\prime} are finitely generated groups and we have an action of Œî‚Ä≤superscriptŒî‚Ä≤\Delta^{\prime} on a space (X,Œº)ùëãùúá(X,\mu) where the restriction of the action to ŒîŒî\Delta has a spectral gap on L2‚Äã(X,Œº,E)superscriptùêø2ùëãùúáùê∏L^{2}(X,\mu,E), then the Œî‚Ä≤superscriptŒî‚Ä≤\Delta^{\prime}‚Äìaction does as well.

In [Vig1], Vigolo gives a systematic treatment of how to discretize level sets of warped cones to produce expander graphs. We call these discretizations the geometric graphs corresponding to the ŒìŒì\Gamma‚Äìaction on XùëãX. We use the following result which combines results of Sawicki and Vigolo, see also papers of Nowak‚ÄìSawicki and De Laat‚ÄìVigolo [NS, Vig1, Saw1, dLV] for related developments. Special cases of the following proposition were certainly known before these works and the basic ideas seem to go back to the earliest days of the subject.

Proposition 9.3.

Let a finitely generated group ŒìŒì\Gamma act on a compact metric space MùëÄM preserving a Radon measure Œºùúá\mu and with a spectral gap on L2‚Äã(X,Œº)superscriptùêø2ùëãùúáL^{2}(X,\mu). Then there exist constants L>1ùêø1L>1 and C>0ùê∂0C>0 and graphs Gnsubscriptùê∫ùëõG_{n} such that Gnsubscriptùê∫ùëõG_{n} is (L,C)ùêøùê∂(L,C)‚Äìquasi-isometric to the level set XnsubscriptùëãùëõX_{n} in the warped cone ùíû‚Äã(Œì‚Ü∑X)ùíû‚Ü∑Œìùëã\mathcal{C}(\Gamma\curvearrowright X) and such that the family of graphs {Gn}subscriptùê∫ùëõ\{G_{n}\} is an expander sequence. We call these graphs the geometric graphs for the action of ŒìŒì\Gamma on MùëÄM.

The ŒìŒì\Gamma‚Äìaction on L2‚Äã(X,Œº,E)superscriptùêø2ùëãùúáùê∏L^{2}(X,\mu,E) has a spectral gap if and only if the geometric graphs for the ŒìŒì\Gamma action on MùëÄM are expanders with respect to Eùê∏E.

Finally we remark that if Eùê∏E is a Hilbert space, then it is easy to see that a spectral gap on L2‚Äã(X,Œº)superscriptùêø2ùëãùúáL^{2}(X,\mu) is equivalent to one on L2‚Äã(X,Œº,E)superscriptùêø2ùëãùúáùê∏L^{2}(X,\mu,E).

To state our key reductions, we need two more definitions. Given two groups ŒìŒì\Gamma and ŒîŒî\Delta where Œì,Œî<KŒìŒîùêæ\Gamma,\Delta<K we define the left-right action of Œì√óŒîŒìŒî\Gamma\times\Delta on KùêæK by acting on the left by ŒìŒì\Gamma and on the right by ŒîŒî\Delta. Given two actions œÅ1subscriptùúå1\rho_{1} and œÅ2subscriptùúå2\rho_{2} of a single group ŒîŒî\Delta on a space XùëãX we say the actions are conjugate up to automorphism if there exists an automorphism œà:Œî‚ÜíŒî:ùúì‚ÜíŒîŒî\psi:\Delta\rightarrow\Delta such that œÅ1‚Äã(Œ¥)=œÅ2‚Äã(œà‚Äã(Œ¥))subscriptùúå1ùõøsubscriptùúå2ùúìùõø\rho_{1}(\delta)=\rho_{2}(\psi(\delta)) for any Œ¥ùõø\delta in ŒîŒî\Delta. This corrects a small discrepancy in standard terminology where a conjugacy between actions of a priori different groups involves a homomorphism identifying the groups but a conjugacy between two actions of the same group implicitly assumes the identification œàùúì\psi is the identity.

Proposition 9.4.

To prove Theorem 1.7 it suffices to produce a finitely presented dense subgroup ŒìŒì\Gamma of a compact group KùêæK with a spectral gap on L2‚Äã(K)superscriptùêø2ùêæL^{2}(K) such that ŒìŒì\Gamma has property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL} and there is a continuum of free left-right actions of Œì√óFnŒìsubscriptùêπùëõ\Gamma\times F_{n} on KùêæK which are not conjugate up to automorphism for some k>1ùëò1k>1.

Proposition 9.5.

To prove Theorem 1.8 it suffices to produce a finitely presented dense subgroup ŒìŒì\Gamma of a compact group KùêæK where ŒìŒì\Gamma has strong property (T)ùëá(T) and property FSLFSL\operatorname{FSL} such that there is a continuum of left-right actions of Œì√óFnŒìsubscriptùêπùëõ\Gamma\times F_{n} on KùêæK which are not conjugate up to automorphism for some k>1ùëò1k>1.

Both propositions follow immediately from Propositions 9.3, Proposition 9.2, Theorem 1.5 and Corollary 5.18.

9.3. Genericity of freely acting, dense subgroups

Note that KùêæK as a compact group is also a real algebraic group. We will write Hom‚Å°(Fn,K)Homsubscriptùêπùëõùêæ\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K) for the representation variety of homomorphisms of FnsubscriptùêπùëõF_{n} into KùêæK and Hom‚Å°(Fn,K)/‚Å£/KHomsubscriptùêπùëõùêæùêæ\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K)\mathbin{\mkern-2.0mu/\mkern-6.0mu/\mkern-2.0mu}K for the character variety. Note that we take the geometric invariant theory quotient here, but that for compact groups this is the same as the set theoretic one. Also observe that Hom‚Å°(Fn,K)‚âÖKnHomsubscriptùêπùëõùêæsuperscriptùêæùëõ\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K)\cong K^{n} as varieties and so one can think of Hom‚Å°(Fn,K)/‚Å£/KHomsubscriptùêπùëõùêæùêæ\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K)\mathbin{\mkern-2.0mu/\mkern-6.0mu/\mkern-2.0mu}K as Kn/‚Å£/KsuperscriptùêæùëõùêæK^{n}\mathbin{\mkern-2.0mu/\mkern-6.0mu/\mkern-2.0mu}K where KùêæK action on KnsuperscriptùêæùëõK^{n} is by simultaneous conjugation in all coordinates. Elements of Kn/KsuperscriptùêæùëõùêæK^{n}/K are often called multidimensional conjugacy classes and the action of KùêæK on KnsuperscriptùêæùëõK^{n} by simultaneous conjugation will be referred to as simply conjugation below.

Lemma 9.6.

  1. (1)

    The subset of Hom‚Å°(Fn,K)Homsubscriptùêπùëõùêæ\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K) consisting of dense, faithful representations is the complement of a countable union of proper subvarieties.

  2. (2)

    Fix a countable subgroup Œî‚äÜKŒîùêæ\Delta\subseteq K. The subset of Hom‚Å°(Fn,K)Homsubscriptùêπùëõùêæ\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K) such that the left-right action of Œî√óFnŒîsubscriptùêπùëõ\Delta\times F_{n} on KùêæK is free is the complement of a countable union of proper subvarieties.

  3. (3)

    Let K=S‚ÄãU‚Äã(n)ùêæùëÜùëàùëõK=SU(n) and fix a countable dense subgroup Œî‚äÜKŒîùêæ\Delta\subseteq K. Then there exists V‚äÇKùëâùêæV\subset K that is a countable union of subvarieties such that if x‚àâVùë•ùëâx\notin V, we have ‚ü®Œî,x‚ü©‚âÖŒî‚àó‚Ñ§Œîùë•Œî‚Ñ§\langle\Delta,x\rangle\cong\Delta*\mathbb{Z}.

Proof.

We note that (1)1(1) is standard and provide a proof for completeness and also to motivate the proof of (2)2(2). We note that up to conjugacy, KùêæK has only countably many closed subgroups Cùê∂C and any of these is an algebraic subgroup, so that Hom‚Å°(Fn,C)Homsubscriptùêπùëõùê∂\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},C) is a proper subvariety of Hom‚Å°(Fn,K)Homsubscriptùêπùëõùêæ\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K). Furthermore the set of representations of FnsubscriptùêπùëõF_{n} into any conjugate of Cùê∂C in KùêæK can be identified with the KùêæK‚Äìconjugates of Hom‚Å°(Fn,C)Homsubscriptùêπùëõùê∂\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},C) in Hom‚Å°(Fn,K)Homsubscriptùêπùëõùêæ\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K), so the set of homomorphisms of FnsubscriptùêπùëõF_{n} into any conjugate of Cùê∂C is a proper subvariety of Hom‚Å°(Fn,K)/‚Å£/KHomsubscriptùêπùëõùêæùêæ\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K)\mathbin{\mkern-2.0mu/\mkern-6.0mu/\mkern-2.0mu}K. This shows that the set representations whose image is not dense, is a countable union of closed subvarieties. We now check that the set of representations that are not faithful is also contained in a (different) countable union of closed subvarieties, which suffices to prove the first claim. For any word w‚ààFnùë§subscriptùêπùëõw\in F_{n}, denote by V‚Äã(w)‚äÜHom‚Å°(Fn,K)ùëâùë§HomsubscriptùêπùëõùêæV(w)\subseteq\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K) the set of representations that vanish on wùë§w. The word map evw:Hom‚Å°(Fn,K)‚ÜíK:subscriptevùë§‚ÜíHomsubscriptùêπùëõùêæùêæ\text{ev}_{w}:\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K)\rightarrow K that evaluates a representation on the word wùë§w is clearly a rational map. It follows that V‚Äã(w)ùëâùë§V(w) is a closed subvariety of Hom‚Å°(Fn,K)Homsubscriptùêπùëõùêæ\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K). Further note there are only countably many words in FnsubscriptùêπùëõF_{n}, so it remains to show that V‚Äã(w)ùëâùë§V(w) is a proper subvariety for every wùë§w.

To do so, it suffices to exhibit a single faithful FnsubscriptùêπùëõF_{n} in KùêæK, i.e. a single point not in V‚Äã(w)ùëâùë§V(w). To motivate the proof of (2)2(2) we proceed differently. We recall a theorem of Borel that says that the map evw:Hom‚Å°(Fn,K)‚ÜíK:subscriptevùë§‚ÜíHomsubscriptùêπùëõùêæùêæ\text{ev}_{w}:\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K)\rightarrow K is not only rational but dominant [Bor]. This implies the image is Zariski‚Äìdense and in particular that not every point maps to the identity, proving that V‚Äã(w)ùëâùë§V(w) is proper. Since V‚Äã(w)ùëâùë§V(w) and its complement are both conjugation invariant, this proves that the image of V‚Äã(w)ùëâùë§V(w) in the character variety is also a proper subvariety.

We now analyze stabilizers of the left-right action of Œî√óFnŒîsubscriptùêπùëõ\Delta\times F_{n} on KùêæK in order to be able to apply Borel‚Äôs theorem again. Computing, we see that Œ¥cŒ≥=‚àí1c\delta c\gamma{{}^{-1}}=c if and only if Œ¥=c‚ÄãŒ≥‚àí1‚Äãcùõøùëêsuperscriptùõæ1ùëê\delta=c{{}^{-1}}\gamma c. I.e. fixing an element Œ¥‚ààŒîùõøŒî\delta\in\Delta, the set of elements Œ≥ùõæ\gamma in FnsubscriptùêπùëõF_{n} where the left-right action of (Œ¥,Œ≥)ùõøùõæ(\delta,\gamma) has a fixed point is the set of elements Œ≥ùõæ\gamma whose image is a conjugate of Œ¥ùõø\delta. We fix an enumeration {Œ¥i}i‚àà‚Ñïsubscriptsubscriptùõøùëñùëñ‚Ñï\{\delta_{i}\}_{i\in\mathbb{N}} of ŒîŒî\Delta. For any word w‚ààFnùë§subscriptùêπùëõw\in F_{n}, the set of representations of FnsubscriptùêπùëõF_{n} into KùêæK where the image of wùë§w is conjugate to Œ¥isubscriptùõøùëñ\delta_{i} is the subset W‚Äã(w,i)ùëäùë§ùëñW(w,i) of Hom‚Å°(Fn,K)Homsubscriptùêπùëõùêæ\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K) where evw‚Äã(k1,‚Ä¶,kn)subscriptevùë§subscriptùëò1‚Ä¶subscriptùëòùëõ\text{ev}_{w}(k_{1},\ldots,k_{n}) is conjugate to Œ¥isubscriptùõøùëñ\delta_{i}. Recall that conjugacy classes of semisimple elements in algebraic groups are Zariski‚Äìclosed and that every element of a compact algebraic group is semisimple. This immediately implies W‚Äã(w,i)ùëäùë§ùëñW(w,i) is a closed subvariety since it is the pre-image of a closed subvariety under a rational map. Since evwsubscriptevùë§\text{ev}_{w} is a dominant map to KùêæK, we also see that W‚Äã(w,i)ùëäùë§ùëñW(w,i) is a proper subvariety of Hom‚Å°(Fn,K)Homsubscriptùêπùëõùêæ\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K). Since it is clearly conjugation‚Äìinvariant we are done as above.

We now prove the third point which is quite similar to the first. We consider a word w‚ààŒî‚àó‚Ñ§ùë§Œî‚Ñ§w\in\Delta*\mathbb{Z} as a map from K‚ÜíK‚ÜíùêæùêæK\rightarrow K by inserting x‚ààKùë•ùêæx\in K into wùë§w anytime the generator for ‚Ñ§‚Ñ§\mathbb{Z} appears. We let V‚Äã(w)ùëâùë§V(w) be the set of x‚ààKùë•ùêæx\in K such that w‚Äã(x)=Idùë§ùë•Idw(x)=\operatorname{Id}. This set is clearly a subvariety of KùêæK and to prove the result it suffices to see that V‚Äã(w)ùëâùë§V(w) is proper for each wùë§w. To see this, it suffices to find one faithful representation of Œî‚àó‚Ñ§Œî‚Ñ§\Delta*\mathbb{Z} into KùêæK. This follows easily from the existence of one such representation into G=S‚ÄãL‚Äã(n,‚ÑÇ)ùê∫ùëÜùêøùëõ‚ÑÇG=SL(n,\mathbb{C}) and the fact that S‚ÄãU‚Äã(n)ùëÜùëàùëõSU(n) is Zariski dense in S‚ÄãL‚Äã(n,‚ÑÇ)ùëÜùêøùëõ‚ÑÇSL(n,\mathbb{C}). To clarify, we can define a map w~:G‚ÜíG:~ùë§‚Üíùê∫ùê∫\tilde{w}:G\rightarrow G exactly as we define wùë§w and let V~‚Äã(w)~ùëâùë§\tilde{V}(w) be the subset of Gùê∫G where w~‚Äã(x)=Id~ùë§ùë•Id\tilde{w}(x)=\operatorname{Id}. Since S‚ÄãU‚Äã(n)ùëÜùëàùëõSU(n) is Zariski dense in S‚ÄãL‚Äã(n,C)ùëÜùêøùëõùê∂SL(n,C) as a complex subvariety and V~‚Äã(w)~ùëâùë§\tilde{V}(w) is a complex subvariety, if V~‚Äã(w)~ùëâùë§\tilde{V}(w) is a proper subset of Gùê∫G then V‚Äã(w)ùëâùë§V(w) is a proper subset of KùêæK. The existence of a faithful embedding of Œî‚àó‚Ñ§Œî‚Ñ§\Delta*\mathbb{Z} in S‚ÄãL‚Äã(n,‚ÑÇ)ùëÜùêøùëõ‚ÑÇSL(n,\mathbb{C}) where ŒîŒî\Delta embeds in S‚ÄãL‚Äã(n,‚ÑÇ)ùëÜùêøùëõ‚ÑÇSL(n,\mathbb{C}) is originally due to Nisnevich and was rediscovered later by Shalen [Nis, Sha]. ‚àé

Remark: Borel‚Äôs proof that word maps are dominant uses that there are dense free subgroups of at least SU‚Å°(n)SUùëõ\operatorname{SU}(n), so our proof of (1)1(1) using dominance really depends on the fact that (1)1(1) was already known. However, the proof of (1)1(1) given above serves well to motivate the proof of (2)2(2).

9.4. Proofs

Before beginning the proof of Theorem 1.7, we make a few historical remarks. We will need a dense subgroup Œî<KŒîùêæ\Delta<K with a spectral gap on L2‚Äã(K)superscriptùêø2ùêæL^{2}(K). For particular choices of KùêæK, many of these are constructed as lattices in a Lie group Gùê∫G which have dense embeddings in a compact form KùêæK of Gùê∫G by Margulis, Sullivan and Drin‚Äôfeld [Mar2, Sul, Dri]. More recently, examples were found by more elementary methods by Gamburd, Jakobson and Sarnak in [GJS] where the authors conjecture that a generic dense free subgroup of a compact simple group KùêæK will have a spectral gap. In recent work towards that conjecture, Bourgain‚ÄìGamburd and Benoist‚ÄìDe Saxce show that any dense free subgroup of KùêæK with algebraic entries has a spectral gap [BG2, BG1, BdS]. If the Gamburd‚ÄìJakobson‚ÄìSarnak conjecture is correct, one can prove Theorem 1.7 using only left actions of a free group and not left-right actions.

Proof of Theorem 1.7 (families of expanders).

Fix K=SU‚Å°(n)ùêæSUùëõK=\operatorname{SU}(n) and a free group Œî‚äÜKŒîùêæ\Delta\subseteq K with a spectral gap on L2‚Äã(K)superscriptùêø2ùêæL^{2}(K). For any k‚ààKùëòùêæk\in K, the group ‚ü®Œî,k‚ü©Œîùëò\langle\Delta,k\rangle has spectral gap. Further, by Lemma 9.6.(3), for a generic choice of kùëòk, we have ‚ü®Œî,k‚ü©‚âÖŒî‚àó‚Ñ§‚âÖFnŒîùëò‚àóŒî‚Ñ§subscriptùêπùëõ\langle\Delta,k\rangle\cong\Delta\ast\mathbb{Z}\cong F_{n}. This produces a continuous of free group actions on KùêæK which are conjugate if and only if the have representatives in the character variety that are related by an automorphism of the free group. Since Out‚Å°(Fn)Outsubscriptùêπùëõ\operatorname{Out}(F_{n}) orbits in the character variety are countable, this produces continuous families that are not conjugate, so which have warped cones giving rise to quasi-isometrically disjoint families of expanders by Theorem 1.5.

‚àé

A different construction is to choose a simple compact Lie group KùêæK and a dense subgroup Œî‚äÜKŒîùêæ\Delta\subseteq K with a spectral gap on L2‚Äã(K)superscriptùêø2ùêæL^{2}(K). As discussed above, we consider Œì=Œî√óFnŒìŒîsubscriptùêπùëõ\Gamma=\Delta\times F_{n} and left-right ŒìŒì\Gamma‚Äìactions on KùêæK as defined by an element Œ±‚ààHom‚Å°(Fn,K)ùõºHomsubscriptùêπùëõùêæ\alpha\in\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K). Using Lemma 9.6 we see that off of a countably union of subvarieties in Hom‚Å°(Fn,K)/‚Å£/KHomsubscriptùêπùëõùêæùêæ\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K)\mathbin{\mkern-2.0mu/\mkern-6.0mu/\mkern-2.0mu}K the resulting left-right action of Œî√óFnŒîsubscriptùêπùëõ\Delta\times F_{n} is free. This produces a continuumm of non-conjugate Œî√óFnŒîsubscriptùêπùëõ\Delta\times F_{n} actions. Since the orbit of any action under Aut‚Å°(Œî√óFn)AutŒîsubscriptùêπùëõ\operatorname{Aut}(\Delta\times F_{n}) in Hom‚Å°(Fn,K)/‚Å£/KHomsubscriptùêπùëõùêæùêæ\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K)\mathbin{\mkern-2.0mu/\mkern-6.0mu/\mkern-2.0mu}K is countable, this suffices to verify the hypotheses of Proposition 9.4.

Proof of Theorem 1.8 (families of superexpanders).

The proof is exactly as the above proof of Theorem 1.7, though the choices of ŒîŒî\Delta and KùêæK are more limited. We can choose ŒîŒî\Delta as in the paper of De Laat‚ÄìVigolo to be a cocompact lattice in SL‚Å°(d,‚Ñöp)SLùëësubscript‚Ñöùëù\operatorname{SL}(d,\mathbb{Q}_{p}) that has a dense embedding in K=SO‚Å°(d)ùêæSOùëëK=\operatorname{SO}(d) [dLV]. As in that paper it follows from Lafforgue‚Äôs work on strong property (T)ùëá(T) [Laf] that the action on L2‚Äã(K,Œº,E)superscriptùêø2ùêæùúáùê∏L^{2}(K,\mu,E) has a spectral gap for any Eùê∏E with nontrivial type and so in particular for any uniformly convex Eùê∏E. More general choices are also possible by work of Liao [Lia]. The rest of the proof follows exactly as in the previous case, where we again choose generic homomorphisms Œ±‚ààHom‚Å°(Fn,K)ùõºHomsubscriptùêπùëõùêæ\alpha\in\operatorname{Hom}(F_{n},K) to define a left-right action of Œì=Œî√óFnŒìŒîsubscriptùêπùëõ\Gamma=\Delta\times F_{n} on KùêæK. ‚àé
